      yourself incapable and your life a spoiled life. You have everything
      before you, everything. And you....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He did not finish his sentence, but his tone showed how highly he thought
      of his friend and how much he expected of him in the future.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How can he talk like that?&rdquo; thought Pierre. He considered his friend a
      model of perfection because Prince Andrew possessed in the highest degree
      just the very qualities Pierre lacked, and which might be best described
      as strength of will. Pierre was always astonished at Prince Andrew&rsquo;s calm
      manner of treating everybody, his extraordinary memory, his extensive
      reading (he had read everything, knew everything, and had an opinion about
      everything), but above all at his capacity for work and study. And if
      Pierre was often struck by Andrew&rsquo;s lack of capacity for philosophical
      meditation (to which he himself was particularly addicted), he regarded
      even this not as a defect but as a sign of strength.
    </p>
    <p>
      Even in the best, most friendly and simplest relations of life, praise and
      commendation are essential, just as grease is necessary to wheels that
      they may run smoothly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My part is played out,&rdquo; said Prince Andrew. &ldquo;What&rsquo;s the use of talking
      about me? Let us talk about you,&rdquo; he added after a silence, smiling at his
      reassuring thoughts.
    </p>
    <p>
      That smile was immediately reflected on Pierre&rsquo;s face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But what is there to say about me?&rdquo; said Pierre, his face relaxing into a
      careless, merry smile. &ldquo;What am I? An illegitimate son!&rdquo; He suddenly
      blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great effort to say
      this. &ldquo;Without a name and without means... And it really...&rdquo; But he did
      not say what &ldquo;it really&rdquo; was. &ldquo;For the present I am free and am all right.
      Only I haven&rsquo;t the least idea what I am to do; I wanted to consult you
      seriously.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew looked kindly at him, yet his glance&mdash;friendly and
      affectionate as it was&mdash;expressed a sense of his own superiority.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man among our whole
      set. Yes, you&rsquo;re all right! Choose what you will; it&rsquo;s all the same.
      You&rsquo;ll be all right anywhere. But look here: give up visiting those
      Kurágins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so badly&mdash;all
      this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What would you have, my dear fellow?&rdquo; answered Pierre, shrugging his
      shoulders. &ldquo;Women, my dear fellow; women!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t understand it,&rdquo; replied Prince Andrew. &ldquo;Women who are <i>comme il
      faut</i>, that&rsquo;s a different matter; but the Kurágins&rsquo; set of women,
      &lsquo;women and wine&rsquo; I don&rsquo;t understand!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre was staying at Prince Vasíli Kurágin&rsquo;s and sharing the dissipated
      life of his son Anatole, the son whom they were planning to reform by
      marrying him to Prince Andrew&rsquo;s sister.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you know?&rdquo; said Pierre, as if suddenly struck by a happy thought,
      &ldquo;seriously, I have long been thinking of it.... Leading such a life I
      can&rsquo;t decide or think properly about anything. One&rsquo;s head aches, and one
      spends all one&rsquo;s money. He asked me for tonight, but I won&rsquo;t go.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You give me your word of honor not to go?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;On my honor!&rdquo;
     </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0009" id="link2HCH0009"></a>
      CHAPTER IX
    </h2>
    <p>
      It was past one o&rsquo;clock when Pierre left his friend. It was a cloudless,
      northern, summer night. Pierre took an open cab intending to drive
      straight home. But the nearer he drew to the house the more he felt the
      impossibility of going to sleep on such a night. It was light enough to
      see a long way in the deserted street and it seemed more like morning or
      evening than night. On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole Kurágin was
      expecting the usual set for cards that evening, after which there was
      generally a drinking bout, finishing with visits of a kind Pierre was very
      fond of.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I should like to go to Kurágin&rsquo;s,&rdquo; thought he.
    </p>
    <p>
      But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go there.
      Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so passionately
      once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to that he
      decided to go. The thought immediately occurred to him that his promise to
      Prince Andrew was of no account, because before he gave it he had already
      promised Prince Anatole to come to his gathering; &ldquo;besides,&rdquo; thought he,
      &ldquo;all such &lsquo;words of honor&rsquo; are conventional things with no definite
      meaning, especially if one considers that by tomorrow one may be dead, or
      something so extraordinary may happen to one that honor and dishonor will
      be all the same!&rdquo; Pierre often indulged in reflections of this sort,
      nullifying all his decisions and intentions. He went to Kurágin&rsquo;s.
    </p>
    <p>
      Reaching the large house near the Horse Guards&rsquo; barracks, in which Anatole
      lived, Pierre entered the lighted porch, ascended the stairs, and went in
      at the open door. There was no one in the anteroom; empty bottles, cloaks,
      and overshoes were lying about; there was a smell of alcohol, and sounds
      of voices and shouting in the distance.
    </p>
    <p>
      Cards and supper were over, but the visitors had not yet dispersed. Pierre
      threw off his cloak and entered the first room, in which were the remains
      of supper. A footman, thinking no one saw him, was drinking on the sly
      what was left in the glasses. From the third room came sounds of laughter,
      the shouting of familiar voices, the growling of a bear, and general
      commotion. Some eight or nine young men were crowding anxiously round an
      open window. Three others were romping with a young bear, one pulling him
      by the chain and trying to set him at the others.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I bet a hundred on Stevens!&rdquo; shouted one.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mind, no holding on!&rdquo; cried another.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I bet on Dólokhov!&rdquo; cried a third. &ldquo;Kurágin, you part our hands.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There, leave Bruin alone; here&rsquo;s a bet on.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;At one draught, or he loses!&rdquo; shouted a fourth.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Jacob, bring a bottle!&rdquo; shouted the host, a tall, handsome fellow who
      stood in the midst of the group, without a coat, and with his fine linen
      shirt unfastened in front. &ldquo;Wait a bit, you fellows.... Here is Pétya!
      Good man!&rdquo; cried he, addressing Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      Another voice, from a man of medium height with clear blue eyes,
      particularly striking among all these drunken voices by its sober ring,
      cried from the window: &ldquo;Come here; part the bets!&rdquo; This was Dólokhov, an
      officer of the Semënov regiment, a notorious gambler and duelist, who was
      living with Anatole. Pierre smiled, looking about him merrily.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t understand. What&rsquo;s it all about?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wait a bit, he is not drunk yet! A bottle here,&rdquo; said Anatole,
      and taking a glass from the table he went up to Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;First of all you must drink!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre drank one glass after another, looking from under his brows at the
      tipsy guests who were again crowding round the window, and listening to
      their chatter. Anatole kept on refilling Pierre&rsquo;s glass while explaining
      that Dólokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval officer, that he
      would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge of the third floor
      window with his legs hanging out.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Go on, you must drink it all,&rdquo; said Anatole, giving Pierre the last
      glass, &ldquo;or I won&rsquo;t let you go!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, I won&rsquo;t,&rdquo; said Pierre, pushing Anatole aside, and he went up to the
      window.
    </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov was holding the Englishman&rsquo;s hand and clearly and distinctly
      repeating the terms of the bet, addressing himself particularly to Anatole
      and Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov was of medium height, with curly hair and light-blue eyes. He was
      about twenty-five. Like all infantry officers he wore no mustache, so that
      his mouth, the most striking feature of his face, was clearly seen. The
      lines of that mouth were remarkably finely curved. The middle of the upper
      lip formed a sharp wedge and closed firmly on the firm lower one, and
      something like two distinct smiles played continually round the two
      corners of the mouth; this, together with the resolute, insolent
      intelligence of his eyes, produced an effect which made it impossible not
      to notice his face. Dólokhov was a man of small means and no connections.
      Yet, though Anatole spent tens of thousands of rubles, Dólokhov lived with
      him and had placed himself on such a footing that all who knew them,
      including Anatole himself, respected him more than they did Anatole.
      Dólokhov could play all games and nearly always won. However much he
      drank, he never lost his clearheadedness. Both Kurágin and Dólokhov were
      at that time notorious among the rakes and scapegraces of Petersburg.
    </p>
    <p>
      The bottle of rum was brought. The window frame which prevented anyone
      from sitting on the outer sill was being forced out by two footmen, who
      were evidently flurried and intimidated by the directions and shouts of
      the gentlemen around.
    </p>
    <p>
      Anatole with his swaggering air strode up to the window. He wanted to
      smash something. Pushing away the footmen he tugged at the frame, but
      could not move it. He smashed a pane.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You have a try, Hercules,&rdquo; said he, turning to Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with a
      crash.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Take it right out, or they&rsquo;ll think I&rsquo;m holding on,&rdquo; said Dólokhov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Is the Englishman bragging?... Eh? Is it all right?&rdquo; said Anatole.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;First-rate,&rdquo; said Pierre, looking at Dólokhov, who with a bottle of rum
      in his hand was approaching the window, from which the light of the sky,
      the dawn merging with the afterglow of sunset, was visible.
    </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov, the bottle of rum still in his hand, jumped onto the window
      sill. &ldquo;Listen!&rdquo; cried he, standing there and addressing those in the room.
      All were silent.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I bet fifty imperials&rdquo;&mdash;he spoke French that the Englishman might
      understand him, but he did not speak it very well&mdash;&ldquo;I bet fifty
      imperials ... or do you wish to make it a hundred?&rdquo; added he, addressing
      the Englishman.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, fifty,&rdquo; replied the latter.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;All right. Fifty imperials ... that I will drink a whole bottle of rum
      without taking it from my mouth, sitting outside the window on this spot&rdquo;
       (he stooped and pointed to the sloping ledge outside the window) &ldquo;and
      without holding on to anything. Is that right?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Quite right,&rdquo; said the Englishman.
    </p>
    <p>
      Anatole turned to the Englishman and taking him by one of the buttons of
      his coat and looking down at him&mdash;the Englishman was short&mdash;began
      repeating the terms of the wager to him in English.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wait!&rdquo; cried Dólokhov, hammering with the bottle on the window sill to
      attract attention. &ldquo;Wait a bit, Kurágin. Listen! If anyone else does the
      same, I will pay him a hundred imperials. Do you understand?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The Englishman nodded, but gave no indication whether he intended to
      accept this challenge or not. Anatole did not release him, and though he
      kept nodding to show that he understood, Anatole went on translating
      Dólokhov&rsquo;s words into English. A thin young lad, an hussar of the Life
      Guards, who had been losing that evening, climbed on the window sill,
      leaned over, and looked down.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh! Oh! Oh!&rdquo; he muttered, looking down from the window at the stones of
      the pavement.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Shut up!&rdquo; cried Dólokhov, pushing him away from the window. The lad
      jumped awkwardly back into the room, tripping over his spurs.
    </p>
    <p>
      Placing the bottle on the window sill where he could reach it easily,
      Dólokhov climbed carefully and slowly through the window and lowered his
      legs. Pressing against both sides of the window, he adjusted himself on
      his seat, lowered his hands, moved a little to the right and then to the
      left, and took up the bottle. Anatole brought two candles and placed them
      on the window sill, though it was already quite light. Dólokhov&rsquo;s back in
      his white shirt, and his curly head, were lit up from both sides. Everyone
      crowded to the window, the Englishman in front. Pierre stood smiling but
      silent. One man, older than the others present, suddenly pushed forward
      with a scared and angry look and wanted to seize hold of Dólokhov&rsquo;s shirt.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I say, this is folly! He&rsquo;ll be killed,&rdquo; said this more sensible man.
    </p>
    <p>
      Anatole stopped him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t touch him! You&rsquo;ll startle him and then he&rsquo;ll be killed. Eh?... What
      then?... Eh?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov turned round and, again holding on with both hands, arranged
      himself on his seat.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If anyone comes meddling again,&rdquo; said he, emitting the words separately
      through his thin compressed lips, &ldquo;I will throw him down there. Now then!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Saying this he again turned round, dropped his hands, took the bottle and
      lifted it to his lips, threw back his head, and raised his free hand to
      balance himself. One of the footmen who had stooped to pick up some broken
      glass remained in that position without taking his eyes from the window
      and from Dólokhov&rsquo;s back. Anatole stood erect with staring eyes. The
      Englishman looked on sideways, pursing up his lips. The man who had wished
      to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room and threw himself on a sofa
      with his face to the wall. Pierre hid his face, from which a faint smile
      forgot to fade though his features now expressed horror and fear. All were
      still. Pierre took his hands from his eyes. Dólokhov still sat in the same
      position, only his head was thrown further back till his curly hair
      touched his shirt collar, and the hand holding the bottle was lifted
      higher and higher and trembled with the effort. The bottle was emptying
      perceptibly and rising still higher and his head tilting yet further back.
      &ldquo;Why is it so long?&rdquo; thought Pierre. It seemed to him that more than half
      an hour had elapsed. Suddenly Dólokhov made a backward movement with his
      spine, and his arm trembled nervously; this was sufficient to cause his
      whole body to slip as he sat on the sloping ledge. As he began slipping
      down, his head and arm wavered still more with the strain. One hand moved
      as if to clutch the window sill, but refrained from touching it. Pierre
      again covered his eyes and thought he would never open them again.
      Suddenly he was aware of a stir all around. He looked up: Dólokhov was
      standing on the window sill, with a pale but radiant face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s empty.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He threw the bottle to the Englishman, who caught it neatly. Dólokhov
      jumped down. He smelt strongly of rum.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well done!... Fine fellow!... There&rsquo;s a bet for you!... Devil take you!&rdquo;
       came from different sides.
    </p>
    <p>
      The Englishman took out his purse and began counting out the money.
      Dólokhov stood frowning and did not speak. Pierre jumped upon the window
      sill.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Gentlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I&rsquo;ll do the same thing!&rdquo; he
      suddenly cried. &ldquo;Even without a bet, there! Tell them to bring me a
      bottle. I&rsquo;ll do it.... Bring a bottle!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Let him do it, let him do it,&rdquo; said Dólokhov, smiling.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What next? Have you gone mad?... No one would let you!... Why, you go
      giddy even on a staircase,&rdquo; exclaimed several voices.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll drink it! Let&rsquo;s have a bottle of rum!&rdquo; shouted Pierre, banging the
      table with a determined and drunken gesture and preparing to climb out of
      the window.
    </p>
    <p>
      They seized him by his arms; but he was so strong that everyone who
      touched him was sent flying.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, you&rsquo;ll never manage him that way,&rdquo; said Anatole. &ldquo;Wait a bit and I&rsquo;ll
      get round him.... Listen! I&rsquo;ll take your bet tomorrow, but now we are all
      going to &mdash;&mdash;&rsquo;s.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come on then,&rdquo; cried Pierre. &ldquo;Come on!... And we&rsquo;ll take Bruin with us.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And he caught the bear, took it in his arms, lifted it from the ground,
      and began dancing round the room with it.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0010" id="link2HCH0010"></a>
      CHAPTER X
    </h2>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli kept the promise he had given to Princess Drubetskáya who
      had spoken to him on behalf of her only son Borís on the evening of Anna
      Pávlovna&rsquo;s soiree. The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an exception
      made, and Borís transferred into the regiment of Semënov Guards with the
      rank of cornet. He received, however, no appointment to Kutúzov&rsquo;s staff
      despite all Anna Mikháylovna&rsquo;s endeavors and entreaties. Soon after Anna
      Pávlovna&rsquo;s reception Anna Mikháylovna returned to Moscow and went straight
      to her rich relations, the Rostóvs, with whom she stayed when in the town
      and where her darling Bóry, who had only just entered a regiment of the
      line and was being at once transferred to the Guards as a cornet, had been
      educated from childhood and lived for years at a time. The Guards had
      already left Petersburg on the tenth of August, and her son, who had
      remained in Moscow for his equipment, was to join them on the march to
      Radzivílov.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was St. Natalia&rsquo;s day and the name day of two of the Rostóvs&mdash;the
      mother and the youngest daughter&mdash;both named Nataly. Ever since the
      morning, carriages with six horses had been coming and going continually,
      bringing visitors to the Countess Rostóva&rsquo;s big house on the Povarskáya,
      so well known to all Moscow. The countess herself and her handsome eldest
      daughter were in the drawing room with the visitors who came to
      congratulate, and who constantly succeeded one another in relays.
    </p>
    <p>
      The countess was a woman of about forty-five, with a thin Oriental type of
      face, evidently worn out with childbearing&mdash;she had had twelve. A
      languor of motion and speech, resulting from weakness, gave her a
      distinguished air which inspired respect. Princess Anna Mikháylovna
      Drubetskáya, who as a member of the household was also seated in the
      drawing room, helped to receive and entertain the visitors. The young
      people were in one of the inner rooms, not considering it necessary to
      take part in receiving the visitors. The count met the guests and saw them
      off, inviting them all to dinner.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am very, very grateful to you, <i>mon cher</i>,&rdquo; or <i>&ldquo;ma chère&rdquo;</i>&mdash;he
      called everyone without exception and without the slightest variation in
      his tone, &ldquo;my dear,&rdquo; whether they were above or below him in rank&mdash;&ldquo;I
      thank you for myself and for our two dear ones whose name day we are
      keeping. But mind you come to dinner or I shall be offended, <i>ma chère!</i>
      On behalf of the whole family I beg you to come, <i>mon cher!</i>&rdquo; These
      words he repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and with the
      same expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the same firm
      pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. As soon as he had
      seen a visitor off he returned to one of those who were still in the
      drawing room, drew a chair toward him or her, and jauntily spreading out
      his legs and putting his hands on his knees with the air of a man who
      enjoys life and knows how to live, he swayed to and fro with dignity,
      offered surmises about the weather, or touched on questions of health,
      sometimes in Russian and sometimes in very bad but self-confident French;
      then again, like a man weary but unflinching in the fulfillment of duty,
      he rose to see some visitors off and, stroking his scanty gray hairs over
      his bald patch, also asked them to dinner. Sometimes on his way back from
      the anteroom he would pass through the conservatory and pantry into the
      large marble dining hall, where tables were being set out for eighty
      people; and looking at the footmen, who were bringing in silver and china,
      moving tables, and unfolding damask table linen, he would call Dmítri
      Vasílevich, a man of good family and the manager of all his affairs, and
      while looking with pleasure at the enormous table would say: &ldquo;Well,
      Dmítri, you&rsquo;ll see that things are all as they should be? That&rsquo;s right!
      The great thing is the serving, that&rsquo;s it.&rdquo; And with a complacent sigh he
      would return to the drawing room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Márya Lvóvna Karágina and her daughter!&rdquo; announced the countess&rsquo; gigantic
      footman in his bass voice, entering the drawing room. The countess
      reflected a moment and took a pinch from a gold snuffbox with her
      husband&rsquo;s portrait on it.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;m quite worn out by these callers. However, I&rsquo;ll see her and no more.
      She is so affected. Ask her in,&rdquo; she said to the footman in a sad voice,
      as if saying: &ldquo;Very well, finish me off.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      A tall, stout, and proud-looking woman, with a round-faced smiling
      daughter, entered the drawing room, their dresses rustling.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Dear Countess, what an age... She has been laid up, poor child ... at the
      Razumóvski&rsquo;s ball ... and Countess Apráksina ... I was so delighted...&rdquo;
       came the sounds of animated feminine voices, interrupting one another and
      mingling with the rustling of dresses and the scraping of chairs. Then one
      of those conversations began which last out until, at the first pause, the
      guests rise with a rustle of dresses and say, &ldquo;I am so delighted...
      Mamma&rsquo;s health... and Countess Apráksina...&rdquo; and then, again rustling,
      pass into the anteroom, put on cloaks or mantles, and drive away. The
      conversation was on the chief topic of the day: the illness of the wealthy
      and celebrated beau of Catherine&rsquo;s day, Count Bezúkhov, and about his
      illegitimate son Pierre, the one who had behaved so improperly at Anna
      Pávlovna&rsquo;s reception.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am so sorry for the poor count,&rdquo; said the visitor. &ldquo;He is in such bad
      health, and now this vexation about his son is enough to kill him!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is that?&rdquo; asked the countess as if she did not know what the visitor
      alluded to, though she had already heard about the cause of Count
      Bezúkhov&rsquo;s distress some fifteen times.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s what comes of a modern education,&rdquo; exclaimed the visitor. &ldquo;It
      seems that while he was abroad this young man was allowed to do as he
      liked, now in Petersburg I hear he has been doing such terrible things
      that he has been expelled by the police.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You don&rsquo;t say so!&rdquo; replied the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He chose his friends badly,&rdquo; interposed Anna Mikháylovna. &ldquo;Prince
      Vasíli&rsquo;s son, he, and a certain Dólokhov have, it is said, been up to
      heaven only knows what! And they have had to suffer for it. Dólokhov has
      been degraded to the ranks and Bezúkhov&rsquo;s son sent back to Moscow. Anatole
      Kurágin&rsquo;s father managed somehow to get his son&rsquo;s affair hushed up, but
      even he was ordered out of Petersburg.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But what have they been up to?&rdquo; asked the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They are regular brigands, especially Dólokhov,&rdquo; replied the visitor. &ldquo;He
      is a son of Márya Ivánovna Dólokhova, such a worthy woman, but there, just
      fancy! Those three got hold of a bear somewhere, put it in a carriage, and
      set off with it to visit some actresses! The police tried to interfere,
      and what did the young men do? They tied a policeman and the bear back to
      back and put the bear into the Moyka Canal. And there was the bear
      swimming about with the policeman on his back!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a nice figure the policeman must have cut, my dear!&rdquo; shouted the
      count, dying with laughter.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, how dreadful! How can you laugh at it, Count?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Yet the ladies themselves could not help laughing.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It was all they could do to rescue the poor man,&rdquo; continued the visitor.
      &ldquo;And to think it is Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov&rsquo;s son who amuses himself
      in this sensible manner! And he was said to be so well educated and
      clever. This is all that his foreign education has done for him! I hope
      that here in Moscow no one will receive him, in spite of his money. They
      wanted to introduce him to me, but I quite declined: I have my daughters
      to consider.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why do you say this young man is so rich?&rdquo; asked the countess, turning
      away from the girls, who at once assumed an air of inattention. &ldquo;His
      children are all illegitimate. I think Pierre also is illegitimate.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The visitor made a gesture with her hand.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I should think he has a score of them.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Princess Anna Mikháylovna intervened in the conversation, evidently
      wishing to show her connections and knowledge of what went on in society.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The fact of the matter is,&rdquo; said she significantly, and also in a half
      whisper, &ldquo;everyone knows Count Cyril&rsquo;s reputation.... He has lost count of
      his children, but this Pierre was his favorite.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How handsome the old man still was only a year ago!&rdquo; remarked the
      countess. &ldquo;I have never seen a handsomer man.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He is very much altered now,&rdquo; said Anna Mikháylovna. &ldquo;Well, as I was
      saying, Prince Vasíli is the next heir through his wife, but the count is
      very fond of Pierre, looked after his education, and wrote to the Emperor
      about him; so that in the case of his death&mdash;and he is so ill that he
      may die at any moment, and Dr. Lorrain has come from Petersburg&mdash;no
      one knows who will inherit his immense fortune, Pierre or Prince Vasíli.
      Forty thousand serfs and millions of rubles! I know it all very well for
      Prince Vasíli told me himself. Besides, Cyril Vladímirovich is my mother&rsquo;s
      second cousin. He&rsquo;s also my Bóry&rsquo;s godfather,&rdquo; she added, as if she
      attached no importance at all to the fact.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Prince Vasíli arrived in Moscow yesterday. I hear he has come on some
      inspection business,&rdquo; remarked the visitor.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, but between ourselves,&rdquo; said the princess, &ldquo;that is a pretext. The
      fact is he has come to see Count Cyril Vladímirovich, hearing how ill he
      is.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But do you know, my dear, that was a capital joke,&rdquo; said the count; and
      seeing that the elder visitor was not listening, he turned to the young
      ladies. &ldquo;I can just imagine what a funny figure that policeman cut!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And as he waved his arms to impersonate the policeman, his portly form
      again shook with a deep ringing laugh, the laugh of one who always eats
      well and, in particular, drinks well. &ldquo;So do come and dine with us!&rdquo; he
      said.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0011" id="link2HCH0011"></a>
      CHAPTER XI
    </h2>
    <p>
      Silence ensued. The countess looked at her callers, smiling affably, but
      not concealing the fact that she would not be distressed if they now rose
      and took their leave. The visitor&rsquo;s daughter was already smoothing down
      her dress with an inquiring look at her mother, when suddenly from the
      next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls running to the door
      and the noise of a chair falling over, and a girl of thirteen, hiding
      something in the folds of her short muslin frock, darted in and stopped
      short in the middle of the room. It was evident that she had not intended
      her flight to bring her so far. Behind her in the doorway appeared a
      student with a crimson coat collar, an officer of the Guards, a girl of
      fifteen, and a plump rosy-faced boy in a short jacket.
    </p>
    <p>
      The count jumped up and, swaying from side to side, spread his arms wide
      and threw them round the little girl who had run in.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, here she is!&rdquo; he exclaimed laughing. &ldquo;My pet, whose name day it is.
      My dear pet!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;<i>Ma chère</i>, there is a time for everything,&rdquo; said the countess with
      feigned severity. &ldquo;You spoil her, Ilyá,&rdquo; she added, turning to her
      husband.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How do you do, my dear? I wish you many happy returns of your name day,&rdquo;
       said the visitor. &ldquo;What a charming child,&rdquo; she added, addressing the
      mother.
    </p>
    <p>
      This black-eyed, wide-mouthed girl, not pretty but full of life&mdash;with
      childish bare shoulders which after her run heaved and shook her bodice,
      with black curls tossed backward, thin bare arms, little legs in
      lace-frilled drawers, and feet in low slippers&mdash;was just at that
      charming age when a girl is no longer a child, though the child is not yet
      a young woman. Escaping from her father she ran to hide her flushed face
      in the lace of her mother&rsquo;s mantilla&mdash;not paying the least attention
      to her severe remark&mdash;and began to laugh. She laughed, and in
      fragmentary sentences tried to explain about a doll which she produced
      from the folds of her frock.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you see?... My doll... Mimi... You see...&rdquo; was all Natásha managed to
      utter (to her everything seemed funny). She leaned against her mother and
      burst into such a loud, ringing fit of laughter that even the prim visitor
      could not help joining in.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now then, go away and take your monstrosity with you,&rdquo; said the mother,
      pushing away her daughter with pretended sternness, and turning to the
      visitor she added: &ldquo;She is my youngest girl.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Natásha, raising her face for a moment from her mother&rsquo;s mantilla, glanced
      up at her through tears of laughter, and again hid her face.
    </p>
    <p>
      The visitor, compelled to look on at this family scene, thought it
      necessary to take some part in it.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Tell me, my dear,&rdquo; said she to Natásha, &ldquo;is Mimi a relation of yours? A
      daughter, I suppose?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Natásha did not like the visitor&rsquo;s tone of condescension to childish
      things. She did not reply, but looked at her seriously.
    </p>
    <p>
      Meanwhile the younger generation: Borís, the officer, Anna Mikháylovna&rsquo;s
      son; Nicholas, the undergraduate, the count&rsquo;s eldest son; Sónya, the
      count&rsquo;s fifteen-year-old niece, and little Pétya, his youngest boy, had
      all settled down in the drawing room and were obviously trying to restrain
      within the bounds of decorum the excitement and mirth that shone in all
      their faces. Evidently in the back rooms, from which they had dashed out
      so impetuously, the conversation had been more amusing than the drawing
      room talk of society scandals, the weather, and Countess Apráksina. Now
      and then they glanced at one another, hardly able to suppress their
      laughter.
    </p>
    <p>
      The two young men, the student and the officer, friends from childhood,
      were of the same age and both handsome fellows, though not alike. Borís
      was tall and fair, and his calm and handsome face had regular, delicate
      features. Nicholas was short with curly hair and an open expression. Dark
      hairs were already showing on his upper lip, and his whole face expressed
      impetuosity and enthusiasm. Nicholas blushed when he entered the drawing
      room. He evidently tried to find something to say, but failed. Borís on
      the contrary at once found his footing, and related quietly and humorously
      how he had known that doll Mimi when she was still quite a young lady,
      before her nose was broken; how she had aged during the five years he had
      known her, and how her head had cracked right across the skull. Having
      said this he glanced at Natásha. She turned away from him and glanced at
      her younger brother, who was screwing up his eyes and shaking with
      suppressed laughter, and unable to control herself any longer, she jumped
      up and rushed from the room as fast as her nimble little feet would carry
      her. Borís did not laugh.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You were meaning to go out, weren&rsquo;t you, Mamma? Do you want the
      carriage?&rdquo; he asked his mother with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, yes, go and tell them to get it ready,&rdquo; she answered, returning his
      smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís quietly left the room and went in search of Natásha. The plump boy
      ran after them angrily, as if vexed that their program had been disturbed.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0012" id="link2HCH0012"></a>
      CHAPTER XII
    </h2>
    <p>
      The only young people remaining in the drawing room, not counting the
      young lady visitor and the countess&rsquo; eldest daughter (who was four years
      older than her sister and behaved already like a grown-up person), were
      Nicholas and Sónya, the niece. Sónya was a slender little brunette with a
      tender look in her eyes which were veiled by long lashes, thick black
      plaits coiling twice round her head, and a tawny tint in her complexion
      and especially in the color of her slender but graceful and muscular arms
      and neck. By the grace of her movements, by the softness and flexibility
      of her small limbs, and by a certain coyness and reserve of manner, she
      reminded one of a pretty, half-grown kitten which promises to become a
      beautiful little cat. She evidently considered it proper to show an
      interest in the general conversation by smiling, but in spite of herself
      her eyes under their thick long lashes watched her cousin who was going to
      join the army, with such passionate girlish adoration that her smile could
      not for a single instant impose upon anyone, and it was clear that the
      kitten had settled down only to spring up with more energy and again play
      with her cousin as soon as they too could, like Natásha and Borís, escape
      from the drawing room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah yes, my dear,&rdquo; said the count, addressing the visitor and pointing to
      Nicholas, &ldquo;his friend Borís has become an officer, and so for friendship&rsquo;s
      sake he is leaving the university and me, his old father, and entering the
      military service, my dear. And there was a place and everything waiting
      for him in the Archives Department! Isn&rsquo;t that friendship?&rdquo; remarked the
      count in an inquiring tone.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But they say that war has been declared,&rdquo; replied the visitor.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They&rsquo;ve been saying so a long while,&rdquo; said the count, &ldquo;and they&rsquo;ll say so
      again and again, and that will be the end of it. My dear, there&rsquo;s
      friendship for you,&rdquo; he repeated. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s joining the hussars.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The visitor, not knowing what to say, shook her head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s not at all from friendship,&rdquo; declared Nicholas, flaring up and
      turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. &ldquo;It is not from friendship
      at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He glanced at his cousin and the young lady visitor; and they were both
      regarding him with a smile of approbation.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Schubert, the colonel of the Pávlograd Hussars, is dining with us today.
      He has been here on leave and is taking Nicholas back with him. It can&rsquo;t
      be helped!&rdquo; said the count, shrugging his shoulders and speaking playfully
      of a matter that evidently distressed him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have already told you, Papa,&rdquo; said his son, &ldquo;that if you don&rsquo;t wish to
      let me go, I&rsquo;ll stay. But I know I am no use anywhere except in the army;
      I am not a diplomat or a government clerk.&mdash;I don&rsquo;t know how to hide
      what I feel.&rdquo; As he spoke he kept glancing with the flirtatiousness of a
      handsome youth at Sónya and the young lady visitor.
    </p>
    <p>
      The little kitten, feasting her eyes on him, seemed ready at any moment to
      start her gambols again and display her kittenish nature.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;All right, all right!&rdquo; said the old count. &ldquo;He always flares up! This
      Buonaparte has turned all their heads; they all think of how he rose from
      an ensign and became Emperor. Well, well, God grant it,&rdquo; he added, not
      noticing his visitor&rsquo;s sarcastic smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      The elders began talking about Bonaparte. Julie Karágina turned to young
      Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a pity you weren&rsquo;t at the Arkhárovs&rsquo; on Thursday. It was so dull
      without you,&rdquo; said she, giving him a tender smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      The young man, flattered, sat down nearer to her with a coquettish smile,
      and engaged the smiling Julie in a confidential conversation without at
      all noticing that his involuntary smile had stabbed the heart of Sónya,
      who blushed and smiled unnaturally. In the midst of his talk he glanced
      round at her. She gave him a passionately angry glance, and hardly able to
      restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile on her lips, she got
      up and left the room. All Nicholas&rsquo; animation vanished. He waited for the
      first pause in the conversation, and then with a distressed face left the
      room to find Sónya.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How plainly all these young people wear their hearts on their sleeves!&rdquo;
       said Anna Mikháylovna, pointing to Nicholas as he went out. <i>&ldquo;Cousinage&mdash;dangereux
      voisinage,&rdquo;</i> * she added.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes,&rdquo; said the countess when the brightness these young people had
      brought into the room had vanished; and as if answering a question no one
      had put but which was always in her mind, &ldquo;and how much suffering, how
      much anxiety one has had to go through that we might rejoice in them now!
      And yet really the anxiety is greater now than the joy. One is always,
      always anxious! Especially just at this age, so dangerous both for girls
      and boys.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It all depends on the bringing up,&rdquo; remarked the visitor.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, you&rsquo;re quite right,&rdquo; continued the countess. &ldquo;Till now I have
      always, thank God, been my children&rsquo;s friend and had their full
      confidence,&rdquo; said she, repeating the mistake of so many parents who
      imagine that their children have no secrets from them. &ldquo;I know I shall
      always be my daughters&rsquo; first confidante, and that if Nicholas, with his
      impulsive nature, does get into mischief (a boy can&rsquo;t help it), he will
      all the same never be like those Petersburg young men.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, they are splendid, splendid youngsters,&rdquo; chimed in the count, who
      always solved questions that seemed to him perplexing by deciding that
      everything was splendid. &ldquo;Just fancy: wants to be an hussar. What&rsquo;s one to
      do, my dear?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a charming creature your younger girl is,&rdquo; said the visitor; &ldquo;a
      little volcano!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, a regular volcano,&rdquo; said the count. &ldquo;Takes after me! And what a
      voice she has; though she&rsquo;s my daughter, I tell the truth when I say
      she&rsquo;ll be a singer, a second Salomoni! We have engaged an Italian to give
      her lessons.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Isn&rsquo;t she too young? I have heard that it harms the voice to train it at
      that age.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh no, not at all too young!&rdquo; replied the count. &ldquo;Why, our mothers used
      to be married at twelve or thirteen.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And she&rsquo;s in love with Borís already. Just fancy!&rdquo; said the countess with
      a gentle smile, looking at Borís and went on, evidently concerned with a
      thought that always occupied her: &ldquo;Now you see if I were to be severe with
      her and to forbid it ... goodness knows what they might be up to on the
      sly&rdquo; (she meant that they would be kissing), &ldquo;but as it is, I know every
      word she utters. She will come running to me of her own accord in the
      evening and tell me everything. Perhaps I spoil her, but really that seems
      the best plan. With her elder sister I was stricter.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, I was brought up quite differently,&rdquo; remarked the handsome elder
      daughter, Countess Véra, with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      But the smile did not enhance Véra&rsquo;s beauty as smiles generally do; on the
      contrary it gave her an unnatural, and therefore unpleasant, expression.
      Véra was good-looking, not at all stupid, quick at learning, was
      well brought up, and had a pleasant voice; what she said was true and
      appropriate, yet, strange to say, everyone&mdash;the visitors and countess
      alike&mdash;turned to look at her as if wondering why she had said it, and
      they all felt awkward.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;People are always too clever with their eldest children and try to make
      something exceptional of them,&rdquo; said the visitor.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What&rsquo;s the good of denying it, my dear? Our dear countess was too clever
      with Véra,&rdquo; said the count. &ldquo;Well, what of that? She&rsquo;s turned out
      splendidly all the same,&rdquo; he added, winking at Véra.
    </p>
    <p>
      The guests got up and took their leave, promising to return to dinner.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What manners! I thought they would never go,&rdquo; said the countess, when she
      had seen her guests out.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0013" id="link2HCH0013"></a>
      CHAPTER XIII
    </h2>
    <p>
      When Natásha ran out of the drawing room she only went as far as the
      conservatory. There she paused and stood listening to the conversation in
      the drawing room, waiting for Borís to come out. She was already growing
      impatient, and stamped her foot, ready to cry at his not coming at once,
      when she heard the young man&rsquo;s discreet steps approaching neither quickly
      nor slowly. At this Natásha dashed swiftly among the flower tubs and hid
      there.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís paused in the middle of the room, looked round, brushed a little
      dust from the sleeve of his uniform, and going up to a mirror examined his
      handsome face. Natásha, very still, peered out from her ambush, waiting to
      see what he would do. He stood a little while before the glass, smiled,
      and walked toward the other door. Natásha was about to call him but
      changed her mind. &ldquo;Let him look for me,&rdquo; thought she. Hardly had Borís
      gone than Sónya, flushed, in tears, and muttering angrily, came in at the
      other door. Natásha checked her first impulse to run out to her, and
      remained in her hiding place, watching&mdash;as under an invisible cap&mdash;to
      see what went on in the world. She was experiencing a new and peculiar
      pleasure. Sónya, muttering to herself, kept looking round toward the
      drawing room door. It opened and Nicholas came in.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sónya, what is the matter with you? How can you?&rdquo; said he, running up to
      her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s nothing, nothing; leave me alone!&rdquo; sobbed Sónya.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, I know what it is.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, if you do, so much the better, and you can go back to her!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Só-o-onya! Look here! How can you torture me and yourself like that, for
      a mere fancy?&rdquo; said Nicholas taking her hand.
    </p>
    <p>
      Sónya did not pull it away, and left off crying. Natásha, not stirring and
      scarcely breathing, watched from her ambush with sparkling eyes. &ldquo;What
      will happen now?&rdquo; thought she.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sónya! What is anyone in the world to me? You alone are everything!&rdquo; said
      Nicholas. &ldquo;And I will prove it to you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t like you to talk like that.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, then, I won&rsquo;t; only forgive me, Sónya!&rdquo; He drew her to him and
      kissed her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, how nice,&rdquo; thought Natásha; and when Sónya and Nicholas had gone out
      of the conservatory she followed and called Borís to her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Borís, come here,&rdquo; said she with a sly and significant look. &ldquo;I have
      something to tell you. Here, here!&rdquo; and she led him into the conservatory
      to the place among the tubs where she had been hiding.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís followed her, smiling.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is the <i>something?</i>&rdquo; asked he.
    </p>
    <p>
      She grew confused, glanced round, and, seeing the doll she had thrown down
      on one of the tubs, picked it up.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Kiss the doll,&rdquo; said she.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís looked attentively and kindly at her eager face, but did not reply.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t you want to? Well, then, come here,&rdquo; said she, and went further in
      among the plants and threw down the doll. &ldquo;Closer, closer!&rdquo; she whispered.
    </p>
    <p>
      She caught the young officer by his cuffs, and a look of solemnity and
      fear appeared on her flushed face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And me? Would you like to kiss me?&rdquo; she whispered almost inaudibly,
      glancing up at him from under her brows, smiling, and almost crying from
      excitement.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís blushed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How funny you are!&rdquo; he said, bending down to her and blushing still more,
      but he waited and did nothing.
    </p>
    <p>
      Suddenly she jumped up onto a tub to be higher than he, embraced him so
      that both her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck, and, tossing
      back her hair, kissed him full on the lips.
    </p>
    <p>
      Then she slipped down among the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs
      and stood, hanging her head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Natásha,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;you know that I love you, but....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You are in love with me?&rdquo; Natásha broke in.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, I am, but please don&rsquo;t let us do like that.... In another four years
      ... then I will ask for your hand.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Natásha considered.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen,&rdquo; she counted on her slender little
      fingers. &ldquo;All right! Then it&rsquo;s settled?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      A smile of joy and satisfaction lit up her eager face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Settled!&rdquo; replied Borís.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Forever?&rdquo; said the little girl. &ldquo;Till death itself?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She took his arm and with a happy face went with him into the adjoining
      sitting room.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0014" id="link2HCH0014"></a>
      CHAPTER XIV
    </h2>
    <p>
      After receiving her visitors, the countess was so tired that she gave
      orders to admit no more, but the porter was told to be sure to invite to
      dinner all who came &ldquo;to congratulate.&rdquo; The countess wished to have a
      tête-à-tête talk with the friend of her childhood, Princess Anna
      Mikháylovna, whom she had not seen properly since she returned from
      Petersburg. Anna Mikháylovna, with her tear-worn but pleasant face, drew
      her chair nearer to that of the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;With you I will be quite frank,&rdquo; said Anna Mikháylovna. &ldquo;There are not
      many left of us old friends! That&rsquo;s why I so value your friendship.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Anna Mikháylovna looked at Véra and paused. The countess pressed her
      friend&rsquo;s hand.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Véra,&rdquo; she said to her eldest daughter who was evidently not a favorite,
      &ldquo;how is it you have so little tact? Don&rsquo;t you see you are not wanted here?
      Go to the other girls, or...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The handsome Véra smiled contemptuously but did not seem at all hurt.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have gone,&rdquo; she replied as she
      rose to go to her own room.
    </p>
    <p>
      But as she passed the sitting room she noticed two couples sitting, one
      pair at each window. She stopped and smiled scornfully. Sónya was sitting
      close to Nicholas who was copying out some verses for her, the first he
      had ever written. Borís and Natásha were at the other window and ceased
      talking when Véra entered. Sónya and Natásha looked at Véra with guilty,
      happy faces.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was pleasant and touching to see these little girls in love; but
      apparently the sight of them roused no pleasant feeling in Véra.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How often have I asked you not to take my things?&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;You have a
      room of your own,&rdquo; and she took the inkstand from Nicholas.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;In a minute, in a minute,&rdquo; he said, dipping his pen.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You always manage to do things at the wrong time,&rdquo; continued Véra. &ldquo;You
      came rushing into the drawing room so that everyone felt ashamed of you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Though what she said was quite just, perhaps for that very reason no one
      replied, and the four simply looked at one another. She lingered in the
      room with the inkstand in her hand.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And at your age what secrets can there be between Natásha and Borís, or
      between you two? It&rsquo;s all nonsense!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now, Véra, what does it matter to you?&rdquo; said Natásha in defense, speaking
      very gently.
    </p>
    <p>
      She seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to
      everyone.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Very silly,&rdquo; said Véra. &ldquo;I am ashamed of you. Secrets indeed!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;All have secrets of their own,&rdquo; answered Natásha, getting warmer. &ldquo;We
      don&rsquo;t interfere with you and Berg.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I should think not,&rdquo; said Véra, &ldquo;because there can never be anything
      wrong in my behavior. But I&rsquo;ll just tell Mamma how you are behaving with
      Borís.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Natálya Ilyníchna behaves very well to me,&rdquo; remarked Borís. &ldquo;I have
      nothing to complain of.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t, Borís! You are such a diplomat that it is really tiresome,&rdquo; said
      Natásha in a mortified voice that trembled slightly. (She used the word
      &ldquo;diplomat,&rdquo; which was just then much in vogue among the children, in the
      special sense they attached to it.) &ldquo;Why does she bother me?&rdquo; And she
      added, turning to Véra, &ldquo;You&rsquo;ll never understand it, because you&rsquo;ve never
      loved anyone. You have no heart! You are a Madame de Genlis and nothing
      more&rdquo; (this nickname, bestowed on Véra by Nicholas, was considered very
      stinging), &ldquo;and your greatest pleasure is to be unpleasant to people! Go
      and flirt with Berg as much as you please,&rdquo; she finished quickly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I shall at any rate not run after a young man before visitors...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, now you&rsquo;ve done what you wanted,&rdquo; put in Nicholas&mdash;&ldquo;said
      unpleasant things to everyone and upset them. Let&rsquo;s go to the nursery.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      All four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The unpleasant things were said to me,&rdquo; remarked Véra, &ldquo;I said none to
      anyone.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Madame de Genlis! Madame de Genlis!&rdquo; shouted laughing voices through the
      door.
    </p>
    <p>
      The handsome Véra, who produced such an irritating and unpleasant effect
      on everyone, smiled and, evidently unmoved by what had been said to her,
      went to the looking glass and arranged her hair and scarf. Looking at her
      own handsome face she seemed to become still colder and calmer.
    </p>
    <p>
      <br />
    </p>
    <p>
      In the drawing room the conversation was still going on.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my dear,&rdquo; said the countess, &ldquo;my life is not all roses either. Don&rsquo;t
      I know that at the rate we are living our means won&rsquo;t last long? It&rsquo;s all
      the Club and his easygoing nature. Even in the country do we get any rest?
      Theatricals, hunting, and heaven knows what besides! But don&rsquo;t let&rsquo;s talk
      about me; tell me how you managed everything. I often wonder at you,
      Annette&mdash;how at your age you can rush off alone in a carriage to
      Moscow, to Petersburg, to those ministers and great people, and know how
      to deal with them all! It&rsquo;s quite astonishing. How did you get things
      settled? I couldn&rsquo;t possibly do it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my love,&rdquo; answered Anna Mikháylovna, &ldquo;God grant you never know what
      it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love to
      distraction! One learns many things then,&rdquo; she added with a certain pride.
      &ldquo;That lawsuit taught me much. When I want to see one of those big people I
      write a note: &lsquo;Princess So-and-So desires an interview with So and-So,&rsquo;
      and then I take a cab and go myself two, three, or four times&mdash;till I
      get what I want. I don&rsquo;t mind what they think of me.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, and to whom did you apply about Bóry?&rdquo; asked the countess. &ldquo;You see
      yours is already an officer in the Guards, while my Nicholas is going as a
      cadet. There&rsquo;s no one to interest himself for him. To whom did you apply?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;To Prince Vasíli. He was so kind. He at once agreed to everything, and
      put the matter before the Emperor,&rdquo; said Princess Anna Mikháylovna
      enthusiastically, quite forgetting all the humiliation she had endured to
      gain her end.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Has Prince Vasíli aged much?&rdquo; asked the countess. &ldquo;I have not seen him
      since we acted together at the Rumyántsovs&rsquo; theatricals. I expect he has
      forgotten me. He paid me attentions in those days,&rdquo; said the countess,
      with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He is just the same as ever,&rdquo; replied Anna Mikháylovna, &ldquo;overflowing with
      amiability. His position has not turned his head at all. He said to me, &lsquo;I
      am sorry I can do so little for you, dear Princess. I am at your command.&rsquo;
      Yes, he is a fine fellow and a very kind relation. But, Nataly, you know
      my love for my son: I would do anything for his happiness! And my affairs
      are in such a bad way that my position is now a terrible one,&rdquo; continued
      Anna Mikháylovna, sadly, dropping her voice. &ldquo;My wretched lawsuit takes
      all I have and makes no progress. Would you believe it, I have literally
      not a penny and don&rsquo;t know how to equip Borís.&rdquo; She took out her
      handkerchief and began to cry. &ldquo;I need five hundred rubles, and have only
      one twenty-five-ruble note. I am in such a state.... My only hope now is
      in Count Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov. If he will not assist his godson&mdash;you
      know he is Bóry&rsquo;s godfather&mdash;and allow him something for his
      maintenance, all my trouble will have been thrown away.... I shall not be
      able to equip him.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The countess&rsquo; eyes filled with tears and she pondered in silence.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I often think, though, perhaps it&rsquo;s a sin,&rdquo; said the princess, &ldquo;that here
      lives Count Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov so rich, all alone... that
      tremendous fortune... and what is his life worth? It&rsquo;s a burden to him,
      and Bóry&rsquo;s life is only just beginning....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Surely he will leave something to Borís,&rdquo; said the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Heaven only knows, my dear! These rich grandees are so selfish. Still, I
      will take Borís and go to see him at once, and I shall speak to him
      straight out. Let people think what they will of me, it&rsquo;s really all the
      same to me when my son&rsquo;s fate is at stake.&rdquo; The princess rose. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s now
      two o&rsquo;clock and you dine at four. There will just be time.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And like a practical Petersburg lady who knows how to make the most of
      time, Anna Mikháylovna sent someone to call her son, and went into the
      anteroom with him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Good-by, my dear,&rdquo; said she to the countess who saw her to the door, and
      added in a whisper so that her son should not hear, &ldquo;Wish me good luck.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Are you going to Count Cyril Vladímirovich, my dear?&rdquo; said the count
      coming out from the dining hall into the anteroom, and he added: &ldquo;If he is
      better, ask Pierre to dine with us. He has been to the house, you know,
      and danced with the children. Be sure to invite him, my dear. We will see
      how Tarás distinguishes himself today. He says Count Orlóv never gave such
      a dinner as ours will be!&rdquo;
     </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0015" id="link2HCH0015"></a>
      CHAPTER XV
    </h2>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My dear Borís,&rdquo; said Princess Anna Mikháylovna to her son as Countess
      Rostóva&rsquo;s carriage in which they were seated drove over the straw covered
      street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril Vladímirovich
      Bezúkhov&rsquo;s house. &ldquo;My dear Borís,&rdquo; said the mother, drawing her hand from
      beneath her old mantle and laying it timidly and tenderly on her son&rsquo;s
      arm, &ldquo;be affectionate and attentive to him. Count Cyril Vladímirovich is
      your godfather after all, and your future depends on him. Remember that, my
      dear, and be nice to him, as you so well know how to be.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If only I knew that anything besides humiliation would come of it...&rdquo;
       answered her son coldly. &ldquo;But I have promised and will do it for your
      sake.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Although the hall porter saw someone&rsquo;s carriage standing at the entrance,
      after scrutinizing the mother and son (who without asking to be announced
      had passed straight through the glass porch between the rows of statues in
      niches) and looking significantly at the lady&rsquo;s old cloak, he asked
      whether they wanted the count or the princesses, and, hearing that they
      wished to see the count, said his excellency was worse today, and that his
      excellency was not receiving anyone.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We may as well go back,&rdquo; said the son in French.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My dear!&rdquo; exclaimed his mother imploringly, again laying her hand on his
      arm as if that touch might soothe or rouse him.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís said no more, but looked inquiringly at his mother without taking
      off his cloak.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My friend,&rdquo; said Anna Mikháylovna in gentle tones, addressing the hall
      porter, &ldquo;I know Count Cyril Vladímirovich is very ill... that&rsquo;s why I have
      come... I am a relation. I shall not disturb him, my friend... I only need
      see Prince Vasíli Sergéevich: he is staying here, is he not? Please
      announce me.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The hall porter sullenly pulled a bell that rang upstairs, and turned
      away.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Princess Drubetskáya to see Prince Vasíli Sergéevich,&rdquo; he called to a
      footman dressed in knee breeches, shoes, and a swallow-tail coat, who ran
      downstairs and looked over from the halfway landing.
    </p>
    <p>
      The mother smoothed the folds of her dyed silk dress before a large
      Venetian mirror in the wall, and in her trodden-down shoes briskly
      ascended the carpeted stairs.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My dear,&rdquo; she said to her son, once more stimulating him by a touch, &ldquo;you
      promised me!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The son, lowering his eyes, followed her quietly.
    </p>
    <p>
      They entered the large hall, from which one of the doors led to the
      apartments assigned to Prince Vasíli.
    </p>
    <p>
      Just as the mother and son, having reached the middle of the hall, were
      about to ask their way of an elderly footman who had sprung up as they
      entered, the bronze handle of one of the doors turned and Prince Vasíli
      came out&mdash;wearing a velvet coat with a single star on his breast, as
      was his custom when at home&mdash;taking leave of a good-looking,
      dark-haired man. This was the celebrated Petersburg doctor, Lorrain.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Then it is certain?&rdquo; said the prince.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Prince, <i>humanum est errare</i>, * but...&rdquo; replied the doctor,
      swallowing his <i>r</i>&rsquo;s, and pronouncing the Latin words with a French
      accent.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * To err is human.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Very well, very well...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Seeing Anna Mikháylovna and her son, Prince Vasíli dismissed the doctor
      with a bow and approached them silently and with a look of inquiry. The
      son noticed that an expression of profound sorrow suddenly clouded his
      mother&rsquo;s face, and he smiled slightly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, Prince! In what sad circumstances we meet again! And how is our dear
      invalid?&rdquo; said she, as though unaware of the cold offensive look fixed on
      her.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli stared at her and at Borís questioningly and perplexed.
      Borís bowed politely. Prince Vasíli without acknowledging the bow turned
      to Anna Mikháylovna, answering her query by a movement of the head and
      lips indicating very little hope for the patient.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Is it possible?&rdquo; exclaimed Anna Mikháylovna. &ldquo;Oh, how awful! It is
      terrible to think.... This is my son,&rdquo; she added, indicating Borís. &ldquo;He
      wanted to thank you himself.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Borís bowed again politely.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Believe me, Prince, a mother&rsquo;s heart will never forget what you have done
      for us.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am glad I was able to do you a service, my dear Anna Mikháylovna,&rdquo; said
      Prince Vasíli, arranging his lace frill, and in tone and manner, here in
      Moscow to Anna Mikháylovna whom he had placed under an obligation,
      assuming an air of much greater importance than he had done in Petersburg
      at Anna Schérer&rsquo;s reception.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Try to serve well and show yourself worthy,&rdquo; added he, addressing Borís
      with severity. &ldquo;I am glad.... Are you here on leave?&rdquo; he went on in his
      usual tone of indifference.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am awaiting orders to join my new regiment, your excellency,&rdquo; replied
      Borís, betraying neither annoyance at the prince&rsquo;s brusque manner nor a
      desire to enter into conversation, but speaking so quietly and
      respectfully that the prince gave him a searching glance.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Are you living with your mother?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am living at Countess Rostóva&rsquo;s,&rdquo; replied Borís, again adding, &ldquo;your
      excellency.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That is, with Ilyá Rostóv who married Nataly Shinshiná,&rdquo; said Anna
      Mikháylovna.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know, I know,&rdquo; answered Prince Vasíli in his monotonous voice. &ldquo;I never
      could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that unlicked bear!
      A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too, I am told.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But a very kind man, Prince,&rdquo; said Anna Mikháylovna with a pathetic
      smile, as though she too knew that Count Rostóv deserved this censure, but
      asked him not to be too hard on the poor old man. &ldquo;What do the doctors
      say?&rdquo; asked the princess after a pause, her worn face again expressing
      deep sorrow.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They give little hope,&rdquo; replied the prince.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And I should so like to thank <i>Uncle</i> once for all his kindness to
      me and Borís. He is his godson,&rdquo; she added, her tone suggesting that this
      fact ought to give Prince Vasíli much satisfaction.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli became thoughtful and frowned. Anna Mikháylovna saw that he
      was afraid of finding in her a rival for Count Bezúkhov&rsquo;s fortune, and
      hastened to reassure him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to <i>Uncle</i>,&rdquo;
       said she, uttering the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, &ldquo;I know
      his character: noble, upright ... but you see he has no one with him
      except the young princesses.... They are still young....&rdquo; She bent her
      head and continued in a whisper: &ldquo;Has he performed his final duty, Prince?
      How priceless are those last moments! It can make things no worse, and it
      is absolutely necessary to prepare him if he is so ill. We women, Prince,&rdquo;
       and she smiled tenderly, &ldquo;always know how to say these things. I
      absolutely must see him, however painful it may be for me. I am used to
      suffering.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Evidently the prince understood her, and also understood, as he had done
      at Anna Pávlovna&rsquo;s, that it would be difficult to get rid of Anna
      Mikháylovna.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Would not such a meeting be too trying for him, dear Anna Mikháylovna?&rdquo;
       said he. &ldquo;Let us wait until evening. The doctors are expecting a crisis.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But one cannot delay, Prince, at such a moment! Consider that the welfare
      of his soul is at stake. Ah, it is awful: the duties of a Christian...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      A door of one of the inner rooms opened and one of the princesses, the
      count&rsquo;s niece, entered with a cold, stern face. The length of her body was
      strikingly out of proportion to her short legs. Prince Vasíli turned to
      her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, how is he?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Still the same; but what can you expect, this noise...&rdquo; said the
      princess, looking at Anna Mikháylovna as at a stranger.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my dear, I hardly knew you,&rdquo; said Anna Mikháylovna with a happy
      smile, ambling lightly up to the count&rsquo;s niece. &ldquo;I have come, and am at
      your service to help you nurse <i>my uncle</i>. I imagine what you have
      gone through,&rdquo; and she sympathetically turned up her eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      The princess gave no reply and did not even smile, but left the room as
      Anna Mikháylovna took off her gloves and, occupying the position she had
      conquered, settled down in an armchair, inviting Prince Vasíli to take a
      seat beside her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Borís,&rdquo; she said to her son with a smile, &ldquo;I shall go in to see the
      count, my uncle; but you, my dear, had better go to Pierre meanwhile and
      don&rsquo;t forget to give him the Rostóvs&rsquo; invitation. They ask him to dinner.
      I suppose he won&rsquo;t go?&rdquo; she continued, turning to the prince.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;On the contrary,&rdquo; replied the prince, who had plainly become depressed,
      &ldquo;I shall be only too glad if you relieve me of that young man.... Here he
      is, and the count has not once asked for him.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He shrugged his shoulders. A footman conducted Borís down one flight of
      stairs and up another, to Pierre&rsquo;s rooms.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0016" id="link2HCH0016"></a>
      CHAPTER XVI
    </h2>
    <p>
      Pierre, after all, had not managed to choose a career for himself in
      Petersburg, and had been expelled from there for riotous conduct and sent
      to Moscow. The story told about him at Count Rostóv&rsquo;s was true. Pierre had
      taken part in tying a policeman to a bear. He had now been for some days
      in Moscow and was staying as usual at his father&rsquo;s house. Though he
      expected that the story of his escapade would be already known in Moscow
      and that the ladies about his father&mdash;who were never favorably
      disposed toward him&mdash;would have used it to turn the count against
      him, he nevertheless on the day of his arrival went to his father&rsquo;s part
      of the house. Entering the drawing room, where the princesses spent most
      of their time, he greeted the ladies, two of whom were sitting at
      embroidery frames while a third read aloud. It was the eldest who was
      reading&mdash;the one who had met Anna Mikháylovna. The two younger ones
      were embroidering: both were rosy and pretty and they differed only in
      that one had a little mole on her lip which made her much prettier. Pierre
      was received as if he were a corpse or a leper. The eldest princess paused
      in her reading and silently stared at him with frightened eyes; the second
      assumed precisely the same expression; while the youngest, the one with
      the mole, who was of a cheerful and lively disposition, bent over her
      frame to hide a smile probably evoked by the amusing scene she foresaw.
      She drew her wool down through the canvas and, scarcely able to refrain
      from laughing, stooped as if trying to make out the pattern.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How do you do, cousin?&rdquo; said Pierre. &ldquo;You don&rsquo;t recognize me?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I recognize you only too well, too well.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How is the count? Can I see him?&rdquo; asked Pierre, awkwardly as usual, but
      unabashed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The count is suffering physically and mentally, and apparently you have
      done your best to increase his mental sufferings.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Can I see the count?&rdquo; Pierre again asked.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Hm.... If you wish to kill him, to kill him outright, you can see him...
      Olga, go and see whether Uncle&rsquo;s beef tea is ready&mdash;it is almost
      time,&rdquo; she added, giving Pierre to understand that they were busy, and
      busy making his father comfortable, while evidently he, Pierre, was only
      busy causing him annoyance.
    </p>
    <p>
      Olga went out. Pierre stood looking at the sisters; then he bowed and
      said: &ldquo;Then I will go to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see
      him.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And he left the room, followed by the low but ringing laughter of the
      sister with the mole.
    </p>
    <p>
      Next day Prince Vasíli had arrived and settled in the count&rsquo;s house. He
      sent for Pierre and said to him: &ldquo;My dear fellow, if you are going to
      behave here as you did in Petersburg, you will end very badly; that is all
      I have to say to you. The count is very, very ill, and you must not see
      him at all.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Since then Pierre had not been disturbed and had spent the whole time in
      his rooms upstairs.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Borís appeared at his door Pierre was pacing up and down his room,
      stopping occasionally at a corner to make menacing gestures at the wall,
      as if running a sword through an invisible foe, and glaring savagely over
      his spectacles, and then again resuming his walk, muttering indistinct
      words, shrugging his shoulders and gesticulating.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;England is done for,&rdquo; said he, scowling and pointing his finger at
      someone unseen. &ldquo;Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the rights of
      man, is sentenced to...&rdquo; But before Pierre&mdash;who at that moment
      imagined himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just effected the
      dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured London&mdash;could
      pronounce Pitt&rsquo;s sentence, he saw a well-built and handsome young officer
      entering his room. Pierre paused. He had left Moscow when Borís was a boy
      of fourteen, and had quite forgotten him, but in his usual impulsive and
      hearty way he took Borís by the hand with a friendly smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you remember me?&rdquo; asked Borís quietly with a pleasant smile. &ldquo;I have
      come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not well.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbing him,&rdquo; answered
      Pierre, trying to remember who this young man was.
    </p>
    <p>
      Borís felt that Pierre did not recognize him but did not consider it
      necessary to introduce himself, and without experiencing the least
      embarrassment looked Pierre straight in the face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Count Rostóv asks you to come to dinner today,&rdquo; said he, after a
      considerable pause which made Pierre feel uncomfortable.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, Count Rostóv!&rdquo; exclaimed Pierre joyfully. &ldquo;Then you are his son,
      Ilyá? Only fancy, I didn&rsquo;t know you at first. Do you remember how we went
      to the Sparrow Hills with Madame Jacquot?... It&rsquo;s such an age...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
