      &ldquo;You are mistaken,&rdquo; said Borís deliberately, with a bold and slightly
      sarcastic smile. &ldquo;I am Borís, son of Princess Anna Mikháylovna
      Drubetskáya. Rostóv, the father, is Ilyá, and his son is Nicholas. I never
      knew any Madame Jacquot.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre shook his head and arms as if attacked by mosquitoes or bees.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh dear, what am I thinking about? I&rsquo;ve mixed everything up. One has so
      many relatives in Moscow! So you are Borís? Of course. Well, now we know
      where we are. And what do you think of the Boulogne expedition? The
      English will come off badly, you know, if Napoleon gets across the
      Channel. I think the expedition is quite feasible. If only Villeneuve
      doesn&rsquo;t make a mess of things!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Borís knew nothing about the Boulogne expedition; he did not read the
      papers and it was the first time he had heard Villeneuve&rsquo;s name.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We here in Moscow are more occupied with dinner parties and scandal than
      with politics,&rdquo; said he in his quiet ironical tone. &ldquo;I know nothing about
      it and have not thought about it. Moscow is chiefly busy with gossip,&rdquo; he
      continued. &ldquo;Just now they are talking about you and your father.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre smiled in his good-natured way as if afraid for his companion&rsquo;s
      sake that the latter might say something he would afterwards regret. But
      Borís spoke distinctly, clearly, and dryly, looking straight into Pierre&rsquo;s
      eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Moscow has nothing else to do but gossip,&rdquo; Borís went on. &ldquo;Everybody is
      wondering to whom the count will leave his fortune, though he may perhaps
      outlive us all, as I sincerely hope he will...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, it is all very horrid,&rdquo; interrupted Pierre, &ldquo;very horrid.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre was still afraid that this officer might inadvertently say
      something disconcerting to himself.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And it must seem to you,&rdquo; said Borís flushing slightly, but not changing
      his tone or attitude, &ldquo;it must seem to you that everyone is trying to get
      something out of the rich man?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;So it does,&rdquo; thought Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But I just wish to say, to avoid misunderstandings, that you are quite
      mistaken if you reckon me or my mother among such people. We are very
      poor, but for my own part at any rate, for the very reason that your
      father is rich, I don&rsquo;t regard myself as a relation of his, and neither I
      nor my mother would ever ask or take anything from him.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      For a long time Pierre could not understand, but when he did, he jumped up
      from the sofa, seized Borís under the elbow in his quick, clumsy way, and,
      blushing far more than Borís, began to speak with a feeling of mingled
      shame and vexation.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, this is strange! Do you suppose I... who could think?... I know
      very well...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      But Borís again interrupted him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am glad I have spoken out fully. Perhaps you did not like it? You must
      excuse me,&rdquo; said he, putting Pierre at ease instead of being put at ease
      by him, &ldquo;but I hope I have not offended you. I always make it a rule to
      speak out... Well, what answer am I to take? Will you come to dinner at
      the Rostóvs&rsquo;?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And Borís, having apparently relieved himself of an onerous duty and
      extricated himself from an awkward situation and placed another in it,
      became quite pleasant again.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, but I say,&rdquo; said Pierre, calming down, &ldquo;you are a wonderful fellow!
      What you have just said is good, very good. Of course you don&rsquo;t know me.
      We have not met for such a long time... not since we were children. You
      might think that I... I understand, quite understand. I could not have
      done it myself, I should not have had the courage, but it&rsquo;s splendid. I am
      very glad to have made your acquaintance. It&rsquo;s queer,&rdquo; he added after a
      pause, &ldquo;that you should have suspected me!&rdquo; He began to laugh. &ldquo;Well, what
      of it! I hope we&rsquo;ll get better acquainted,&rdquo; and he pressed Borís&rsquo; hand.
      &ldquo;Do you know, I have not once been in to see the count. He has not sent
      for me.... I am sorry for him as a man, but what can one do?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And so you think Napoleon will manage to get an army across?&rdquo; asked Borís
      with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre saw that Borís wished to change the subject, and being of the same
      mind he began explaining the advantages and disadvantages of the Boulogne
      expedition.
    </p>
    <p>
      A footman came in to summon Borís&mdash;the princess was going. Pierre, in
      order to make Borís&rsquo; better acquaintance, promised to come to dinner, and
      warmly pressing his hand looked affectionately over his spectacles into
      Borís&rsquo; eyes. After he had gone Pierre continued pacing up and down the
      room for a long time, no longer piercing an imaginary foe with his
      imaginary sword, but smiling at the remembrance of that pleasant,
      intelligent, and resolute young man.
    </p>
    <p>
      As often happens in early youth, especially to one who leads a lonely
      life, he felt an unaccountable tenderness for this young man and made up
      his mind that they would be friends.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli saw the princess off. She held a handkerchief to her eyes
      and her face was tearful.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It is dreadful, dreadful!&rdquo; she was saying, &ldquo;but cost me what it may I
      shall do my duty. I will come and spend the night. He must not be left
      like this. Every moment is precious. I can&rsquo;t think why his nieces put it
      off. Perhaps God will help me to find a way to prepare him!... Adieu,
      Prince! May God support you...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Adieu, ma bonne,&rdquo;</i> answered Prince Vasíli turning away from her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, he is in a dreadful state,&rdquo; said the mother to her son when they were
      in the carriage. &ldquo;He hardly recognizes anybody.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t understand, Mamma&mdash;what is his attitude to Pierre?&rdquo; asked
      the son.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The will will show that, my dear; our fate also depends on it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But why do you expect that he will leave us anything?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my dear! He is so rich, and we are so poor!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, that is hardly a sufficient reason, Mamma...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, Heaven! How ill he is!&rdquo; exclaimed the mother.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0017" id="link2HCH0017"></a>
      CHAPTER XVII
    </h2>
    <p>
      After Anna Mikháylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril
      Vladímirovich Bezúkhov, Countess Rostóva sat for a long time all alone
      applying her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she rang.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is the matter with you, my dear?&rdquo; she said crossly to the maid who
      kept her waiting some minutes. &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t you wish to serve me? Then I&rsquo;ll find
      you another place.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The countess was upset by her friend&rsquo;s sorrow and humiliating poverty, and
      was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always found
      expression in calling her maid &ldquo;my dear&rdquo; and speaking to her with
      exaggerated politeness.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am very sorry, ma&rsquo;am,&rdquo; answered the maid.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ask the count to come to me.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The count came waddling in to see his wife with a rather guilty look as
      usual.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, little countess? What a <i>sauté</i> of game <i>au madère</i> we
      are to have, my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Tarás
      were not ill-spent. He is worth it!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands ruffling
      his gray hair.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What are your commands, little countess?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You see, my dear... What&rsquo;s that mess?&rdquo; she said, pointing to his
      waistcoat. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s the <i>sauté</i>, most likely,&rdquo; she added with a smile.
      &ldquo;Well, you see, Count, I want some money.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Her face became sad.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, little countess!&rdquo; ... and the count began bustling to get out his
      pocketbook.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I want a great deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles,&rdquo; and taking out
      her cambric handkerchief she began wiping her husband&rsquo;s waistcoat.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, immediately, immediately! Hey, who&rsquo;s there?&rdquo; he called out in a tone
      only used by persons who are certain that those they call will rush to
      obey the summons. &ldquo;Send Dmítri to me!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Dmítri, a man of good family who had been brought up in the count&rsquo;s house
      and now managed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;This is what I want, my dear fellow,&rdquo; said the count to the deferential
      young man who had entered. &ldquo;Bring me...&rdquo; he reflected a moment, &ldquo;yes,
      bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don&rsquo;t bring me such tattered
      and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones for the countess.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, Dmítri, clean ones, please,&rdquo; said the countess, sighing deeply.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;When would you like them, your excellency?&rdquo; asked Dmítri. &ldquo;Allow me to
      inform you... But, don&rsquo;t be uneasy,&rdquo; he added, noticing that the count was
      beginning to breathe heavily and quickly which was always a sign of
      approaching anger. &ldquo;I was forgetting... Do you wish it brought at once?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a treasure that Dmítri is,&rdquo; added the count with a smile when the
      young man had departed. &ldquo;There is never any &lsquo;impossible&rsquo; with him. That&rsquo;s
      a thing I hate! Everything is possible.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world,&rdquo; said
      the countess. &ldquo;But I am in great need of this sum.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift,&rdquo; said the count,
      and having kissed his wife&rsquo;s hand he went back to his study.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Anna Mikháylovna returned from Count Bezúkhov&rsquo;s the money, all in
      clean notes, was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess&rsquo; little
      table, and Anna Mikháylovna noticed that something was agitating her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, my dear?&rdquo; asked the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so ill!
      I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Annette, for heaven&rsquo;s sake don&rsquo;t refuse me,&rdquo; the countess began, with a
      blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified, elderly face, and
      she took the money from under the handkerchief.
    </p>
    <p>
      Anna Mikháylovna instantly guessed her intention and stooped to be ready
      to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Anna Mikháylovna was already embracing her and weeping. The countess wept
      too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were
      kindhearted, and because they&mdash;friends from childhood&mdash;had to
      think about such a base thing as money, and because their youth was
      over.... But those tears were pleasant to them both.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0018" id="link2HCH0018"></a>
      CHAPTER XVIII
    </h2>
    <p>
      Countess Rostóva, with her daughters and a large number of guests, was
      already seated in the drawing room. The count took the gentlemen into his
      study and showed them his choice collection of Turkish pipes. From time to
      time he went out to ask: &ldquo;Hasn&rsquo;t she come yet?&rdquo; They were
      expecting Márya Dmítrievna Akhrosímova, known in society as <i>le terrible
      dragon</i>, a lady distinguished not for wealth or rank, but for common sense and
      frank plainness of speech. Márya Dmítrievna was known to the Imperial family as
      well as to all Moscow and Petersburg, and both cities wondered at her,
      laughed privately at her rudenesses, and told good stories about her,
      while none the less all without exception respected and feared her.
    </p>
    <p>
      In the count&rsquo;s room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked of the war
      that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the recruiting. None of
      them had yet seen the manifesto, but they all knew it had appeared. The
      count sat on the sofa between two guests who were smoking and talking. He
      neither smoked nor talked, but bending his head first to one side and then
      to the other watched the smokers with evident pleasure and listened to the
      conversation of his two neighbors, whom he egged on against each other.
    </p>
    <p>
      One of them was a sallow, clean-shaven civilian with a thin and wrinkled
      face, already growing old, though he was dressed like a most fashionable
      young man. He sat with his legs up on the sofa as if quite at home and,
      having stuck an amber mouthpiece far into his mouth, was inhaling the
      smoke spasmodically and screwing up his eyes. This was an old bachelor,
      Shinshín, a cousin of the countess&rsquo;, a man with &ldquo;a sharp tongue&rdquo; as they
      said in Moscow society. He seemed to be condescending to his companion.
      The latter, a fresh, rosy officer of the Guards, irreproachably washed,
      brushed, and buttoned, held his pipe in the middle of his mouth and with
      red lips gently inhaled the smoke, letting it escape from his handsome
      mouth in rings. This was Lieutenant Berg, an officer in the Semënov
      regiment with whom Borís was to travel to join the army, and about whom
      Natásha had teased her elder sister Véra, speaking of Berg as her
      &ldquo;intended.&rdquo; The count sat between them and listened attentively. His
      favorite occupation when not playing boston, a card game he was very fond
      of, was that of listener, especially when he succeeded in setting two
      loquacious talkers at one another.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, then, old chap, <i>mon très honorable</i> Alphonse Kárlovich,&rdquo; said
      Shinshín, laughing ironically and mixing the most ordinary Russian
      expressions with the choicest French phrases&mdash;which was a peculiarity
      of his speech. &ldquo;<i>Vous comptez vous faire des rentes sur l&rsquo;état</i>; *
      you want to make something out of your company?&rdquo;
     </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * You expect to make an income out of the government.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, Peter Nikoláevich; I only want to show that in the cavalry the
      advantages are far less than in the infantry. Just consider my own
      position now, Peter Nikoláevich...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Berg always spoke quietly, politely, and with great precision. His
      conversation always related entirely to himself; he would remain calm and
      silent when the talk related to any topic that had no direct bearing on
      himself. He could remain silent for hours without being at all put out of
      countenance himself or making others uncomfortable, but as soon as the
      conversation concerned himself he would begin to talk circumstantially and
      with evident satisfaction.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Consider my position, Peter Nikoláevich. Were I in the cavalry I should
      get not more than two hundred rubles every four months, even with the rank
      of lieutenant; but as it is I receive two hundred and thirty,&rdquo; said he,
      looking at Shinshín and the count with a joyful, pleasant smile, as if it
      were obvious to him that his success must always be the chief desire of
      everyone else.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Besides that, Peter Nikoláevich, by exchanging into the Guards I shall be
      in a more prominent position,&rdquo; continued Berg, &ldquo;and vacancies occur much
      more frequently in the Foot Guards. Then just think what can be done with
      two hundred and thirty rubles! I even manage to put a little aside and to
      send something to my father,&rdquo; he went on, emitting a smoke ring.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;<i>La balance y est</i>... * A German knows how to skin a flint, as the
      proverb says,&rdquo; remarked Shinshín, moving his pipe to the other side of his
      mouth and winking at the count.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
      * So that squares matters.
</p>
    <p>
      The count burst out laughing. The other guests seeing that Shinshín was
      talking came up to listen. Berg, oblivious of irony or indifference,
      continued to explain how by exchanging into the Guards he had already
      gained a step on his old comrades of the Cadet Corps; how in wartime the
      company commander might get killed and he, as senior in the company, might
      easily succeed to the post; how popular he was with everyone in the
      regiment, and how satisfied his father was with him. Berg evidently
      enjoyed narrating all this, and did not seem to suspect that others, too,
      might have their own interests. But all he said was so prettily sedate,
      and the naïveté of his youthful egotism was so obvious, that he disarmed
      his hearers.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, my boy, you&rsquo;ll get along wherever you go&mdash;foot or horse&mdash;that
      I&rsquo;ll warrant,&rdquo; said Shinshín, patting him on the shoulder and taking his
      feet off the sofa.
    </p>
    <p>
      Berg smiled joyously. The count, followed by his guests, went into
      the drawing room.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was just the moment before a big dinner when the assembled guests,
      expecting the summons to <i>zakúska</i>, * avoid engaging in any long
      conversation but think it necessary to move about and talk, in order to
      show that they are not at all impatient for their food. The host and
      hostess look toward the door, and now and then glance at one another, and
      the visitors try to guess from these glances who, or what, they are
      waiting for&mdash;some important relation who has not yet arrived, or a
      dish that is not yet ready.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * Hors d&rsquo;oeuvres.
</p>
    <p>
      Pierre had come just at dinnertime and was sitting awkwardly in the middle
      of the drawing room on the first chair he had come across, blocking the
      way for everyone. The countess tried to make him talk, but he went on
      naïvely looking around through his spectacles as if in search of somebody
      and answered all her questions in monosyllables. He was in the way and was
      the only one who did not notice the fact. Most of the guests, knowing of
      the affair with the bear, looked with curiosity at this big, stout, quiet
      man, wondering how such a clumsy, modest fellow could have played such a
      prank on a policeman.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You have only lately arrived?&rdquo; the countess asked him.
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Oui, madame,&rdquo;</i> replied he, looking around him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You have not yet seen my husband?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Non, madame.&rdquo;</i> He smiled quite inappropriately.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You have been in Paris recently, I believe? I suppose it&rsquo;s very
      interesting.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Very interesting.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The countess exchanged glances with Anna Mikháylovna. The latter
      understood that she was being asked to entertain this young man, and
      sitting down beside him she began to speak about his father; but he
      answered her, as he had the countess, only in monosyllables. The other
      guests were all conversing with one another. &ldquo;The Razumóvskis... It was
      charming... You are very kind... Countess Apráksina...&rdquo; was heard on all
      sides. The countess rose and went into the ballroom.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Márya Dmítrievna?&rdquo; came her voice from there.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Herself,&rdquo; came the answer in a rough voice, and Márya Dmítrievna entered
      the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      All the unmarried ladies and even the married ones except the very oldest
      rose. Márya Dmítrievna paused at the door. Tall and stout, holding high
      her fifty-year-old head with its gray curls, she stood surveying the
      guests, and leisurely arranged her wide sleeves as if rolling them up.
      Márya Dmítrievna always spoke in Russian.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Health and happiness to her whose name day we are keeping and to her
      children,&rdquo; she said, in her loud, full-toned voice which drowned all
      others. &ldquo;Well, you old sinner,&rdquo; she went on, turning to the count who was
      kissing her hand, &ldquo;you&rsquo;re feeling dull in Moscow, I daresay? Nowhere to
      hunt with your dogs? But what is to be done, old man? Just see how these
      nestlings are growing up,&rdquo; and she pointed to the girls. &ldquo;You must look
      for husbands for them whether you like it or not....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well,&rdquo; said she, &ldquo;how&rsquo;s my Cossack?&rdquo; (Márya Dmítrievna always called
      Natásha a Cossack) and she stroked the child&rsquo;s arm as she came up fearless
      and gay to kiss her hand. &ldquo;I know she&rsquo;s a scamp of a girl, but I like
      her.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrings from her huge reticule and,
      having given them to the rosy Natásha, who beamed with the pleasure of her
      saint&rsquo;s-day fete, turned away at once and addressed herself to Pierre.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Eh, eh, friend! Come here a bit,&rdquo; said she, assuming a soft high tone of
      voice. &ldquo;Come here, my friend...&rdquo; and she ominously tucked up her sleeves
      still higher. Pierre approached, looking at her in a childlike way through
      his spectacles.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come nearer, come nearer, friend! I used to be the only one to tell your
      father the truth when he was in favor, and in your case it&rsquo;s my evident
      duty.&rdquo; She paused. All were silent, expectant of what was to follow, for
      this was clearly only a prelude.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;A fine lad! My word! A fine lad!... His father lies on his deathbed and
      he amuses himself setting a policeman astride a bear! For shame, sir, for
      shame! It would be better if you went to the war.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She turned away and gave her hand to the count, who could hardly keep from
      laughing.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, I suppose it is time we were at table?&rdquo; said Márya Dmítrievna.
    </p>
    <p>
      The count went in first with Márya Dmítrievna, the countess followed on
      the arm of a colonel of hussars, a man of importance to them because
      Nicholas was to go with him to the regiment; then came Anna Mikháylovna
      with Shinshín. Berg gave his arm to Véra. The smiling Julie Karágina went
      in with Nicholas. After them other couples followed, filling the whole
      dining hall, and last of all the children, tutors, and governesses
      followed singly. The footmen began moving about, chairs scraped, the band
      struck up in the gallery, and the guests settled down in their places.
      Then the strains of the count&rsquo;s household band were replaced by the
      clatter of knives and forks, the voices of visitors, and the soft steps of
      the footmen. At one end of the table sat the countess with Márya
      Dmítrievna on her right and Anna Mikháylovna on her left, the other lady
      visitors were farther down. At the other end sat the count, with the
      hussar colonel on his left and Shinshín and the other male visitors on his
      right. Midway down the long table on one side sat the grown-up young
      people: Véra beside Berg, and Pierre beside Borís; and on the other side,
      the children, tutors, and governesses. From behind the crystal decanters
      and fruit vases, the count kept glancing at his wife and her tall cap with
      its light-blue ribbons, and busily filled his neighbors&rsquo; glasses, not
      neglecting his own. The countess in turn, without omitting her duties as
      hostess, threw significant glances from behind the pineapples at her
      husband whose face and bald head seemed by their redness to contrast more
      than usual with his gray hair. At the ladies&rsquo; end an even chatter of
      voices was heard all the time, at the men&rsquo;s end the voices sounded louder
      and louder, especially that of the colonel of hussars who, growing more
      and more flushed, ate and drank so much that the count held him up as a
      pattern to the other guests. Berg with tender smiles was saying to Véra
      that love is not an earthly but a heavenly feeling. Borís was telling his
      new friend Pierre who the guests were and exchanging glances with Natásha,
      who was sitting opposite. Pierre spoke little but examined the new faces,
      and ate a great deal. Of the two soups he chose turtle with savory patties
      and went on to the game without omitting a single dish or one of the
      wines. These latter the butler thrust mysteriously forward, wrapped in a
      napkin, from behind the next man&rsquo;s shoulders and whispered: &ldquo;Dry
      Madeira&rdquo;... &ldquo;Hungarian&rdquo;... or &ldquo;Rhine wine&rdquo; as the case might be. Of the
      four crystal glasses engraved with the count&rsquo;s monogram that stood before
      his plate, Pierre held out one at random and drank with enjoyment, gazing
      with ever-increasing amiability at the other guests. Natásha, who sat
      opposite, was looking at Borís as girls of thirteen look at the boy they
      are in love with and have just kissed for the first time. Sometimes that
      same look fell on Pierre, and that funny lively little girl&rsquo;s look made
      him inclined to laugh without knowing why.
    </p>
    <p>
      Nicholas sat at some distance from Sónya, beside Julie Karágina, to whom
      he was again talking with the same involuntary smile. Sónya wore a company
      smile but was evidently tormented by jealousy; now she turned pale, now
      blushed and strained every nerve to overhear what Nicholas and Julie were
      saying to one another. The governess kept looking round uneasily as if
      preparing to resent any slight that might be put upon the children. The
      German tutor was trying to remember all the dishes, wines, and kinds of
      dessert, in order to send a full description of the dinner to his people
      in Germany; and he felt greatly offended when the butler with a bottle
      wrapped in a napkin passed him by. He frowned, trying to appear as if he
      did not want any of that wine, but was mortified because no one would
      understand that it was not to quench his thirst or from greediness that he
      wanted it, but simply from a conscientious desire for knowledge.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0019" id="link2HCH0019"></a>
      CHAPTER XIX
    </h2>
    <p>
      At the men&rsquo;s end of the table the talk grew more and more animated. The
      colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared in
      Petersburg and that a copy, which he had himself seen, had that day been
      forwarded by courier to the commander in chief.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And why the deuce are we going to fight Bonaparte?&rdquo; remarked Shinshín.
      &ldquo;He has stopped Austria&rsquo;s cackle and I fear it will be our turn next.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The colonel was a stout, tall, plethoric German, evidently devoted to the
      service and patriotically Russian. He resented Shinshín&rsquo;s remark.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It is for the reasson, my goot sir,&rdquo; said he, speaking with a German
      accent, &ldquo;for the reasson zat ze Emperor knows zat. He declares in ze
      manifessto zat he cannot fiew wiz indifference ze danger vreatening Russia
      and zat ze safety and dignity of ze Empire as vell as ze sanctity of its
      <i>alliances</i>...&rdquo; he spoke this last word with particular emphasis as
      if in it lay the gist of the matter.
    </p>
    <p>
      Then with the unerring official memory that characterized him he repeated
      from the opening words of the manifesto:
    </p>
    <p>
      ... <i>and the wish, which constitutes the Emperor&rsquo;s sole and absolute aim&mdash;to
      establish peace in Europe on firm foundations&mdash;has now decided him to
      despatch part of the army abroad and to create a new condition for the
      attainment of that purpose</i>.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Zat, my dear sir, is vy...&rdquo; he concluded, drinking a tumbler of wine with
      dignity and looking to the count for approval.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;<i>Connaissez-vous le Proverbe:</i>* &lsquo;Jerome, Jerome, do not roam, but
      turn spindles at home!&rsquo;?&rdquo; said Shinshín, puckering his brows and smiling.
      &ldquo;<i>Cela nous convient à merveille</i>.*(2) Suvórov now&mdash;he knew what
      he was about; yet they beat him <i>à plate couture</i>,*(3) and where are
      we to find Suvórovs now? <i>Je vous demande un peu</i>,&rdquo; *(4) said he,
      continually changing from French to Russian.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * Do you know the proverb?
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     *(2) That suits us down to the ground.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     *(3) Hollow.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     *(4) I just ask you that.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ve must vight to the last tr-r-op of our plood!&rdquo; said the colonel,
      thumping the table; &ldquo;and ve must tie for our Emperor, and zen all vill pe
      vell. And ve must discuss it as little as po-o-ossible&rdquo;... he dwelt
      particularly on the word <i>possible</i>... &ldquo;as po-o-ossible,&rdquo; he ended,
      again turning to the count. &ldquo;Zat is how ve old hussars look at it, and
      zere&rsquo;s an end of it! And how do you, a young man and a young hussar, how
      do you judge of it?&rdquo; he added, addressing Nicholas, who when he heard that
      the war was being discussed had turned from his partner with eyes and ears
      intent on the colonel.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am quite of your opinion,&rdquo; replied Nicholas, flaming up, turning his
      plate round and moving his wineglasses about with as much decision and
      desperation as though he were at that moment facing some great danger. &ldquo;I
      am convinced that we Russians must die or conquer,&rdquo; he concluded,
      conscious&mdash;as were others&mdash;after the words were uttered that his
      remarks were too enthusiastic and emphatic for the occasion and were
      therefore awkward.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What you said just now was splendid!&rdquo; said his partner Julie.
    </p>
    <p>
      Sónya trembled all over and blushed to her ears and behind them and down
      to her neck and shoulders while Nicholas was speaking.
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre listened to the colonel&rsquo;s speech and nodded approvingly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s fine,&rdquo; said he.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The young man&rsquo;s a real hussar!&rdquo; shouted the colonel, again thumping the
      table.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What are you making such a noise about over there?&rdquo; Márya Dmítrievna&rsquo;s
      deep voice suddenly inquired from the other end of the table. &ldquo;What are
      you thumping the table for?&rdquo; she demanded of the hussar, &ldquo;and why are you
      exciting yourself? Do you think the French are here?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am speaking ze truce,&rdquo; replied the hussar with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s all about the war,&rdquo; the count shouted down the table. &ldquo;You know my
      son&rsquo;s going, Márya Dmítrievna? My son is going.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have four sons in the army but still I don&rsquo;t fret. It is all in God&rsquo;s
      hands. You may die in your bed or God may spare you in a battle,&rdquo; replied
      Márya Dmítrievna&rsquo;s deep voice, which easily carried the whole length of
      the table.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s true!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Once more the conversations concentrated, the ladies&rsquo; at the one end and
      the men&rsquo;s at the other.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You won&rsquo;t ask,&rdquo; Natásha&rsquo;s little brother was saying; &ldquo;I know you won&rsquo;t
      ask!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I will,&rdquo; replied Natásha.
    </p>
    <p>
      Her face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution. She half
      rose, by a glance inviting Pierre, who sat opposite, to listen to what was
      coming, and turning to her mother:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mamma!&rdquo; rang out the clear contralto notes of her childish voice, audible
      the whole length of the table.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is it?&rdquo; asked the countess, startled; but seeing by her daughter&rsquo;s
      face that it was only mischief, she shook a finger at her sternly with a
      threatening and forbidding movement of her head.
    </p>
    <p>
      The conversation was hushed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?&rdquo; and Natásha&rsquo;s voice sounded
      still more firm and resolute.
    </p>
    <p>
      The countess tried to frown, but could not. Márya Dmítrievna shook her fat
      finger.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Cossack!&rdquo; she said threateningly.
    </p>
    <p>
      Most of the guests, uncertain how to regard this sally, looked at the
      elders.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You had better take care!&rdquo; said the countess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?&rdquo; Natásha again cried boldly,
      with saucy gaiety, confident that her prank would be taken in good part.
    </p>
    <p>
      Sónya and fat little Pétya doubled up with laughter.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You see! I <i>have</i> asked,&rdquo; whispered Natásha to her little brother
      and to Pierre, glancing at him again.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ice pudding, but you won&rsquo;t get any,&rdquo; said Márya Dmítrievna.
    </p>
    <p>
      Natásha saw there was nothing to be afraid of and so she braved even Márya
      Dmítrievna.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Márya Dmítrievna! What kind of ice pudding? I don&rsquo;t like ice cream.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Carrot ices.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No! What kind, Márya Dmítrievna? What kind?&rdquo; she almost screamed; &ldquo;I want
      to know!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Márya Dmítrievna and the countess burst out laughing, and all the guests
      joined in. Everyone laughed, not at Márya Dmítrievna&rsquo;s answer but at the
      incredible boldness and smartness of this little girl who had dared to
      treat Márya Dmítrievna in this fashion.
    </p>
    <p>
      Natásha only desisted when she had been told that there would be pineapple
      ice. Before the ices, champagne was served round. The band again struck
      up, the count and countess kissed, and the guests, leaving their seats,
      went up to &ldquo;congratulate&rdquo; the countess, and reached across the table to
      clink glasses with the count, with the children, and with one another.
      Again the footmen rushed about, chairs scraped, and in the same order in
      which they had entered but with redder faces, the guests returned to the
      drawing room and to the count&rsquo;s study.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0020" id="link2HCH0020"></a>
      CHAPTER XX
    </h2>
    <p>
      The card tables were drawn out, sets made up for boston, and the count&rsquo;s
      visitors settled themselves, some in the two drawing rooms, some in the
      sitting room, some in the library.
    </p>
    <p>
      The count, holding his cards fanwise, kept himself with difficulty from
      dropping into his usual after-dinner nap, and laughed at everything. The
      young people, at the countess&rsquo; instigation, gathered round the clavichord
      and harp. Julie by general request played first. After she had played a
      little air with variations on the harp, she joined the other young ladies
      in begging Natásha and Nicholas, who were noted for their musical talent,
      to sing something. Natásha, who was treated as though she were grown up,
      was evidently very proud of this but at the same time felt shy.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What shall we sing?&rdquo; she said.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;&lsquo;The Brook,&rsquo;&rdquo; suggested Nicholas.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, then, let&rsquo;s be quick. Borís, come here,&rdquo; said Natásha. &ldquo;But where
      is Sónya?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She looked round and seeing that her friend was not in the room ran to
      look for her.
    </p>
    <p>
      Running into Sónya&rsquo;s room and not finding her there, Natásha ran to the
      nursery, but Sónya was not there either. Natásha concluded that she must
      be on the chest in the passage. The chest in the passage was the place of
      mourning for the younger female generation in the Rostóv household. And
      there in fact was Sónya lying face downward on Nurse&rsquo;s dirty feather bed
      on the top of the chest, crumpling her gauzy pink dress under her, hiding
      her face with her slender fingers, and sobbing so convulsively that her
      bare little shoulders shook. Natásha&rsquo;s face, which had been so radiantly
      happy all that saint&rsquo;s day, suddenly changed: her eyes became fixed, and
      then a shiver passed down her broad neck and the corners of her mouth
      drooped.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sónya! What is it? What is the matter?... Oo... Oo... Oo...!&rdquo; And
      Natásha&rsquo;s large mouth widened, making her look quite ugly, and she began
      to wail like a baby without knowing why, except that Sónya was crying.
      Sónya tried to lift her head to answer but could not, and hid her face
      still deeper in the bed. Natásha wept, sitting on the blue-striped feather
      bed and hugging her friend. With an effort Sónya sat up and began wiping
      her eyes and explaining.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Nicholas is going away in a week&rsquo;s time, his... papers... have come... he
      told me himself... but still I should not cry,&rdquo; and she showed a paper she
      held in her hand&mdash;with the verses Nicholas had written, &ldquo;still, I
      should not cry, but you can&rsquo;t... no one can understand... what a soul he
      has!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And she began to cry again because he had such a noble soul.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s all very well for you... I am not envious... I love you and Borís
      also,&rdquo; she went on, gaining a little strength; &ldquo;he is nice... there are no
      difficulties in your way.... But Nicholas is my cousin... one would have
      to... the Metropolitan himself... and even then it can&rsquo;t be done. And
      besides, if she tells Mamma&rdquo; (Sónya looked upon the countess as her mother
      and called her so) &ldquo;that I am spoiling Nicholas&rsquo; career and am heartless
      and ungrateful, while truly... God is my witness,&rdquo; and she made the sign
      of the cross, &ldquo;I love her so much, and all of you, only Véra... And what
      for? What have I done to her? I am so grateful to you that I would
      willingly sacrifice everything, only I have nothing....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Sónya could not continue, and again hid her face in her hands and in the
      feather bed. Natásha began consoling her, but her face showed that she
      understood all the gravity of her friend&rsquo;s trouble.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sónya,&rdquo; she suddenly exclaimed, as if she had guessed the true reason of
      her friend&rsquo;s sorrow, &ldquo;I&rsquo;m sure Véra has said something to you since
      dinner? Hasn&rsquo;t she?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, these verses Nicholas wrote himself and I copied some others, and
      she found them on my table and said she&rsquo;d show them to Mamma, and that I
      was ungrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry me, but that
      he&rsquo;ll marry Julie. You see how he&rsquo;s been with her all day... Natásha, what
      have I done to deserve it?...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And again she began to sob, more bitterly than before. Natásha lifted her
      up, hugged her, and, smiling through her tears, began comforting her.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sónya, don&rsquo;t believe her, darling! Don&rsquo;t believe her! Do you remember how
      we and Nicholas, all three of us, talked in the sitting room after supper?
      Why, we settled how everything was to be. I don&rsquo;t quite remember how, but
      don&rsquo;t you remember that it could all be arranged and how nice it all was?
      There&rsquo;s Uncle Shinshín&rsquo;s brother has married his first cousin. And we are
      only second cousins, you know. And Borís says it is quite possible. You
      know I have told him all about it. And he is so clever and so good!&rdquo; said
      Natásha. &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t you cry, Sónya, dear love, darling Sónya!&rdquo; and she kissed
      her and laughed. &ldquo;Véra&rsquo;s spiteful; never mind her! And all will come right
      and she won&rsquo;t say anything to Mamma. Nicholas will tell her himself, and
      he doesn&rsquo;t care at all for Julie.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Natásha kissed her on the hair.
    </p>
    <p>
      Sónya sat up. The little kitten brightened, its eyes shone, and it seemed
      ready to lift its tail, jump down on its soft paws, and begin playing with
      the ball of worsted as a kitten should.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you think so?... Really? Truly?&rdquo; she said, quickly smoothing her frock
      and hair.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Really, truly!&rdquo; answered Natásha, pushing in a crisp lock that had
      strayed from under her friend&rsquo;s plaits.
    </p>
    <p>
      Both laughed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, let&rsquo;s go and sing &lsquo;The Brook.&rsquo;&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come along!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you know, that fat Pierre who sat opposite me is so funny!&rdquo; said
      Natásha, stopping suddenly. &ldquo;I feel so happy!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And she set off at a run along the passage.
    </p>
    <p>
      Sónya, shaking off some down which clung to her and tucking away the
      verses in the bosom of her dress close to her bony little chest, ran after
      Natásha down the passage into the sitting room with flushed face and
      light, joyous steps. At the visitors&rsquo; request the young people sang the
      quartette, &ldquo;The Brook,&rdquo; with which everyone was delighted. Then Nicholas
      sang a song he had just learned:
    </p>
<p class="poem">
   At nighttime in the moon&rsquo;s fair glow<br/>
    How sweet, as fancies wander free,<br/>
   To feel that in this world there&rsquo;s one<br/>
    Who still is thinking but of thee!<br/>
<br/>
   That while her fingers touch the harp<br/>
    Wafting sweet music o&rsquo;er the lea,<br/>
   It is for thee thus swells her heart,<br/>
    Sighing its message out to thee...<br/>
<br/>
   A day or two, then bliss unspoilt,<br/>
    But oh! till then I cannot live!...
</p>
    <p>
      He had not finished the last verse before the young people began to get
      ready to dance in the large hall, and the sound of the feet and the
      coughing of the musicians were heard from the gallery.
    </p>
    <p>
      <br />
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre was sitting in the drawing room where Shinshín had engaged him, as
      a man recently returned from abroad, in a political conversation in which
      several others joined but which bored Pierre. When the music began Natásha
      came in and walking straight up to Pierre said, laughing and blushing:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mamma told me to ask you to join the dancers.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am afraid of mixing the figures,&rdquo; Pierre replied; &ldquo;but if you will be
      my teacher...&rdquo; And lowering his big arm he offered it to the slender
      little girl.
    </p>
    <p>
      While the couples were arranging themselves and the musicians tuning up,
      Pierre sat down with his little partner. Natásha was perfectly happy; she
      was dancing with a <i>grown-up</i> man, who had been <i>abroad</i>. She
      was sitting in a conspicuous place and talking to him like a grown-up
      lady. She had a fan in her hand that one of the ladies had given her to
      hold. Assuming quite the pose of a society woman (heaven knows when and
      where she had learned it) she talked with her partner, fanning herself and
      smiling over the fan.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Dear, dear! Just look at her!&rdquo; exclaimed the countess as she crossed the
      ballroom, pointing to Natásha.
    </p>
    <p>
      Natásha blushed and laughed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised at?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      <br />
    </p>
    <p>
      In the midst of the third <i>écossaise</i> there was a clatter of chairs
      being pushed back in the sitting room where the count and Márya Dmítrievna
      had been playing cards with the majority of the more distinguished and
      older visitors. They now, stretching themselves after sitting so long, and
      replacing their purses and pocketbooks, entered the ballroom. First came
      Márya Dmítrievna and the count, both with merry countenances. The count,
      with playful ceremony somewhat in ballet style, offered his bent arm to
      Márya Dmítrievna. He drew himself up, a smile of debonair gallantry lit up
      his face and as soon as the last figure of the <i>écossaise</i> was ended,
      he clapped his hands to the musicians and shouted up to their gallery,
      addressing the first violin:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Semën! Do you know the <i>Daniel Cooper?</i>&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      This was the count&rsquo;s favorite dance, which he had danced in his youth.
      (Strictly speaking, <i>Daniel Cooper</i> was one figure of the <i>anglaise</i>.)
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Look at Papa!&rdquo; shouted Natásha to the whole company, and quite forgetting
      that she was dancing with a grown-up partner she bent her curly head to
      her knees and made the whole room ring with her laughter.
    </p>
    <p>
      And indeed everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the
      jovial old gentleman, who standing beside his tall and stout partner,
      Márya Dmítrievna, curved his arms, beat time, straightened his shoulders,
      turned out his toes, tapped gently with his foot, and, by a smile that
      broadened his round face more and more, prepared the onlookers for what
      was to follow. As soon as the provocatively gay strains of <i>Daniel
      Cooper</i> (somewhat resembling those of a merry peasant dance) began to
      sound, all the doorways of the ballroom were suddenly filled by the
      domestic serfs&mdash;the men on one side and the women on the other&mdash;who
      with beaming faces had come to see their master making merry.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Just look at the master! A regular eagle he is!&rdquo; loudly remarked the
      nurse, as she stood in one of the doorways.
    </p>
    <p>
      The count danced well and knew it. But his partner could not and did not
      want to dance well. Her enormous figure stood erect, her powerful arms
      hanging down (she had handed her reticule to the countess), and only her
      stern but handsome face really joined in the dance. What was expressed by
      the whole of the count&rsquo;s plump figure, in Márya Dmítrievna found
      expression only in her more and more beaming face and quivering nose. But
      if the count, getting more and more into the swing of it, charmed the
      spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers and the agility
      with which he capered about on his light feet, Márya Dmítrievna produced
      no less impression by slight exertions&mdash;the least effort to move her
      shoulders or bend her arms when turning, or stamp her foot&mdash;which
      everyone appreciated in view of her size and habitual severity. The dance
      grew livelier and livelier. The other couples could not attract a moment&rsquo;s
      attention to their own evolutions and did not even try to do so. All were
      watching the count and Márya Dmítrievna. Natásha kept pulling everyone by
      sleeve or dress, urging them to &ldquo;look at Papa!&rdquo; though as it was they
      never took their eyes off the couple. In the intervals of the dance the
      count, breathing deeply, waved and shouted to the musicians to play
      faster. Faster, faster, and faster; lightly, more lightly, and yet more
      lightly whirled the count, flying round Márya Dmítrievna, now on his toes,
      now on his heels; until, turning his partner round to her seat, he
      executed the final <i>pas</i>, raising his soft foot backwards, bowing his
      perspiring head, smiling and making a wide sweep with his arm, amid a
      thunder of applause and laughter led by Natásha. Both partners stood
      still, breathing heavily and wiping their faces with their cambric
      handkerchiefs.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s how we used to dance in our time, <i>ma chère</i>,&rdquo; said the
      count.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That <i>was</i> a <i>Daniel Cooper!</i>&rdquo; exclaimed Márya Dmítrievna,
      tucking up her sleeves and puffing heavily.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0021" id="link2HCH0021"></a>
      CHAPTER XXI
    </h2>
    <p>
      While in the Rostóvs&rsquo; ballroom the sixth <i>anglaise</i> was being danced,
      to a tune in which the weary musicians blundered, and while tired footmen
      and cooks were getting the supper, Count Bezúkhov had a sixth stroke. The
      doctors pronounced recovery impossible. After a mute confession, communion
      was administered to the dying man, preparations made for the sacrament of
      unction, and in his house there was the bustle and thrill of suspense
      usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond the gates, a group of
      undertakers, who hid whenever a carriage drove up, waited in expectation
      of an important order for an expensive funeral. The Military Governor of
      Moscow, who had been assiduous in sending aides-de-camp to inquire after
      the count&rsquo;s health, came himself that evening to bid a last farewell to
      the celebrated grandee of Catherine&rsquo;s court, Count Bezúkhov.
    </p>
    <p>
      The magnificent reception room was crowded. Everyone stood up respectfully
      when the Military Governor, having stayed about half an hour alone with
      the dying man, passed out, slightly acknowledging their bows and trying to
      escape as quickly as possible from the glances fixed on him by the
      doctors, clergy, and relatives of the family. Prince Vasíli, who had grown
      thinner and paler during the last few days, escorted him to the door,
      repeating something to him several times in low tones.
    </p>
    <p>
      When the Military Governor had gone, Prince Vasíli sat down all alone on a
      chair in the ballroom, crossing one leg high over the other, leaning his
      elbow on his knee and covering his face with his hand. After sitting so
      for a while he rose, and, looking about him with frightened eyes, went
      with unusually hurried steps down the long corridor leading to the back of
      the house, to the room of the eldest princess.
    </p>
    <p>
      Those who were in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous whispers,
      and, whenever anyone went into or came from the dying man&rsquo;s room, grew
      silent and gazed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at his door,
      which creaked slightly when opened.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The limits of human life ... are fixed and may not be o&rsquo;erpassed,&rdquo; said
      an old priest to a lady who had taken a seat beside him and was listening
      naïvely to his words.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I wonder, is it not too late to administer unction?&rdquo; asked the lady,
      adding the priest&rsquo;s clerical title, as if she had no opinion of her own on
      the subject.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, madam, it is a great sacrament,&rdquo; replied the priest, passing his hand
      over the thin grizzled strands of hair combed back across his bald head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Who was that? The Military Governor himself?&rdquo; was being asked at the
      other side of the room. &ldquo;How young-looking he is!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, and he is over sixty. I hear the count no longer recognizes anyone.
      They wished to administer the sacrament of unction.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I knew someone who received that sacrament seven times.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The second princess had just come from the sickroom with her eyes red from
      weeping and sat down beside Dr. Lorrain, who was sitting in a graceful
      pose under a portrait of Catherine, leaning his elbow on a table.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Beautiful,&rdquo; said the doctor in answer to a remark about the weather. &ldquo;The
      weather is beautiful, Princess; and besides, in Moscow one feels as if one
      were in the country.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, indeed,&rdquo; replied the princess with a sigh. &ldquo;So he may have something
      to drink?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Lorrain considered.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Has he taken his medicine?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The doctor glanced at his watch.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Take a glass of boiled water and put a pinch of cream of tartar,&rdquo; and he
      indicated with his delicate fingers what he meant by a pinch.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Dere has neffer been a gase,&rdquo; a German doctor was saying to an
      aide-de-camp, &ldquo;dat one liffs after de sird stroke.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And what a well-preserved man he was!&rdquo; remarked the aide-de-camp. &ldquo;And
      who will inherit his wealth?&rdquo; he added in a whisper.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It von&rsquo;t go begging,&rdquo; replied the German with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      Everyone again looked toward the door, which creaked as the second
      princess went in with the drink she had prepared according to Lorrain&rsquo;s
      instructions. The German doctor went up to Lorrain.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you think he can last till morning?&rdquo; asked the German, addressing
      Lorrain in French which he pronounced badly.
    </p>
    <p>
      Lorrain, pursing up his lips, waved a severely negative finger before his
      nose.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Tonight, not later,&rdquo; said he in a low voice, and he moved away with a
      decorous smile of self-satisfaction at being able clearly to understand
      and state the patient&rsquo;s condition.
    </p>
    <p>
      Meanwhile Prince Vasíli had opened the door into the princess&rsquo; room.
    </p>
    <p>
      In this room it was almost dark; only two tiny lamps were burning before
      the icons and there was a pleasant scent of flowers and burnt pastilles.
      The room was crowded with small pieces of furniture, whatnots, cupboards,
      and little tables. The quilt of a high, white feather bed was just visible
      behind a screen. A small dog began to bark.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, is it you, cousin?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She rose and smoothed her hair, which was as usual so extremely smooth
      that it seemed to be made of one piece with her head and covered with
      varnish.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Has anything happened?&rdquo; she asked. &ldquo;I am so terrified.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, there is no change. I only came to have a talk about business,
      Catiche,&rdquo; * muttered the prince, seating himself wearily on the chair she
      had just vacated. &ldquo;You have made the place warm, I must say,&rdquo; he remarked.
      &ldquo;Well, sit down: let&rsquo;s have a talk.&rdquo;
     </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * Catherine.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I thought perhaps something had happened,&rdquo; she said with her unchanging
      stonily severe expression; and, sitting down opposite the prince, she
      prepared to listen.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I wished to get a nap, <i>mon cousin</i>, but I can&rsquo;t.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, my dear?&rdquo; said Prince Vasíli, taking her hand and bending it
      downwards as was his habit.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was plain that this &ldquo;well?&rdquo; referred to much that they both understood
      without naming.
    </p>
    <p>
      The princess, who had a straight, rigid body, abnormally long for her
      legs, looked directly at Prince Vasíli with no sign of emotion in her
      prominent gray eyes. Then she shook her head and glanced up at the icons
      with a sigh. This might have been taken as an expression of sorrow and
      devotion, or of weariness and hope of resting before long. Prince Vasíli
      understood it as an expression of weariness.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And I?&rdquo; he said; &ldquo;do you think it is easier for me? I am as worn out as a
      post horse, but still I must have a talk with you, Catiche, a very serious
      talk.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli said no more and his cheeks began to twitch nervously, now
      on one side, now on the other, giving his face an unpleasant expression
      which was never to be seen on it in a drawing room. His eyes too seemed
      strange; at one moment they looked impudently sly and at the next glanced
      round in alarm.
    </p>
    <p>
      The princess, holding her little dog on her lap with her thin bony hands,
      looked attentively into Prince Vasíli&rsquo;s eyes evidently resolved not to be
      the first to break silence, if she had to wait till morning.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, you see, my dear princess and cousin, Catherine Semënovna,&rdquo;
       continued Prince Vasíli, returning to his theme, apparently not without an
      inner struggle; &ldquo;at such a moment as this one must think of everything.
      One must think of the future, of all of you... I love you all, like
      children of my own, as you know.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The princess continued to look at him without moving, and with the same
      dull expression.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And then of course my family has also to be considered,&rdquo; Prince Vasíli
      went on, testily pushing away a little table without looking at her. &ldquo;You
      know, Catiche, that we&mdash;you three sisters, Mámontov, and my wife&mdash;are
      the count&rsquo;s only direct heirs. I know, I know how hard it is for you to
      talk or think of such matters. It is no easier for me; but, my dear, I am
      getting on for sixty and must be prepared for anything. Do you know I have
      sent for Pierre? The count,&rdquo; pointing to his portrait, &ldquo;definitely
      demanded that he should be called.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Prince Vasíli looked questioningly at the princess, but could not make out
      whether she was considering what he had just said or whether she was
      simply looking at him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There is one thing I constantly pray God to grant, <i>mon cousin</i>,&rdquo;
       she replied, &ldquo;and it is that He would be merciful to him and would allow
      his noble soul peacefully to leave this...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, yes, of course,&rdquo; interrupted Prince Vasíli impatiently, rubbing his
      bald head and angrily pulling back toward him the little table that he had
      pushed away. &ldquo;But... in short, the fact is... you know yourself that last
      winter the count made a will by which he left all his property, not to us
      his direct heirs, but to Pierre.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He has made wills enough!&rdquo; quietly remarked the princess. &ldquo;But he cannot
      leave the estate to Pierre. Pierre is illegitimate.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But, my dear,&rdquo; said Prince Vasíli suddenly, clutching the little table
      and becoming more animated and talking more rapidly: &ldquo;what if a letter has
      been written to the Emperor in which the count asks for Pierre&rsquo;s
      legitimation? Do you understand that in consideration of the count&rsquo;s
      services, his request would be granted?...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The princess smiled as people do who think they know more about the
      subject under discussion than those they are talking with.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I can tell you more,&rdquo; continued Prince Vasíli, seizing her hand, &ldquo;that
      letter was written, though it was not sent, and the Emperor knew of it.
      The only question is, has it been destroyed or not? If not, then as soon
      as <i>all is over</i>,&rdquo; and Prince Vasíli sighed to intimate what he meant
      by the words <i>all is over</i>, &ldquo;and the count&rsquo;s papers are opened, the
      will and letter will be delivered to the Emperor, and the petition will
      certainly be granted. Pierre will get everything as the legitimate son.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And our share?&rdquo; asked the princess smiling ironically, as if anything
      might happen, only not that.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But, my poor Catiche, it is as clear as daylight! He will then be the
      legal heir to everything and you won&rsquo;t get anything. You must know, my
      dear, whether the will and letter were written, and whether they have been
      destroyed or not. And if they have somehow been overlooked, you ought to
      know where they are, and must find them, because...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What next?&rdquo; the princess interrupted, smiling sardonically and not
      changing the expression of her eyes. &ldquo;I am a woman, and you think we are
      all stupid; but I know this: an illegitimate son cannot inherit... <i>un
      bâtard!</i>&rdquo;* she added, as if supposing that this translation of the word
      would effectively prove to Prince Vasíli the invalidity of his contention.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * A bastard.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, really, Catiche! Can&rsquo;t you understand! You are so intelligent, how
      is it you don&rsquo;t see that if the count has written a letter to the Emperor
      begging him to recognize Pierre as legitimate, it follows that Pierre will
      not be Pierre but will become Count Bezúkhov, and will then inherit
      everything under the will? And if the will and letter are not destroyed,
      then you will have nothing but the consolation of having been dutiful <i>et
      tout ce qui s&rsquo;ensuit!</i>* That&rsquo;s certain.&rdquo;
     </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * And all that follows therefrom.
</p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know the will was made, but I also know that it is invalid; and you, <i>mon
      cousin</i>, seem to consider me a perfect fool,&rdquo; said the princess with
      the expression women assume when they suppose they are saying something
      witty and stinging.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My dear Princess Catherine Semënovna,&rdquo; began Prince Vasíli impatiently,
      &ldquo;I came here not to wrangle with you, but to talk about your interests as
      with a kinswoman, a good, kind, true relation. And I tell you for the
      tenth time that if the letter to the Emperor and the will in Pierre&rsquo;s
      favor are among the count&rsquo;s papers, then, my dear girl, you and your
      sisters are not heiresses! If you don&rsquo;t believe me, then believe an
      expert. I have just been talking to Dmítri Onúfrich&rdquo; (the family
      solicitor) &ldquo;and he says the same.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      At this a sudden change evidently took place in the princess&rsquo; ideas; her
      thin lips grew white, though her eyes did not change, and her voice when
      she began to speak passed through such transitions as she herself
      evidently did not expect.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That would be a fine thing!&rdquo; said she. &ldquo;I never wanted anything and I
      don&rsquo;t now.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      She pushed the little dog off her lap and smoothed her dress.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And this is gratitude&mdash;this is recognition for those who have
      sacrificed everything for his sake!&rdquo; she cried. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s splendid! Fine! I
      don&rsquo;t want anything, Prince.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, but you are not the only one. There are your sisters...&rdquo; replied
      Prince Vasíli.
    </p>
    <p>
      But the princess did not listen to him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, I knew it long ago but had forgotten. I knew that I could expect
      nothing but meanness, deceit, envy, intrigue, and ingratitude&mdash;the
      blackest ingratitude&mdash;in this house...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you or do you not know where that will is?&rdquo; insisted Prince Vasíli,
      his cheeks twitching more than ever.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, I was a fool! I still believed in people, loved them, and sacrificed
      myself. But only the base, the vile succeed! I know who has been
      intriguing!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The princess wished to rise, but the prince held her by the hand. She had
      the air of one who has suddenly lost faith in the whole human race. She
      gave her companion an angry glance.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There is still time, my dear. You must remember, Catiche, that it was all
      done casually in a moment of anger, of illness, and was afterwards
      forgotten. Our duty, my dear, is to rectify his mistake, to ease his last
      moments by not letting him commit this injustice, and not to let him die
      feeling that he is rendering unhappy those who...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Who sacrificed everything for him,&rdquo; chimed in the princess, who would
      again have risen had not the prince still held her fast, &ldquo;though he never
      could appreciate it. No, <i>mon cousin</i>,&rdquo; she added with a sigh, &ldquo;I
      shall always remember that in this world one must expect no reward, that
      in this world there is neither honor nor justice. In this world one has to
      be cunning and cruel.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now come, come! Be reasonable. I know your excellent heart.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, I have a wicked heart.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know your heart,&rdquo; repeated the prince. &ldquo;I value your friendship and
      wish you to have as good an opinion of me. Don&rsquo;t upset yourself, and let
      us talk sensibly while there is still time, be it a day or be it but an
      hour.... Tell me all you know about the will, and above all where it is.
      You must know. We will take it at once and show it to the count. He has,
      no doubt, forgotten it and will wish to destroy it. You understand that my
      sole desire is conscientiously to carry out his wishes; that is my only
      reason for being here. I came simply to help him and you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now I see it all! I know who has been intriguing&mdash;I know!&rdquo; cried the
      princess.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s not the point, my dear.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s that protégé of yours, that sweet Princess Drubetskáya, that Anna
      Mikháylovna whom I would not take for a housemaid... the infamous, vile
      woman!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do not let us lose any time...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, don&rsquo;t talk to me! Last winter she wheedled herself in here and told
      the count such vile, disgraceful things about us, especially about Sophie&mdash;I
      can&rsquo;t repeat them&mdash;that it made the count quite ill and he would not
      see us for a whole fortnight. I know it was then he wrote this vile,
      infamous paper, but I thought the thing was invalid.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We&rsquo;ve got to it at last&mdash;why did you not tell me about it sooner?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s in the inlaid portfolio that he keeps under his pillow,&rdquo; said the
      princess, ignoring his question. &ldquo;Now I know! Yes; if I have a sin, a
      great sin, it is hatred of that vile woman!&rdquo; almost shrieked the princess,
      now quite changed. &ldquo;And what does she come worming herself in here for?
      But I will give her a piece of my mind. The time will come!&rdquo;
     </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0022" id="link2HCH0022"></a>
      CHAPTER XXII
    </h2>
    <p>
      While these conversations were going on in the reception room and the
      princess&rsquo; room, a carriage containing Pierre (who had been sent for) and
      Anna Mikháylovna (who found it necessary to accompany him) was driving
      into the court of Count Bezúkhov&rsquo;s house. As the wheels rolled softly over
      the straw beneath the windows, Anna Mikháylovna, having turned with words
      of comfort to her companion, realized that he was asleep in his corner and
      woke him up. Rousing himself, Pierre followed Anna Mikháylovna out of the
      carriage, and only then began to think of the interview with his dying
      father which awaited him. He noticed that they had not come to the front
      entrance but to the back door. While he was getting down from the carriage
      steps two men, who looked like tradespeople, ran hurriedly from the
      entrance and hid in the shadow of the wall. Pausing for a moment, Pierre
      noticed several other men of the same kind hiding in the shadow of the
      house on both sides. But neither Anna Mikháylovna nor the footman nor the
      coachman, who could not help seeing these people, took any notice of them.
      &ldquo;It seems to be all right,&rdquo; Pierre concluded, and followed Anna
      Mikháylovna. She hurriedly ascended the narrow dimly lit stone staircase,
      calling to Pierre, who was lagging behind, to follow. Though he did not
      see why it was necessary for him to go to the count at all, still less why
      he had to go by the back stairs, yet judging by Anna Mikháylovna&rsquo;s air of
      assurance and haste, Pierre concluded that it was all absolutely
      necessary. Halfway up the stairs they were almost knocked over by some men
      who, carrying pails, came running downstairs, their boots clattering.
      These men pressed close to the wall to let Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna
      pass and did not evince the least surprise at seeing them there.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Is this the way to the princesses&rsquo; apartments?&rdquo; asked Anna Mikháylovna of
      one of them.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes,&rdquo; replied a footman in a bold loud voice, as if anything were now
      permissible; &ldquo;the door to the left, ma&rsquo;am.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Perhaps the count did not ask for me,&rdquo; said Pierre when he reached the
      landing. &ldquo;I&rsquo;d better go to my own room.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Anna Mikháylovna paused and waited for him to come up.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my friend!&rdquo; she said, touching his arm as she had done her son&rsquo;s when
      speaking to him that afternoon, &ldquo;believe me I suffer no less than you do,
      but be a man!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But really, hadn&rsquo;t I better go away?&rdquo; he asked, looking kindly at her
      over his spectacles.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my dear friend! Forget the wrongs that may have been done you. Think
      that he is your father ... perhaps in the agony of death.&rdquo; She sighed. &ldquo;I
      have loved you like a son from the first. Trust yourself to me, Pierre. I
      shall not forget your interests.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Pierre did not understand a word, but the conviction that all this had to
      be grew stronger, and he meekly followed Anna Mikháylovna who was already
      opening a door.
    </p>
    <p>
      This door led into a back anteroom. An old man, a servant of the
      princesses, sat in a corner knitting a stocking. Pierre had never been in
      this part of the house and did not even know of the existence of these
      rooms. Anna Mikháylovna, addressing a maid who was hurrying past with a
      decanter on a tray as &ldquo;my dear&rdquo; and &ldquo;my sweet,&rdquo; asked about the princess&rsquo;
      health and then led Pierre along a stone passage. The first door on the
      left led into the princesses&rsquo; apartments. The maid with the decanter in
      her haste had not closed the door (everything in the house was done in
      haste at that time), and Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna in passing
      instinctively glanced into the room, where Prince Vasíli and the eldest
      princess were sitting close together talking. Seeing them pass, Prince
      Vasíli drew back with obvious impatience, while the princess jumped up and
      with a gesture of desperation slammed the door with all her might.
    </p>
    <p>
      This action was so unlike her usual composure and the fear depicted on
      Prince Vasíli&rsquo;s face so out of keeping with his dignity that Pierre
      stopped and glanced inquiringly over his spectacles at his guide. Anna
      Mikháylovna evinced no surprise, she only smiled faintly and sighed, as if
      to say that this was no more than she had expected.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Be a man, my friend. I will look after your interests,&rdquo; said she in reply
      to his look, and went still faster along the passage.
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre could not make out what it was all about, and still less what
      &ldquo;watching over his interests&rdquo; meant, but he decided that all these things
      had to be. From the passage they went into a large, dimly lit room
      adjoining the count&rsquo;s reception room. It was one of those sumptuous but
      cold apartments known to Pierre only from the front approach, but even in
      this room there now stood an empty bath, and water had been spilled on the
      carpet. They were met by a deacon with a censer and by a servant who
      passed out on tiptoe without heeding them. They went into the reception
      room familiar to Pierre, with two Italian windows opening into the
      conservatory, with its large bust and full length portrait of Catherine
      the Great. The same people were still sitting here in almost the same
      positions as before, whispering to one another. All became silent and
      turned to look at the pale tear-worn Anna Mikháylovna as she entered, and
      at the big stout figure of Pierre who, hanging his head, meekly followed
      her.
    </p>
    <p>
      Anna Mikháylovna&rsquo;s face expressed a consciousness that the decisive moment
      had arrived. With the air of a practical Petersburg lady she now, keeping
      Pierre close beside her, entered the room even more boldly than that
      afternoon. She felt that as she brought with her the person the dying man
      wished to see, her own admission was assured. Casting a rapid glance at
      all those in the room and noticing the count&rsquo;s confessor there, she glided
      up to him with a sort of amble, not exactly bowing yet seeming to grow
      suddenly smaller, and respectfully received the blessing first of one and
      then of another priest.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;God be thanked that you are in time,&rdquo; said she to one of the priests;
      &ldquo;all we relatives have been in such anxiety. This young man is the count&rsquo;s
      son,&rdquo; she added more softly. &ldquo;What a terrible moment!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Having said this she went up to the doctor.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Dear doctor,&rdquo; said she, &ldquo;this young man is the count&rsquo;s son. Is there any
      hope?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The doctor cast a rapid glance upwards and silently shrugged his
      shoulders. Anna Mikháylovna with just the same movement raised her
      shoulders and eyes, almost closing the latter, sighed, and moved away from
      the doctor to Pierre. To him, in a particularly respectful and tenderly
      sad voice, she said:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Trust in His mercy!&rdquo; and pointing out a small sofa for him to sit and
      wait for her, she went silently toward the door that everyone was watching
      and it creaked very slightly as she disappeared behind it.
    </p>
    <p>
      Pierre, having made up his mind to obey his monitress implicitly, moved
