      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t like your Mademoiselle Bourienne at all,&rdquo; said Prince Andrew.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No? She is very nice and kind and, above all, she&rsquo;s much to be pitied.
      She has no one, no one. To tell the truth, I don&rsquo;t need her, and she&rsquo;s
      even in my way. You know I always was a savage, and now am even more so. I
      like being alone.... Father likes her very much. She and Michael Ivánovich
      are the two people to whom he is always gentle and kind, because he has
      been a benefactor to them both. As Sterne says: &lsquo;We don&rsquo;t love people so
      much for the good they have done us, as for the good we have done them.&rsquo;
      Father took her when she was homeless after losing her own father. She is
      very good-natured, and my father likes her way of reading. She reads to
      him in the evenings and reads splendidly.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father&rsquo;s character sometimes makes
      things trying for you, doesn&rsquo;t it?&rdquo; Prince Andrew asked suddenly.
    </p>
    <p>
      Princess Mary was first surprised and then aghast at this question.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;For me? For me?... Trying for me!...&rdquo; said she.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He always was rather harsh; and now I should think he&rsquo;s getting very
      trying,&rdquo; said Prince Andrew, apparently speaking lightly of their father
      in order to puzzle or test his sister.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You are good in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of intellectual
      pride,&rdquo; said the princess, following the train of her own thoughts rather
      than the trend of the conversation&mdash;&ldquo;and that&rsquo;s a great sin. How can
      one judge Father? But even if one might, what feeling except veneration
      could such a man as my father evoke? And I am so contented and happy with
      him. I only wish you were all as happy as I am.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Her brother shook his head incredulously.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The only thing that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth,
      Andrew... is Father&rsquo;s way of treating religious subjects. I don&rsquo;t
      understand how a man of his immense intellect can fail to see what is as
      clear as day, and can go so far astray. That is the only thing that makes
      me unhappy. But even in this I can see lately a shade of improvement. His
      satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a monk he received and
      had a long talk with.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wasting your powder,&rdquo; said
      Prince Andrew banteringly yet tenderly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah! <i>mon ami</i>, I only pray, and hope that God will hear me.
      Andrew...&rdquo; she said timidly after a moment&rsquo;s silence, &ldquo;I have a great
      favor to ask of you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is it, dear?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No&mdash;promise that you will not refuse! It will give you no trouble
      and is nothing unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise,
      Andrúsha!...&rdquo; said she, putting her hand in her reticule but not yet
      taking out what she was holding inside it, as if what she held were the
      subject of her request and must not be shown before the request was
      granted.
    </p>
    <p>
      She looked timidly at her brother.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Even if it were a great deal of trouble...&rdquo; answered Prince Andrew, as if
      guessing what it was about.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as you
      please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father&rsquo;s father, our
      grandfather, wore it in all his wars.&rdquo; (She still did not take out what
      she was holding in her reticule.) &ldquo;So you promise?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Of course. What is it?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will never
      take it off. Do you promise?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If it does not weigh a hundredweight and won&rsquo;t break my neck... To please
      you...&rdquo; said Prince Andrew. But immediately, noticing the pained
      expression his joke had brought to his sister&rsquo;s face, he repented and
      added: &ldquo;I am glad; really, dear, I am very glad.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Against your will He will save and have mercy on you and bring you to
      Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace,&rdquo; said she in a voice
      trembling with emotion, solemnly holding up in both hands before her
      brother a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a gold
      setting, on a finely wrought silver chain.
    </p>
    <p>
      She crossed herself, kissed the icon, and handed it to Andrew.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Please, Andrew, for my sake!...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rays of gentle light shone from her large, timid eyes. Those eyes lit up
      the whole of her thin, sickly face and made it beautiful. Her brother
      would have taken the icon, but she stopped him. Andrew understood, crossed
      himself and kissed the icon. There was a look of tenderness, for he was
      touched, but also a gleam of irony on his face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Thank you, my dear.&rdquo; She kissed him on the forehead and sat down again on
      the sofa. They were silent for a while.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;As I was saying to you, Andrew, be kind and generous as you always used
      to be. Don&rsquo;t judge Lise harshly,&rdquo; she began. &ldquo;She is so sweet, so
      good-natured, and her position now is a very hard one.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I do not think I have complained of my wife to you, Másha, or blamed her.
      Why do you say all this to me?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Red patches appeared on Princess Mary&rsquo;s face and she was silent as if she
      felt guilty.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have said nothing to you, but you have already been talked to. And I am
      sorry for that,&rdquo; he went on.
    </p>
    <p>
      The patches grew deeper on her forehead, neck, and cheeks. She tried to
      say something but could not. Her brother had guessed right: the little
      princess had been crying after dinner and had spoken of her forebodings
      about her confinement, and how she dreaded it, and had complained of her
      fate, her father-in-law, and her husband. After crying she had fallen
      asleep. Prince Andrew felt sorry for his sister.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Know this, Másha: I can&rsquo;t reproach, have not reproached, and never shall
      reproach <i>my wife</i> with anything, and I cannot reproach myself with
      anything in regard to her; and that always will be so in whatever
      circumstances I may be placed. But if you want to know the truth... if you
      want to know whether I am happy? No! Is she happy? No! But why this is so
      I don&rsquo;t know...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      As he said this he rose, went to his sister, and, stooping, kissed her
      forehead. His fine eyes lit up with a thoughtful, kindly, and unaccustomed
      brightness, but he was looking not at his sister but over her head toward
      the darkness of the open doorway.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Let us go to her, I must say good-by. Or&mdash;go and wake and I&rsquo;ll come
      in a moment. Petrúshka!&rdquo; he called to his valet: &ldquo;Come here, take these
      away. Put this on the seat and this to the right.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Princess Mary rose and moved to the door, then stopped and said: &ldquo;Andrew,
      if you had faith you would have turned to God and asked Him to give you
      the love you do not feel, and your prayer would have been answered.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, maybe!&rdquo; said Prince Andrew. &ldquo;Go, Másha; I&rsquo;ll come immediately.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      On the way to his sister&rsquo;s room, in the passage which connected one wing
      with the other, Prince Andrew met Mademoiselle Bourienne smiling sweetly.
      It was the third time that day that, with an ecstatic and artless smile,
      she had met him in secluded passages.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh! I thought you were in your room,&rdquo; she said, for some reason blushing
      and dropping her eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew looked sternly at her and an expression of anger suddenly
      came over his face. He said nothing to her but looked at her forehead and
      hair, without looking at her eyes, with such contempt that the Frenchwoman
      blushed and went away without a word. When he reached his sister&rsquo;s room
      his wife was already awake and her merry voice, hurrying one word after
      another, came through the open door. She was speaking as usual in French,
      and as if after long self-restraint she wished to make up for lost time.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, but imagine the old Countess Zúbova, with false curls and her mouth
      full of false teeth, as if she were trying to cheat old age.... Ha, ha,
      ha! Mary!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      This very sentence about Countess Zúbova and this same laugh Prince Andrew
      had already heard from his wife in the presence of others some five times.
      He entered the room softly. The little princess, plump and rosy, was
      sitting in an easy chair with her work in her hands, talking incessantly,
      repeating Petersburg reminiscences and even phrases. Prince Andrew came
      up, stroked her hair, and asked if she felt rested after their journey.
      She answered him and continued her chatter.
    </p>
    <p>
      The coach with six horses was waiting at the porch. It was an autumn
      night, so dark that the coachman could not see the carriage pole. Servants
      with lanterns were bustling about in the porch. The immense house was
      brilliant with lights shining through its lofty windows. The domestic
      serfs were crowding in the hall, waiting to bid good-by to the young
      prince. The members of the household were all gathered in the reception
      hall: Michael Ivánovich, Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess Mary, and the
      little princess. Prince Andrew had been called to his father&rsquo;s study as
      the latter wished to say good-by to him alone. All were waiting for them
      to come out.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Prince Andrew entered the study the old man in his old-age spectacles
      and white dressing gown, in which he received no one but his son, sat at
      the table writing. He glanced round.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Going?&rdquo; And he went on writing.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve come to say good-by.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Kiss me here,&rdquo; and he touched his cheek: &ldquo;Thanks, thanks!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What do you thank me for?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;For not dilly-dallying and not hanging to a woman&rsquo;s apron strings. The
      Service before everything. Thanks, thanks!&rdquo; And he went on writing, so
      that his quill spluttered and squeaked. &ldquo;If you have anything to say, say
      it. These two things can be done together,&rdquo; he added.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;About my wife... I am ashamed as it is to leave her on your hands....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why talk nonsense? Say what you want.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;When her confinement is due, send to Moscow for an <i>accoucheur</i>....
      Let him be here....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The old prince stopped writing and, as if not understanding, fixed his
      stern eyes on his son.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know that no one can help if nature does not do her work,&rdquo; said Prince
      Andrew, evidently confused. &ldquo;I know that out of a million cases only one
      goes wrong, but it is her fancy and mine. They have been telling her
      things. She has had a dream and is frightened.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Hm... Hm...&rdquo; muttered the old prince to himself, finishing what he was
      writing. &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll do it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He signed with a flourish and suddenly turning to his son began to laugh.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a bad business, eh?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is bad, Father?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The wife!&rdquo; said the old prince, briefly and significantly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t understand!&rdquo; said Prince Andrew.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, it can&rsquo;t be helped, lad,&rdquo; said the prince. &ldquo;They&rsquo;re all like that;
      one can&rsquo;t unmarry. Don&rsquo;t be afraid; I won&rsquo;t tell anyone, but you know it
      yourself.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He seized his son by the hand with small bony fingers, shook it, looked
      straight into his son&rsquo;s face with keen eyes which seemed to see through
      him, and again laughed his frigid laugh.
    </p>
    <p>
      The son sighed, thus admitting that his father had understood him. The old
      man continued to fold and seal his letter, snatching up and throwing down
      the wax, the seal, and the paper, with his accustomed rapidity.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What&rsquo;s to be done? She&rsquo;s pretty! I will do everything. Make your mind
      easy,&rdquo; said he in abrupt sentences while sealing his letter.
    </p>
    <p>
      Andrew did not speak; he was both pleased and displeased that his father
      understood him. The old man got up and gave the letter to his son.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Listen!&rdquo; said he; &ldquo;don&rsquo;t worry about your wife: what can be done shall
      be. Now listen! Give this letter to Michael Ilariónovich. * I have written
      that he should make use of you in proper places and not keep you long as
      an adjutant: a bad position! Tell him I remember and like him. Write and
      tell me how he receives you. If he is all right&mdash;serve him. Nicholas
      Bolkónski&rsquo;s son need not serve under anyone if he is in disfavor. Now come
      here.&rdquo;
     </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * Kutúzov.
</p>
    <p>
      He spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words, but his son was
      accustomed to understand him. He led him to the desk, raised the lid, drew
      out a drawer, and took out an exercise book filled with his bold, tall,
      close handwriting.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I shall probably die before you. So remember, these are my memoirs; hand
      them to the Emperor after my death. Now here is a Lombard bond and a
      letter; it is a premium for the man who writes a history of Suvórov&rsquo;s
      wars. Send it to the Academy. Here are some jottings for you to read when
      I am gone. You will find them useful.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Andrew did not tell his father that he would no doubt live a long time
      yet. He felt that he must not say it.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I will do it all, Father,&rdquo; he said.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, now, good-by!&rdquo; He gave his son his hand to kiss, and embraced him.
      &ldquo;Remember this, Prince Andrew, if they kill you it will hurt me, your old
      father...&rdquo; he paused unexpectedly, and then in a querulous voice suddenly
      shrieked: &ldquo;but if I hear that you have not behaved like a son of Nicholas
      Bolkónski, I shall be ashamed!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You need not have said that to me, Father,&rdquo; said the son with a smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      The old man was silent.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I also wanted to ask you,&rdquo; continued Prince Andrew, &ldquo;if I&rsquo;m killed and if
      I have a son, do not let him be taken away from you&mdash;as I said
      yesterday... let him grow up with you.... Please.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Not let the wife have him?&rdquo; said the old man, and laughed.
    </p>
    <p>
      They stood silent, facing one another. The old man&rsquo;s sharp eyes were fixed
      straight on his son&rsquo;s. Something twitched in the lower part of the old
      prince&rsquo;s face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We&rsquo;ve said good-by. Go!&rdquo; he suddenly shouted in a loud, angry voice,
      opening his door.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What is it? What?&rdquo; asked both princesses when they saw for a moment at
      the door Prince Andrew and the figure of the old man in a white dressing
      gown, spectacled and wigless, shouting in an angry voice.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew sighed and made no reply.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well!&rdquo; he said, turning to his wife.
    </p>
    <p>
      And this &ldquo;Well!&rdquo; sounded coldly ironic, as if he were saying: &ldquo;Now go
      through your performance.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Andrew, already!&rdquo; said the little princess, turning pale and looking with
      dismay at her husband.
    </p>
    <p>
      He embraced her. She screamed and fell unconscious on his shoulder.
    </p>
    <p>
      He cautiously released the shoulder she leaned on, looked into her face,
      and carefully placed her in an easy chair.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Adieu, Mary,&rdquo; said he gently to his sister, taking her by the hand and
      kissing her, and then he left the room with rapid steps.
    </p>
    <p>
      The little princess lay in the armchair, Mademoiselle Bourienne chafing
      her temples. Princess Mary, supporting her sister-in-law, still looked
      with her beautiful eyes full of tears at the door through which Prince
      Andrew had gone and made the sign of the cross in his direction. From the
      study, like pistol shots, came the frequent sound of the old man angrily
      blowing his nose. Hardly had Prince Andrew gone when the study door opened
      quickly and the stern figure of the old man in the white dressing gown
      looked out.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Gone? That&rsquo;s all right!&rdquo; said he; and looking angrily at the unconscious
      little princess, he shook his head reprovingly and slammed the door.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2H_4_0030" id="link2H_4_0030"></a>
      BOOK TWO: 1805
    </h2>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0029" id="link2HCH0029"></a>
      CHAPTER I
    </h2>
    <p>
      In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupying the villages and towns of
      the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other regiments freshly arriving from
      Russia were settling near the fortress of Braunau and burdening the
      inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was the headquarters of
      the commander in chief, Kutúzov.
    </p>
    <p>
      On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry regiments that had just reached
      Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waiting to be inspected by
      the commander in chief. Despite the un-Russian appearance of the locality
      and surroundings&mdash;fruit gardens, stone fences, tiled roofs, and hills
      in the distance&mdash;and despite the fact that the inhabitants (who gazed
      with curiosity at the soldiers) were not Russians, the regiment had just
      the appearance of any Russian regiment preparing for an inspection
      anywhere in the heart of Russia.
    </p>
    <p>
      On the evening of the last day&rsquo;s march an order had been received that the
      commander in chief would inspect the regiment on the march. Though the
      words of the order were not clear to the regimental commander, and the
      question arose whether the troops were to be in marching order or not, it
      was decided at a consultation between the battalion commanders to present
      the regiment in parade order, on the principle that it is always better to
      &ldquo;bow too low than not bow low enough.&rdquo; So the soldiers, after a
      twenty-mile march, were kept mending and cleaning all night long without
      closing their eyes, while the adjutants and company commanders calculated
      and reckoned, and by morning the regiment&mdash;instead of the straggling,
      disorderly crowd it had been on its last march the day before&mdash;presented
      a well-ordered array of two thousand men each of whom knew his place and
      his duty, had every button and every strap in place, and shone with
      cleanliness. And not only externally was all in order, but had it pleased
      the commander in chief to look under the uniforms he would have found on
      every man a clean shirt, and in every knapsack the appointed number of
      articles, &ldquo;awl, soap, and all,&rdquo; as the soldiers say. There was only one
      circumstance concerning which no one could be at ease. It was the state of
      the soldiers&rsquo; boots. More than half the men&rsquo;s boots were in holes. But
      this defect was not due to any fault of the regimental commander, for in
      spite of repeated demands boots had not been issued by the Austrian
      commissariat, and the regiment had marched some seven hundred miles.
    </p>
    <p>
      The commander of the regiment was an elderly, choleric, stout, and
      thick-set general with grizzled eyebrows and whiskers, and wider from
      chest to back than across the shoulders. He had on a brand-new uniform
      showing the creases where it had been folded and thick gold epaulettes
      which seemed to stand rather than lie down on his massive shoulders. He
      had the air of a man happily performing one of the most solemn duties of
      his life. He walked about in front of the line and at every step pulled
      himself up, slightly arching his back. It was plain that the commander
      admired his regiment, rejoiced in it, and that his whole mind was
      engrossed by it, yet his strut seemed to indicate that, besides military
      matters, social interests and the fair sex occupied no small part of his
      thoughts.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, Michael Mítrich, sir?&rdquo; he said, addressing one of the battalion
      commanders who smilingly pressed forward (it was plain that they both felt
      happy). &ldquo;We had our hands full last night. However, I think the regiment
      is not a bad one, eh?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The battalion commander perceived the jovial irony and laughed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It would not be turned off the field even on the Tsarítsin Meadow.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What?&rdquo; asked the commander.
    </p>
    <p>
      At that moment, on the road from the town on which signalers had been
      posted, two men appeared on horse back. They were an aide-de-camp followed
      by a Cossack.
    </p>
    <p>
      The aide-de-camp was sent to confirm the order which had not been clearly
      worded the day before, namely, that the commander in chief wished to see
      the regiment just in the state in which it had been on the march: in their
      greatcoats, and packs, and without any preparation whatever.
    </p>
    <p>
      A member of the Hofkriegsrath from Vienna had come to Kutúzov the day
      before with proposals and demands for him to join up with the army of the
      Archduke Ferdinand and Mack, and Kutúzov, not considering this junction
      advisable, meant, among other arguments in support of his view, to show
      the Austrian general the wretched state in which the troops arrived from
      Russia. With this object he intended to meet the regiment; so the worse
      the condition it was in, the better pleased the commander in chief would
      be. Though the aide-de-camp did not know these circumstances, he
      nevertheless delivered the definite order that the men should be in their
      greatcoats and in marching order, and that the commander in chief would
      otherwise be dissatisfied. On hearing this the regimental commander hung
      his head, silently shrugged his shoulders, and spread out his arms with a
      choleric gesture.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;A fine mess we&rsquo;ve made of it!&rdquo; he remarked.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There now! Didn&rsquo;t I tell you, Michael Mítrich, that if it was said &lsquo;on
      the march&rsquo; it meant in greatcoats?&rdquo; said he reproachfully to the battalion
      commander. &ldquo;Oh, my God!&rdquo; he added, stepping resolutely forward. &ldquo;Company
      commanders!&rdquo; he shouted in a voice accustomed to command. &ldquo;Sergeants
      major!... How soon will he be here?&rdquo; he asked the aide-de-camp with a
      respectful politeness evidently relating to the personage he was referring
      to.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;In an hour&rsquo;s time, I should say.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Shall we have time to change clothes?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t know, General....&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The regimental commander, going up to the line himself, ordered the
      soldiers to change into their greatcoats. The company commanders ran off
      to their companies, the sergeants major began bustling (the greatcoats
      were not in very good condition), and instantly the squares that had up to
      then been in regular order and silent began to sway and stretch and hum
      with voices. On all sides soldiers were running to and fro, throwing up
      their knapsacks with a jerk of their shoulders and pulling the straps over
      their heads, unstrapping their overcoats and drawing the sleeves on with
      upraised arms.
    </p>
    <p>
      In half an hour all was again in order, only the squares had become gray
      instead of black. The regimental commander walked with his jerky steps to
      the front of the regiment and examined it from a distance.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Whatever is this? This!&rdquo; he shouted and stood still. &ldquo;Commander of the
      third company!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Commander of the third company wanted by the general!... commander to the
      general... third company to the commander.&rdquo; The words passed along the
      lines and an adjutant ran to look for the missing officer.
    </p>
    <p>
      When the eager but misrepeated words had reached their destination in a
      cry of: &ldquo;The general to the third company,&rdquo; the missing officer appeared
      from behind his company and, though he was a middle-aged man and not in
      the habit of running, trotted awkwardly stumbling on his toes toward the
      general. The captain&rsquo;s face showed the uneasiness of a schoolboy who is
      told to repeat a lesson he has not learned. Spots appeared on his nose,
      the redness of which was evidently due to intemperance, and his mouth
      twitched nervously. The general looked the captain up and down as he came
      up panting, slackening his pace as he approached.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You will soon be dressing your men in petticoats! What is this?&rdquo; shouted
      the regimental commander, thrusting forward his jaw and pointing at a
      soldier in the ranks of the third company in a greatcoat of bluish cloth,
      which contrasted with the others. &ldquo;What have you been after? The commander
      in chief is expected and you leave your place? Eh? I&rsquo;ll teach you to dress
      the men in fancy coats for a parade.... Eh...?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The commander of the company, with his eyes fixed on his superior, pressed
      two fingers more and more rigidly to his cap, as if in this pressure lay
      his only hope of salvation.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, why don&rsquo;t you speak? Whom have you got there dressed up as a
      Hungarian?&rdquo; said the commander with an austere gibe.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Your excellency...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, your excellency, what? Your excellency! But what about your
      excellency?... nobody knows.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Your excellency, it&rsquo;s the officer Dólokhov, who has been reduced to the
      ranks,&rdquo; said the captain softly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well? Has he been degraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier? If a
      soldier, he should be dressed in regulation uniform like the others.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Your excellency, you gave him leave yourself, on the march.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Gave him leave? Leave? That&rsquo;s just like you young men,&rdquo; said the
      regimental commander cooling down a little. &ldquo;Leave indeed.... One says a
      word to you and you... What?&rdquo; he added with renewed irritation, &ldquo;I beg you
      to dress your men decently.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And the commander, turning to look at the adjutant, directed his jerky
      steps down the line. He was evidently pleased at his own display of anger
      and walking up to the regiment wished to find a further excuse for wrath.
      Having snapped at an officer for an unpolished badge, at another because
      his line was not straight, he reached the third company.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;H-o-o-w are you standing? Where&rsquo;s your leg? Your leg?&rdquo; shouted the
      commander with a tone of suffering in his voice, while there were still
      five men between him and Dólokhov with his bluish-gray uniform.
    </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov slowly straightened his bent knee, looking straight with his
      clear, insolent eyes in the general&rsquo;s face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why a blue coat? Off with it... Sergeant major! Change his coat... the
      ras...&rdquo; he did not finish.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;General, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure...&rdquo; Dólokhov
      hurriedly interrupted.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No talking in the ranks!... No talking, no talking!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Not bound to endure insults,&rdquo; Dólokhov concluded in loud, ringing tones.
    </p>
    <p>
      The eyes of the general and the soldier met. The general became silent,
      angrily pulling down his tight scarf.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I request you to have the goodness to change your coat,&rdquo; he said as he
      turned away.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0030" id="link2HCH0030"></a>
      CHAPTER II
    </h2>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He&rsquo;s coming!&rdquo; shouted the signaler at that moment.
    </p>
    <p>
      The regimental commander, flushing, ran to his horse, seized the stirrup
      with trembling hands, threw his body across the saddle, righted himself,
      drew his saber, and with a happy and resolute countenance, opening his
      mouth awry, prepared to shout. The regiment fluttered like a bird preening
      its plumage and became motionless.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Att-ention!&rdquo; shouted the regimental commander in a soul-shaking voice
      which expressed joy for himself, severity for the regiment, and welcome
      for the approaching chief.
    </p>
    <p>
      Along the broad country road, edged on both sides by trees, came a high,
      light blue Viennese <i>calèche</i>, slightly creaking on its springs and
      drawn by six horses at a smart trot. Behind the <i>calèche</i> galloped
      the suite and a convoy of Croats. Beside Kutúzov sat an Austrian general,
      in a white uniform that looked strange among the Russian black ones. The
      <i>calèche</i> stopped in front of the regiment. Kutúzov and the Austrian
      general were talking in low voices and Kutúzov smiled slightly as treading
      heavily he stepped down from the carriage just as if those two thousand
      men breathlessly gazing at him and the regimental commander did not exist.
    </p>
    <p>
      The word of command rang out, and again the regiment quivered, as with a
      jingling sound it presented arms. Then amidst a dead silence the feeble
      voice of the commander in chief was heard. The regiment roared, &ldquo;Health to
      your ex... len... len... lency!&rdquo; and again all became silent. At first
      Kutúzov stood still while the regiment moved; then he and the general in
      white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the ranks.
    </p>
    <p>
      From the way the regimental commander saluted the commander in chief and
      devoured him with his eyes, drawing himself up obsequiously, and from the
      way he walked through the ranks behind the generals, bending forward and
      hardly able to restrain his jerky movements, and from the way he darted
      forward at every word or gesture of the commander in chief, it was evident
      that he performed his duty as a subordinate with even greater zeal than
      his duty as a commander. Thanks to the strictness and assiduity of its
      commander the regiment, in comparison with others that had reached Braunau
      at the same time, was in splendid condition. There were only 217 sick and
      stragglers. Everything was in good order except the boots.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov walked through the ranks, sometimes stopping to say a few friendly
      words to officers he had known in the Turkish war, sometimes also to the
      soldiers. Looking at their boots he several times shook his head sadly,
      pointing them out to the Austrian general with an expression which seemed
      to say that he was not blaming anyone, but could not help noticing what a
      bad state of things it was. The regimental commander ran forward on each
      such occasion, fearing to miss a single word of the commander in chief&rsquo;s
      regarding the regiment. Behind Kutúzov, at a distance that allowed every
      softly spoken word to be heard, followed some twenty men of his suite.
      These gentlemen talked among themselves and sometimes laughed. Nearest of
      all to the commander in chief walked a handsome adjutant. This was Prince
      Bolkónski. Beside him was his comrade Nesvítski, a tall staff officer,
      extremely stout, with a kindly, smiling, handsome face and moist eyes.
      Nesvítski could hardly keep from laughter provoked by a swarthy hussar
      officer who walked beside him. This hussar, with a grave face and without
      a smile or a change in the expression of his fixed eyes, watched the
      regimental commander&rsquo;s back and mimicked his every movement. Each time the
      commander started and bent forward, the hussar started and bent forward in
      exactly the same manner. Nesvítski laughed and nudged the others to make
      them look at the wag.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov walked slowly and languidly past thousands of eyes which were
      starting from their sockets to watch their chief. On reaching the third
      company he suddenly stopped. His suite, not having expected this,
      involuntarily came closer to him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, Timókhin!&rdquo; said he, recognizing the red-nosed captain who had been
      reprimanded on account of the blue greatcoat.
    </p>
    <p>
      One would have thought it impossible for a man to stretch himself more
      than Timókhin had done when he was reprimanded by the regimental
      commander, but now that the commander in chief addressed him he drew
      himself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained it
      had the commander in chief continued to look at him, and so Kutúzov, who
      evidently understood his case and wished him nothing but good, quickly
      turned away, a scarcely perceptible smile flitting over his scarred and
      puffy face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Another Ismail comrade,&rdquo; said he. &ldquo;A brave officer! Are you satisfied
      with him?&rdquo; he asked the regimental commander.
    </p>
    <p>
      And the latter&mdash;unconscious that he was being reflected in the hussar
      officer as in a looking glass&mdash;started, moved forward, and answered:
      &ldquo;Highly satisfied, your excellency!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We all have our weaknesses,&rdquo; said Kutúzov smiling and walking away from
      him. &ldquo;He used to have a predilection for Bacchus.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The regimental commander was afraid he might be blamed for this and did
      not answer. The hussar at that moment noticed the face of the red-nosed
      captain and his drawn-in stomach, and mimicked his expression and pose
      with such exactitude that Nesvítski could not help laughing. Kutúzov
      turned round. The officer evidently had complete control of his face, and
      while Kutúzov was turning managed to make a grimace and then assume a most
      serious, deferential, and innocent expression.
    </p>
    <p>
      The third company was the last, and Kutúzov pondered, apparently trying to
      recollect something. Prince Andrew stepped forward from among the suite
      and said in French:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You told me to remind you of the officer Dólokhov, reduced to the ranks
      in this regiment.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Where is Dólokhov?&rdquo; asked Kutúzov.
    </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov, who had already changed into a soldier&rsquo;s gray greatcoat, did not
      wait to be called. The shapely figure of the fair-haired soldier, with his
      clear blue eyes, stepped forward from the ranks, went up to the commander
      in chief, and presented arms.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Have you a complaint to make?&rdquo; Kutúzov asked with a slight frown.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;This is Dólokhov,&rdquo; said Prince Andrew.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah!&rdquo; said Kutúzov. &ldquo;I hope this will be a lesson to you. Do your duty.
      The Emperor is gracious, and I shan&rsquo;t forget you if you deserve well.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The clear blue eyes looked at the commander in chief just as boldly as
      they had looked at the regimental commander, seeming by their expression
      to tear open the veil of convention that separates a commander in chief so
      widely from a private.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;One thing I ask of your excellency,&rdquo; Dólokhov said in his firm, ringing,
      deliberate voice. &ldquo;I ask an opportunity to atone for my fault and prove my
      devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov turned away. The same smile of the eyes with which he had turned
      from Captain Timókhin again flitted over his face. He turned away with a
      grimace as if to say that everything Dólokhov had said to him and
      everything he could say had long been known to him, that he was weary of
      it and it was not at all what he wanted. He turned away and went to the
      carriage.
    </p>
    <p>
      The regiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed
      quarters near Braunau, where they hoped to receive boots and clothes and
      to rest after their hard marches.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You won&rsquo;t bear me a grudge, Prokhór Ignátych?&rdquo; said the regimental
      commander, overtaking the third company on its way to its quarters and
      riding up to Captain Timókhin who was walking in front. (The regimental
      commander&rsquo;s face now that the inspection was happily over beamed with
      irrepressible delight.) &ldquo;It&rsquo;s in the Emperor&rsquo;s service... it can&rsquo;t be
      helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on parade... I am the first to
      apologize, you know me!... He was very pleased!&rdquo; And he held out his hand
      to the captain.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t mention it, General, as if I&rsquo;d be so bold!&rdquo; replied the captain,
      his nose growing redder as he gave a smile which showed where two front teeth
      were missing that had been knocked out by the butt end of a gun at Ismail.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And tell Mr. Dólokhov that I won&rsquo;t forget him&mdash;he may be quite easy.
      And tell me, please&mdash;I&rsquo;ve been meaning to ask&mdash;how is he
      behaving himself, and in general...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;As far as the service goes he is quite punctilious, your excellency; but
      his character...&rdquo; said Timókhin.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And what about his character?&rdquo; asked the regimental commander.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s different on different days,&rdquo; answered the captain. &ldquo;One day he is
      sensible, well educated, and good-natured, and the next he&rsquo;s a wild
      beast.... In Poland, if you please, he nearly killed a Jew.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, well, well!&rdquo; remarked the regimental commander. &ldquo;Still, one must have
      pity on a young man in misfortune. You know he has important
      connections... Well, then, you just...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I will, your excellency,&rdquo; said Timókhin, showing by his smile that he
      understood his commander&rsquo;s wish.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, of course, of course!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The regimental commander sought out Dólokhov in the ranks and, reining in
      his horse, said to him:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;After the next affair... epaulettes.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov looked round but did not say anything, nor did the mocking smile
      on his lips change.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, that&rsquo;s all right,&rdquo; continued the regimental commander. &ldquo;A cup of
      vodka for the men from me,&rdquo; he added so that the soldiers could hear. &ldquo;I
      thank you all! God be praised!&rdquo; and he rode past that company and overtook
      the next one.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, he&rsquo;s really a good fellow, one can serve under him,&rdquo; said Timókhin
      to the subaltern beside him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;In a word, a hearty one...&rdquo; said the subaltern, laughing (the regimental
      commander was nicknamed <i>King of Hearts</i>).
    </p>
    <p>
      The cheerful mood of their officers after the inspection infected the
      soldiers. The company marched on gaily. The soldiers&rsquo; voices could be
      heard on every side.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And they said Kutúzov was blind of one eye?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And so he is! Quite blind!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, friend, he is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and leg bands... he
      noticed everything...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;When he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were smeared
      with chalk&mdash;as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as they
      do the guns.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I say, Fédeshon!... Did he say when the battles are to begin? You were
      near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Buonaparte himself!... Just listen to the fool, what he doesn&rsquo;t know! The
      Prussians are up in arms now. The Austrians, you see, are putting them
      down. When they&rsquo;ve been put down, the war with Buonaparte will begin. And
      he says Buonaparte is in Braunau! Shows you&rsquo;re a fool. You&rsquo;d better listen
      more carefully!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What devils these quartermasters are! See, the fifth company is turning
      into the village already... they will have their buckwheat cooked before
      we reach our quarters.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Give me a biscuit, you devil!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And did you give me tobacco yesterday? That&rsquo;s just it, friend! Ah, well,
      never mind, here you are.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They might call a halt here or we&rsquo;ll have to do another four miles
      without eating.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wasn&rsquo;t it fine when those Germans gave us lifts! You just sit still and
      are drawn along.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And here, friend, the people are quite beggarly. There they all seemed to
      be Poles&mdash;all under the Russian crown&mdash;but here they&rsquo;re all
      regular Germans.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Singers to the front&rdquo; came the captain&rsquo;s order.
    </p>
    <p>
      And from the different ranks some twenty men ran to the front. A drummer,
      their leader, turned round facing the singers, and flourishing his arm,
      began a long-drawn-out soldiers&rsquo; song, commencing with the words: <i>&ldquo;Morning
      dawned, the sun was rising,&rdquo;</i> and concluding: <i>&ldquo;On then, brothers, on to
      glory, led by Father Kámenski.&rdquo;</i> This song had been composed in the Turkish
      campaign and now being sung in Austria, the only change being that the
      words &ldquo;Father Kámenski&rdquo; were replaced by &ldquo;Father Kutúzov.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Having jerked out these last words as soldiers do and waved his arms as if
      flinging something to the ground, the drummer&mdash;a lean, handsome
      soldier of forty&mdash;looked sternly at the singers and screwed up his
      eyes. Then having satisfied himself that all eyes were fixed on him, he
      raised both arms as if carefully lifting some invisible but precious
      object above his head and, holding it there for some seconds, suddenly
      flung it down and began:
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Oh, my bower, oh, my bower...!&rdquo;</i>
     </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Oh, my bower new...!&rdquo;</i> chimed in twenty voices, and the castanet player,
      in spite of the burden of his equipment, rushed out to the front and,
      walking backwards before the company, jerked his shoulders and flourished
      his castanets as if threatening someone. The soldiers, swinging their arms
      and keeping time spontaneously, marched with long steps. Behind the
      company the sound of wheels, the creaking of springs, and the tramp of
      horses&rsquo; hoofs were heard. Kutúzov and his suite were returning to the
      town. The commander in chief made a sign that the men should continue to
      march at ease, and he and all his suite showed pleasure at the sound of
      the singing and the sight of the dancing soldier and the gay and smartly
      marching men. In the second file from the right flank, beside which the
      carriage passed the company, a blue-eyed soldier involuntarily attracted
      notice. It was Dólokhov marching with particular grace and boldness in
      time to the song and looking at those driving past as if he pitied all who
      were not at that moment marching with the company. The hussar cornet of
      Kutúzov&rsquo;s suite who had mimicked the regimental commander, fell back from
      the carriage and rode up to Dólokhov.
    </p>
    <p>
      Hussar cornet Zherkóv had at one time, in Petersburg, belonged to the wild
      set led by Dólokhov. Zherkóv had met Dólokhov abroad as a private and had
      not seen fit to recognize him. But now that Kutúzov had spoken to the
      gentleman ranker, he addressed him with the cordiality of an old friend.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;My dear fellow, how are you?&rdquo; said he through the singing, making his
      horse keep pace with the company.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How am I?&rdquo; Dólokhov answered coldly. &ldquo;I am as you see.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The lively song gave a special flavor to the tone of free and easy gaiety
      with which Zherkóv spoke, and to the intentional coldness of Dólokhov&rsquo;s
      reply.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And how do you get on with the officers?&rdquo; inquired Zherkóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;All right. They are good fellows. And how have you wriggled onto the
      staff?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I was attached; I&rsquo;m on duty.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Both were silent.
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;She let the hawk fly upward from her wide right sleeve,&rdquo;</i> went the song,
      arousing an involuntary sensation of courage and cheerfulness. Their
      conversation would probably have been different but for the effect of that
      song.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Is it true that Austrians have been beaten?&rdquo; asked Dólokhov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The devil only knows! They say so.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;m glad,&rdquo; answered Dólokhov briefly and clearly, as the song demanded.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I say, come round some evening and we&rsquo;ll have a game of faro!&rdquo; said
      Zherkóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why, have you too much money?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do come.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I can&rsquo;t. I&rsquo;ve sworn not to. I won&rsquo;t drink and won&rsquo;t play till I get
      reinstated.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, that&rsquo;s only till the first engagement.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We shall see.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      They were again silent.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come if you need anything. One can at least be of use on the staff...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Dólokhov smiled. &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t trouble. If I want anything, I won&rsquo;t beg&mdash;I&rsquo;ll
      take it!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, never mind; I only...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And I only...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Good-by.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Good health...&rdquo;
     </p>
<p class="poem">
        <i>&ldquo;It&rsquo;s a long, long way.<br/>
        To my native land...&rdquo;</i>
 </p>
    <p>
      Zherkóv touched his horse with the spurs; it pranced excitedly from foot
      to foot uncertain with which to start, then settled down, galloped past
      the company, and overtook the carriage, still keeping time to the song.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0031" id="link2HCH0031"></a>
      CHAPTER III
    </h2>
    <p>
      On returning from the review, Kutúzov took the Austrian general into his
      private room and, calling his adjutant, asked for some papers relating to
      the condition of the troops on their arrival, and the letters that had
      come from the Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of the advanced army.
      Prince Andrew Bolkónski came into the room with the required papers.
      Kutúzov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriegsrath were sitting at the
      table on which a plan was spread out.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah!...&rdquo; said Kutúzov glancing at Bolkónski as if by this exclamation he
      was asking the adjutant to wait, and he went on with the conversation in
      French.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;All I can say, General,&rdquo; said he with a pleasant elegance of expression
      and intonation that obliged one to listen to each deliberately spoken
      word. It was evident that Kutúzov himself listened with pleasure to his
      own voice. &ldquo;All I can say, General, is that if the matter depended on my
      personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the Emperor Francis would have
      been fulfilled long ago. I should long ago have joined the archduke. And
      believe me on my honour that to me personally it would be a pleasure to
      hand over the supreme command of the army into the hands of a better
      informed and more skillful general&mdash;of whom Austria has so many&mdash;and
      to lay down all this heavy responsibility. But circumstances are sometimes
      too strong for us, General.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And Kutúzov smiled in a way that seemed to say, &ldquo;You are quite at liberty
      not to believe me and I don&rsquo;t even care whether you do or not, but you
      have no grounds for telling me so. And that is the whole point.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The Austrian general looked dissatisfied, but had no option but to reply
      in the same tone.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;On the contrary,&rdquo; he said, in a querulous and angry tone that contrasted
      with his flattering words, &ldquo;on the contrary, your excellency&rsquo;s
      participation in the common action is highly valued by His Majesty; but we
      think the present delay is depriving the splendid Russian troops and their
      commander of the laurels they have been accustomed to win in their
      battles,&rdquo; he concluded his evidently prearranged sentence.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov bowed with the same smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But that is my conviction, and judging by the last letter with which His
      Highness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imagine that the
      Austrian troops, under the direction of so skillful a leader as General
      Mack, have by now already gained a decisive victory and no longer need our
      aid,&rdquo; said Kutúzov.
    </p>
    <p>
      The general frowned. Though there was no definite news of an Austrian
      defeat, there were many circumstances confirming the unfavorable rumors
      that were afloat, and so Kutúzov&rsquo;s suggestion of an Austrian victory
      sounded much like irony. But Kutúzov went on blandly smiling with the same
      expression, which seemed to say that he had a right to suppose so. And, in
      fact, the last letter he had received from Mack&rsquo;s army informed him of a
      victory and stated strategically the position of the army was very
      favorable.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Give me that letter,&rdquo; said Kutúzov turning to Prince Andrew. &ldquo;Please have
      a look at it&rdquo;&mdash;and Kutúzov with an ironical smile about the corners
      of his mouth read to the Austrian general the following passage, in
      German, from the Archduke Ferdinand&rsquo;s letter:
    </p>
    <p>
      We have fully concentrated forces of nearly seventy thousand men with
      which to attack and defeat the enemy should he cross the Lech. Also, as we
      are masters of Ulm, we cannot be deprived of the advantage of commanding
      both sides of the Danube, so that should the enemy not cross the Lech, we
      can cross the Danube, throw ourselves on his line of communications,
      recross the river lower down, and frustrate his intention should he try to
      direct his whole force against our faithful ally. We shall therefore
      confidently await the moment when the Imperial Russian army will be fully
      equipped, and shall then, in conjunction with it, easily find a way to
      prepare for the enemy the fate he deserves.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov sighed deeply on finishing this paragraph and looked at the member
      of the Hofkriegsrath mildly and attentively.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But you know the wise maxim your excellency, advising one to expect the
      worst,&rdquo; said the Austrian general, evidently wishing to have done with
      jests and to come to business. He involuntarily looked round at the
      aide-de-camp.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Excuse me, General,&rdquo; interrupted Kutúzov, also turning to Prince Andrew.
      &ldquo;Look here, my dear fellow, get from Kozlóvski all the reports from our
      scouts. Here are two letters from Count Nostitz and here is one from His
      Highness the Archduke Ferdinand and here are these,&rdquo; he said, handing him
      several papers, &ldquo;make a neat memorandum in French out of all this, showing
      all the news we have had of the movements of the Austrian army, and then
      give it to his excellency.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew bowed his head in token of having understood from the first
      not only what had been said but also what Kutúzov would have liked to tell
      him. He gathered up the papers and with a bow to both, stepped softly over
      the carpet and went out into the waiting room.
    </p>
    <p>
      Though not much time had passed since Prince Andrew had left Russia, he
      had changed greatly during that period. In the expression of his face, in
      his movements, in his walk, scarcely a trace was left of his former
      affected languor and indolence. He now looked like a man who has time to
      think of the impression he makes on others, but is occupied with agreeable
      and interesting work. His face expressed more satisfaction with himself
      and those around him, his smile and glance were brighter and more
      attractive.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov, whom he had overtaken in Poland, had received him very kindly,
      promised not to forget him, distinguished him above the other adjutants,
      and had taken him to Vienna and given him the more serious commissions.
      From Vienna Kutúzov wrote to his old comrade, Prince Andrew&rsquo;s father.
    </p>
    <p>
      Your son bids fair to become an officer distinguished by his industry,
      firmness, and expedition. I consider myself fortunate to have such a
      subordinate by me.
    </p>
    <p>
      On Kutúzov&rsquo;s staff, among his fellow officers and in the army generally,
      Prince Andrew had, as he had had in Petersburg society, two quite opposite
      reputations. Some, a minority, acknowledged him to be different from
      themselves and from everyone else, expected great things of him, listened
      to him, admired, and imitated him, and with them Prince Andrew was natural
      and pleasant. Others, the majority, disliked him and considered him
      conceited, cold, and disagreeable. But among these people Prince Andrew
      knew how to take his stand so that they respected and even feared him.
    </p>
    <p>
      Coming out of Kutúzov&rsquo;s room into the waiting room with the papers in his
      hand Prince Andrew came up to his comrade, the aide-de-camp on duty,
      Kozlóvski, who was sitting at the window with a book.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, Prince?&rdquo; asked Kozlóvski.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am ordered to write a memorandum explaining why we are not advancing.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And why is it?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Any news from Mack?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If it were true that he has been beaten, news would have come.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Probably,&rdquo; said Prince Andrew moving toward the outer door.
    </p>
    <p>
      But at that instant a tall Austrian general in a greatcoat, with the order
      of Maria Theresa on his neck and a black bandage round his head, who had
      evidently just arrived, entered quickly, slamming the door. Prince Andrew
      stopped short.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Commander in Chief Kutúzov?&rdquo; said the newly arrived general speaking
      quickly with a harsh German accent, looking to both sides and advancing
      straight toward the inner door.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The commander in chief is engaged,&rdquo; said Kozlóvski, going hurriedly up to
      the unknown general and blocking his way to the door. &ldquo;Whom shall I
      announce?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The unknown general looked disdainfully down at Kozlóvski, who was rather
      short, as if surprised that anyone should not know him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The commander in chief is engaged,&rdquo; repeated Kozlóvski calmly.
    </p>
    <p>
      The general&rsquo;s face clouded, his lips quivered and trembled. He took out a
      notebook, hurriedly scribbled something in pencil, tore out the leaf, gave
      it to Kozlóvski, stepped quickly to the window, and threw himself into a
      chair, gazing at those in the room as if asking, &ldquo;Why do they look at me?&rdquo;
       Then he lifted his head, stretched his neck as if he intended to say
      something, but immediately, with affected indifference, began to hum to
      himself, producing a queer sound which immediately broke off. The door of
      the private room opened and Kutúzov appeared in the doorway. The general
      with the bandaged head bent forward as though running away from some
      danger, and, making long, quick strides with his thin legs, went up to
      Kutúzov.
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Vous voyez le malheureux Mack,&rdquo;</i> he uttered in a broken voice.
    </p>
    <p>
      Kutúzov&rsquo;s face as he stood in the open doorway remained perfectly immobile
      for a few moments. Then wrinkles ran over his face like a wave and his
      forehead became smooth again, he bowed his head respectfully, closed his
      eyes, silently let Mack enter his room before him, and closed the door
      himself behind him.
    </p>
    <p>
      The report which had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten
      and that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm proved to be correct.
      Within half an hour adjutants had been sent in various directions with
      orders which showed that the Russian troops, who had hitherto been
      inactive, would also soon have to meet the enemy.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew was one of those rare staff officers whose chief interest
      lay in the general progress of the war. When he saw Mack and heard the
      details of his disaster he understood that half the campaign was lost,
      understood all the difficulties of the Russian army&rsquo;s position, and
      vividly imagined what awaited it and the part he would have to play.
      Involuntarily he felt a joyful agitation at the thought of the humiliation
      of arrogant Austria and that in a week&rsquo;s time he might, perhaps, see and
      take part in the first Russian encounter with the French since Suvórov met
      them. He feared that Bonaparte&rsquo;s genius might outweigh all the courage of
      the Russian troops, and at the same time could not admit the idea of his
      hero being disgraced.
    </p>
    <p>
      Excited and irritated by these thoughts Prince Andrew went toward his room
      to write to his father, to whom he wrote every day. In the corridor he met
      Nesvítski, with whom he shared a room, and the wag Zherkóv; they were as
      usual laughing.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why are you so glum?&rdquo; asked Nesvítski noticing Prince Andrew&rsquo;s pale face
      and glittering eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There&rsquo;s nothing to be gay about,&rdquo; answered Bolkónski.
    </p>
    <p>
      Just as Prince Andrew met Nesvítski and Zherkóv, there came toward them
      from the other end of the corridor, Strauch, an Austrian general who was on
      Kutúzov&rsquo;s staff in charge of the provisioning of the Russian army, and the
      member of the Hofkriegsrath who had arrived the previous evening. There
      was room enough in the wide corridor for the generals to pass the three
      officers quite easily, but Zherkóv, pushing Nesvítski aside with his arm,
      said in a breathless voice,
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They&rsquo;re coming!... they&rsquo;re coming!... Stand aside, make way, please make
      way!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The generals were passing by, looking as if they wished to avoid
      embarrassing attentions. On the face of the wag Zherkóv there suddenly
      appeared a stupid smile of glee which he seemed unable to suppress.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Your excellency,&rdquo; said he in German, stepping forward and addressing the
      Austrian general, &ldquo;I have the honor to congratulate you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He bowed his head and scraped first with one foot and then with the other,
      awkwardly, like a child at a dancing lesson.
    </p>
    <p>
      The member of the Hofkriegsrath looked at him severely but, seeing the
      seriousness of his stupid smile, could not but give him a moment&rsquo;s
      attention. He screwed up his eyes showing that he was listening.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have the honor to congratulate you. General Mack has arrived, quite
      well, only a little bruised just here,&rdquo; he added, pointing with a beaming
      smile to his head.
    </p>
    <p>
      The general frowned, turned away, and went on.
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Gott, wie naiv!&rdquo;</i> * said he angrily, after he had gone a few steps.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * &ldquo;Good God, what simplicity!&rdquo;
 </p>
    <p>
      Nesvítski with a laugh threw his arms round Prince Andrew, but Bolkónski,
      turning still paler, pushed him away with an angry look and turned to
      Zherkóv. The nervous irritation aroused by the appearance of Mack, the
      news of his defeat, and the thought of what lay before the Russian army
      found vent in anger at Zherkóv&rsquo;s untimely jest.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If you, sir, choose to make a <i>buffoon</i> of yourself,&rdquo; he said
      sharply, with a slight trembling of the lower jaw, &ldquo;I can&rsquo;t prevent
      your doing so; but I warn you that if you <i>dare</i> to play the fool in my
      presence, I will teach you to behave yourself.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Nesvítski and Zherkóv were so surprised by this outburst that they gazed
      at Bolkónski silently with wide-open eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What&rsquo;s the matter? I only congratulated them,&rdquo; said Zherkóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am not jesting with you; please be silent!&rdquo; cried Bolkónski, and taking
      Nesvítski&rsquo;s arm he left Zherkóv, who did not know what to say.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come, what&rsquo;s the matter, old fellow?&rdquo; said Nesvítski trying to soothe
      him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What&rsquo;s the matter?&rdquo; exclaimed Prince Andrew standing still in
      his excitement. &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t you understand that either we are officers
      serving our Tsar and our country, rejoicing in the successes and grieving at the
      misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely lackeys who care nothing
      for their master&rsquo;s business. <i>Quarante mille hommes massacrés et l&rsquo;armée de
      nos alliés détruite, et vous trouvez là le mot pour rire,&rdquo;</i> * he said, as
      if strengthening his views by this French sentence. <i>&ldquo;C&rsquo;est bien pour un
      garçon de rien comme cet individu dont vous avez fait un ami, mais pas
      pour vous, pas pour vous</i>. *(2) Only a <i>hobbledehoy</i> could amuse himself in
      this way,&rdquo; he added in Russian&mdash;but pronouncing the word with a
      French accent&mdash;having noticed that Zherkóv could still hear him.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * &ldquo;Forty thousand men massacred and the army of our allies
     destroyed, and you find that a cause for jesting!&rdquo;
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * (2) &ldquo;It is all very well for that good-for-nothing fellow
     of whom you have made a friend, but not for you, not for
     you.&rdquo;
 </p>
    <p>
      He waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer, but he turned
      and went out of the corridor.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0032" id="link2HCH0032"></a>
      CHAPTER IV
    </h2>
    <p>
      The Pávlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. The squadron
      in which Nicholas Rostóv served as a cadet was quartered in the German
      village of Salzeneck. The best quarters in the village were assigned to
      cavalry-captain Denísov, the squadron commander, known throughout the
      whole cavalry division as Váska Denísov. Cadet Rostóv, ever since he had
      overtaken the regiment in Poland, had lived with the squadron commander.
    </p>
    <p>
      On October 11, the day when all was astir at headquarters over the news of
      Mack&rsquo;s defeat, the camp life of the officers of this squadron was
      proceeding as usual. Denísov, who had been losing at cards all night, had
      not yet come home when Rostóv rode back early in the morning from a
      foraging expedition. Rostóv in his cadet uniform, with a jerk to his
      horse, rode up to the porch, swung his leg over the saddle with a supple
      youthful movement, stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to part
      from his horse, and at last sprang down and called to his orderly.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, Bondarénko, dear friend!&rdquo; said he to the hussar who rushed up
      headlong to the horse. &ldquo;Walk him up and down, my dear fellow,&rdquo; he
      continued, with that gay brotherly cordiality which goodhearted young
      people show to everyone when they are happy.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, your excellency,&rdquo; answered the Ukrainian gaily, tossing his head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Mind, walk him up and down well!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Another hussar also rushed toward the horse, but Bondarénko had already
      thrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse&rsquo;s head. It was
      evident that the cadet was liberal with his tips and that it paid to serve
      him. Rostóv patted the horse&rsquo;s neck and then his flank, and lingered for a
      moment.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Splendid! What a horse he will be!&rdquo; he thought with a smile, and holding
      up his saber, his spurs jingling, he ran up the steps of the porch. His
      landlord, who in a waistcoat and a pointed cap, pitchfork in hand, was
      clearing manure from the cowhouse, looked out, and his face immediately
      brightened on seeing Rostóv. <i>&ldquo;Schön gut Morgen! Schön gut Morgen!&rdquo;</i> * he
      said winking with a merry smile, evidently pleased to greet the young man.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
    * &ldquo;A very good morning! A very good morning!&rdquo;
 </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Schon fleissig?&rdquo;</i> * said Rostóv with the same gay brotherly smile which
      did not leave his eager face. <i>&ldquo;Hoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen! Kaiser
      Alexander hoch!&rdquo;</i> *(2) said he, quoting words often repeated by the German
      landlord.
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
    * &ldquo;Busy already?&rdquo;
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
    * (2) &ldquo;Hurrah for the Austrians! Hurrah for the Russians!
     Hurrah for Emperor Alexander!&rdquo;
 </p>
    <p>
      The German laughed, came out of the cowshed, pulled off his cap, and
      waving it above his head cried:
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Und die ganze Welt hoch!&rdquo;</i> *
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
    * &ldquo;And hurrah for the whole world!&rdquo;
 </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv waved his cap above his head like the German and cried laughing,
      <i>&ldquo;Und vivat die ganze Welt!&rdquo;</i> Though neither the German cleaning his cowshed
      nor Rostóv back with his platoon from foraging for hay had any reason for
      rejoicing, they looked at each other with joyful delight and brotherly
      love, wagged their heads in token of their mutual affection, and parted
      smiling, the German returning to his cowshed and Rostóv going to the
      cottage he occupied with Denísov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What about your master?&rdquo; he asked Lavrúshka, Denísov&rsquo;s orderly, whom all
      the regiment knew for a rogue.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Hasn&rsquo;t been in since the evening. Must have been losing,&rdquo; answered
      Lavrúshka. &ldquo;I know by now, if he wins he comes back early to brag about
      it, but if he stays out till morning it means he&rsquo;s lost and will come back
      in a rage. Will you have coffee?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, bring some.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Ten minutes later Lavrúshka brought the coffee. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s coming!&rdquo; said he.
      &ldquo;Now for trouble!&rdquo; Rostóv looked out of the window and saw Denísov coming
      home. Denísov was a small man with a red face, sparkling black eyes, and
      black tousled mustache and hair. He wore an unfastened cloak, wide
      breeches hanging down in creases, and a crumpled shako on the back of his
      head. He came up to the porch gloomily, hanging his head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Lavwúska!&rdquo; he shouted loudly and angrily, &ldquo;take it off, blockhead!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, I am taking it off,&rdquo; replied Lavrúshka&rsquo;s voice.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, you&rsquo;re up already,&rdquo; said Denísov, entering the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Long ago,&rdquo; answered Rostóv, &ldquo;I have already been for the hay, and have
      seen Fräulein Mathilde.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Weally! And I&rsquo;ve been losing, bwother. I lost yesterday like a damned
      fool!&rdquo; cried Denísov, not pronouncing his <i>r</i>&rsquo;s. &ldquo;Such ill luck! Such ill
      luck. As soon as you left, it began and went on. Hullo there! Tea!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Puckering up his face though smiling, and showing his short strong teeth,
      he began with stubby fingers of both hands to ruffle up his thick tangled
      black hair.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And what devil made me go to that wat?&rdquo; (an officer nicknamed &ldquo;the rat&rdquo;)
      he said, rubbing his forehead and whole face with both hands. &ldquo;Just fancy,
      he didn&rsquo;t let me win a single cahd, not one cahd.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He took the lighted pipe that was offered to him, gripped it in his fist,
      and tapped it on the floor, making the sparks fly, while he continued to
      shout.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He lets one win the singles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it;
      gives the singles and snatches the doubles!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He scattered the burning tobacco, smashed the pipe, and threw it away.
      Then he remained silent for a while, and all at once looked cheerfully
      with his glittering, black eyes at Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If at least we had some women here; but there&rsquo;s nothing foh one to do but
      dwink. If we could only get to fighting soon. Hullo, who&rsquo;s there?&rdquo; he
      said, turning to the door as he heard a tread of heavy boots and the
      clinking of spurs that came to a stop, and a respectful cough.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The squadron quartermaster!&rdquo; said Lavrúshka.
    </p>
    <p>
      Denísov&rsquo;s face puckered still more.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wetched!&rdquo; he muttered, throwing down a purse with some gold in it.
      &ldquo;Wostóv, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the purse
      undah the pillow,&rdquo; he said, and went out to the quartermaster.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv took the money and, mechanically arranging the old and new coins in
      separate piles, began counting them.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah! Telyánin! How d&rsquo;ye do? They plucked me last night,&rdquo; came Denísov&rsquo;s
      voice from the next room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Where? At Bykov&rsquo;s, at the rat&rsquo;s... I knew it,&rdquo; replied a piping voice,
      and Lieutenant Telyánin, a small officer of the same squadron, entered the
      room.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv thrust the purse under the pillow and shook the damp little hand
      which was offered him. Telyánin for some reason had been transferred from
      the Guards just before this campaign. He behaved very well in the regiment
      but was not liked; Rostóv especially detested him and was unable to
      overcome or conceal his groundless antipathy to the man.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, young cavalryman, how is my Rook behaving?&rdquo; he asked. (Rook was a
      young horse Telyánin had sold to Rostóv.)
    </p>
    <p>
      The lieutenant never looked the man he was speaking to straight in the
      face; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I saw you riding this morning...&rdquo; he added.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, he&rsquo;s all right, a good horse,&rdquo; answered Rostóv, though the horse for
      which he had paid seven hundred rubbles was not worth half that sum. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s
      begun to go a little lame on the left foreleg,&rdquo; he added.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The hoof&rsquo;s cracked! That&rsquo;s nothing. I&rsquo;ll teach you what to do and show
      you what kind of rivet to use.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, please do,&rdquo; said Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll show you, I&rsquo;ll show you! It&rsquo;s not a secret. And it&rsquo;s a horse you&rsquo;ll
      thank me for.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Then I&rsquo;ll have it brought round,&rdquo; said Rostóv wishing to avoid Telyánin,
      and he went out to give the order.
    </p>
    <p>
      In the passage Denísov, with a pipe, was squatting on the threshold facing
      the quartermaster who was reporting to him. On seeing Rostóv, Denísov
      screwed up his face and pointing over his shoulder with his thumb to the
      room where Telyánin was sitting, he frowned and gave a shudder of disgust.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ugh! I don&rsquo;t like that fellow,&rdquo; he said, regardless of the
      quartermaster&rsquo;s presence.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv shrugged his shoulders as much as to say: &ldquo;Nor do I, but what&rsquo;s one
      to do?&rdquo; and, having given his order, he returned to Telyánin.
    </p>
    <p>
      Telyánin was sitting in the same indolent pose in which Rostóv had left
      him, rubbing his small white hands.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well there certainly are disgusting people,&rdquo; thought Rostóv as he
      entered.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Have you told them to bring the horse?&rdquo; asked Telyánin, getting up and
      looking carelessly about him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Let us go ourselves. I only came round to ask Denísov about yesterday&rsquo;s
      order. Have you got it, Denísov?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Not yet. But where are you off to?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I want to teach this young man how to shoe a horse,&rdquo; said Telyánin.
    </p>
    <p>
      They went through the porch and into the stable. The lieutenant explained
      how to rivet the hoof and went away to his own quarters.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Rostóv went back there was a bottle of vodka and a sausage on the
      table. Denísov was sitting there scratching with his pen on a sheet of
      paper. He looked gloomily in Rostóv&rsquo;s face and said: &ldquo;I am witing to her.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He leaned his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand and, evidently
      glad of a chance to say quicker in words what he wanted to write, told
      Rostóv the contents of his letter.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You see, my fwiend,&rdquo; he said, &ldquo;we sleep when we don&rsquo;t love. We are
      childwen of the dust... but one falls in love and one is a God, one is
