      pua&rsquo; as on the fihst day of cweation... Who&rsquo;s that now? Send him to the
      devil, I&rsquo;m busy!&rdquo; he shouted to Lavrúshka, who went up to him not in the
      least abashed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Who should it be? You yourself told him to come. It&rsquo;s the quartermaster
      for the money.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Denísov frowned and was about to shout some reply but stopped.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wetched business,&rdquo; he muttered to himself. &ldquo;How much is left in the
      puhse?&rdquo; he asked, turning to Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Seven new and three old imperials.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, it&rsquo;s wetched! Well, what are you standing there for, you sca&rsquo;cwow?
      Call the quahtehmasteh,&rdquo; he shouted to Lavrúshka.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Please, Denísov, let me lend you some: I have some, you know,&rdquo; said
      Rostóv, blushing.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t like bowwowing from my own fellows, I don&rsquo;t,&rdquo; growled Denísov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But if you won&rsquo;t accept money from me like a comrade, you will offend me.
      Really I have some,&rdquo; Rostóv repeated.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, I tell you.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And Denísov went to the bed to get the purse from under the pillow.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Where have you put it, Wostóv?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Under the lower pillow.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s not there.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Denísov threw both pillows on the floor. The purse was not there.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s a miwacle.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wait, haven&rsquo;t you dropped it?&rdquo; said Rostóv, picking up the pillows one at
      a time and shaking them.
    </p>
    <p>
      He pulled off the quilt and shook it. The purse was not there.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Dear me, can I have forgotten? No, I remember thinking that you kept it
      under your head like a treasure,&rdquo; said Rostóv. &ldquo;I put it just here. Where
      is it?&rdquo; he asked, turning to Lavrúshka.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I haven&rsquo;t been in the room. It must be where you put it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But it isn&rsquo;t?...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You&rsquo;re always like that; you thwow a thing down anywhere and forget it.
      Feel in your pockets.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, if I hadn&rsquo;t thought of it being a treasure,&rdquo; said Rostóv, &ldquo;but I
      remember putting it there.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Lavrúshka turned all the bedding over, looked under the bed and under the
      table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the room.
      Denísov silently watched Lavrúshka&rsquo;s movements, and when the latter threw
      up his arms in surprise saying it was nowhere to be found Denísov glanced
      at Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Wostóv, you&rsquo;ve not been playing schoolboy twicks...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv felt Denísov&rsquo;s gaze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and instantly
      dropped them again. All the blood which had seemed congested somewhere
      below his throat rushed to his face and eyes. He could not draw breath.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And there hasn&rsquo;t been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and
      yourselves. It must be here somewhere,&rdquo; said Lavrúshka.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now then, you devil&rsquo;s puppet, look alive and hunt for it!&rdquo; shouted
      Denísov, suddenly, turning purple and rushing at the man with a
      threatening gesture. &ldquo;If the purse isn&rsquo;t found I&rsquo;ll flog you, I&rsquo;ll flog
      you all.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv, his eyes avoiding Denísov, began buttoning his coat, buckled on
      his saber, and put on his cap.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I must have that purse, I tell you,&rdquo; shouted Denísov, shaking his orderly
      by the shoulders and knocking him against the wall.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Denísov, let him alone, I know who has taken it,&rdquo; said Rostóv, going
      toward the door without raising his eyes. Denísov paused, thought a
      moment, and, evidently understanding what Rostóv hinted at, seized his
      arm.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Nonsense!&rdquo; he cried, and the veins on his forehead and neck stood out
      like cords. &ldquo;You are mad, I tell you. I won&rsquo;t allow it. The purse is here!
      I&rsquo;ll flay this scoundwel alive, and it will be found.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know who has taken it,&rdquo; repeated Rostóv in an unsteady voice, and went
      to the door.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And I tell you, don&rsquo;t you dahe to do it!&rdquo; shouted Denísov, rushing at the
      cadet to restrain him.
    </p>
    <p>
      But Rostóv pulled away his arm and, with as much anger as though Denísov
      were his worst enemy, firmly fixed his eyes directly on his face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Do you understand what you&rsquo;re saying?&rdquo; he said in a trembling voice.
      &ldquo;There was no one else in the room except myself. So that if it is not so,
      then...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He could not finish, and ran out of the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, may the devil take you and evewybody,&rdquo; were the last words Rostóv
      heard.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv went to Telyánin&rsquo;s quarters.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The master is not in, he&rsquo;s gone to headquarters,&rdquo; said Telyánin&rsquo;s
      orderly. &ldquo;Has something happened?&rdquo; he added, surprised at the cadet&rsquo;s
      troubled face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, nothing.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You&rsquo;ve only just missed him,&rdquo; said the orderly.
    </p>
    <p>
      The headquarters were situated two miles away from Salzeneck, and Rostóv,
      without returning home, took a horse and rode there. There was an inn in
      the village which the officers frequented. Rostóv rode up to it and saw
      Telyánin&rsquo;s horse at the porch.
    </p>
    <p>
      In the second room of the inn the lieutenant was sitting over a dish of
      sausages and a bottle of wine.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, you&rsquo;ve come here too, young man!&rdquo; he said, smiling and raising his
      eyebrows.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes,&rdquo; said Rostóv as if it cost him a great deal to utter the word; and
      he sat down at the nearest table.
    </p>
    <p>
      Both were silent. There were two Germans and a Russian officer in the
      room. No one spoke and the only sounds heard were the clatter of knives
      and the munching of the lieutenant.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Telyánin had finished his lunch he took out of his pocket a double
      purse and, drawing its rings aside with his small, white, turned-up
      fingers, drew out a gold imperial, and lifting his eyebrows gave it to the
      waiter.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Please be quick,&rdquo; he said.
    </p>
    <p>
      The coin was a new one. Rostóv rose and went up to Telyánin.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Allow me to look at your purse,&rdquo; he said in a low, almost inaudible,
      voice.
    </p>
    <p>
      With shifting eyes but eyebrows still raised, Telyánin handed him the
      purse.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, it&rsquo;s a nice purse. Yes, yes,&rdquo; he said, growing suddenly pale, and
      added, &ldquo;Look at it, young man.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv took the purse in his hand, examined it and the money in it, and
      looked at Telyánin. The lieutenant was looking about in his usual way and
      suddenly seemed to grow very merry.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If we get to Vienna I&rsquo;ll get rid of it there but in these wretched little
      towns there&rsquo;s nowhere to spend it,&rdquo; said he. &ldquo;Well, let me have it, young
      man, I&rsquo;m going.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv did not speak.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And you? Are you going to have lunch too? They feed you quite decently
      here,&rdquo; continued Telyánin. &ldquo;Now then, let me have it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He stretched out his hand to take hold of the purse. Rostóv let go of it.
      Telyánin took the purse and began carelessly slipping it into the pocket
      of his riding breeches, with his eyebrows lifted and his mouth slightly
      open, as if to say, &ldquo;Yes, yes, I am putting my purse in my pocket and
      that&rsquo;s quite simple and is no one else&rsquo;s business.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, young man?&rdquo; he said with a sigh, and from under his lifted brows he
      glanced into Rostóv&rsquo;s eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      Some flash as of an electric spark shot from Telyánin&rsquo;s eyes to Rostóv&rsquo;s
      and back, and back again and again in an instant.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come here,&rdquo; said Rostóv, catching hold of Telyánin&rsquo;s arm and almost
      dragging him to the window. &ldquo;That money is Denísov&rsquo;s; you took it...&rdquo; he
      whispered just above Telyánin&rsquo;s ear.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What? What? How dare you? What?&rdquo; said Telyánin.
    </p>
    <p>
      But these words came like a piteous, despairing cry and an entreaty for
      pardon. As soon as Rostóv heard them, an enormous load of doubt fell from
      him. He was glad, and at the same instant began to pity the miserable man
      who stood before him, but the task he had begun had to be completed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Heaven only knows what the people here may imagine,&rdquo; muttered Telyánin,
      taking up his cap and moving toward a small empty room. &ldquo;We must have an
      explanation...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I know it and shall prove it,&rdquo; said Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Every muscle of Telyánin&rsquo;s pale, terrified face began to quiver, his eyes
      still shifted from side to side but with a downward look not rising to
      Rostóv&rsquo;s face, and his sobs were audible.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Count!... Don&rsquo;t ruin a young fellow... here is this wretched money, take
      it...&rdquo; He threw it on the table. &ldquo;I have an old father and mother!...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv took the money, avoiding Telyánin&rsquo;s eyes, and went out of the room
      without a word. But at the door he stopped and then retraced his steps. &ldquo;O
      God,&rdquo; he said with tears in his eyes, &ldquo;how could you do it?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Count...&rdquo; said Telyánin drawing nearer to him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t touch me,&rdquo; said Rostóv, drawing back. &ldquo;If you need it, take the
      money,&rdquo; and he threw the purse to him and ran out of the inn.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0033" id="link2HCH0033"></a>
      CHAPTER V
    </h2>
    <p>
      That same evening there was an animated discussion among the squadron&rsquo;s
      officers in Denísov&rsquo;s quarters.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And I tell you, Rostóv, that you must apologize to the colonel!&rdquo; said a
      tall, grizzly-haired staff captain, with enormous mustaches and many
      wrinkles on his large features, to Rostóv who was crimson with excitement.
    </p>
    <p>
      The staff captain, Kírsten, had twice been reduced to the ranks for
      affairs of honor and had twice regained his commission.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I will allow no one to call me a liar!&rdquo; cried Rostóv. &ldquo;He told me I lied,
      and I told him he lied. And there it rests. He may keep me on duty every
      day, or may place me under arrest, but no one can make me apologize,
      because if he, as commander of this regiment, thinks it beneath his
      dignity to give me satisfaction, then...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You just wait a moment, my dear fellow, and listen,&rdquo; interrupted the
      staff captain in his deep bass, calmly stroking his long mustache. &ldquo;You
      tell the colonel in the presence of other officers that an officer has
      stolen...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;m not to blame that the conversation began in the presence of other
      officers. Perhaps I ought not to have spoken before them, but I am not a
      diplomatist. That&rsquo;s why I joined the hussars, thinking that here one would
      not need finesse; and he tells me that I am lying&mdash;so let him give me
      satisfaction...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s all right. No one thinks you a coward, but that&rsquo;s not the point.
      Ask Denísov whether it is not out of the question for a cadet to demand
      satisfaction of his regimental commander?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Denísov sat gloomily biting his mustache and listening to the
      conversation, evidently with no wish to take part in it. He answered the
      staff captain&rsquo;s question by a disapproving shake of his head.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You speak to the colonel about this nasty business before other
      officers,&rdquo; continued the staff captain, &ldquo;and Bogdánich&rdquo; (the colonel was
      called Bogdánich) &ldquo;shuts you up.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He did not shut me up, he said I was telling an untruth.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, have it so, and you talked a lot of nonsense to him and must
      apologize.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Not on any account!&rdquo; exclaimed Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I did not expect this of you,&rdquo; said the staff captain seriously and
      severely. &ldquo;You don&rsquo;t wish to apologize, but, man, it&rsquo;s not only to him but
      to the whole regiment&mdash;all of us&mdash;you&rsquo;re to blame all round. The
      case is this: you ought to have thought the matter over and taken advice;
      but no, you go and blurt it all straight out before the officers. Now what
      was the colonel to do? Have the officer tried and disgrace the whole
      regiment? Disgrace the whole regiment because of one scoundrel? Is that
      how you look at it? We don&rsquo;t see it like that. And Bogdánich was a brick:
      he told you you were saying what was not true. It&rsquo;s not pleasant, but
      what&rsquo;s to be done, my dear fellow? You landed yourself in it. And now,
      when one wants to smooth the thing over, some conceit prevents your
      apologizing, and you wish to make the whole affair public. You are
      offended at being put on duty a bit, but why not apologize to an old and
      honorable officer? Whatever Bogdánich may be, anyway he is an honorable
      and brave old colonel! You&rsquo;re quick at taking offense, but you don&rsquo;t mind
      disgracing the whole regiment!&rdquo; The staff captain&rsquo;s voice began to
      tremble. &ldquo;You have been in the regiment next to no time, my lad, you&rsquo;re
      here today and tomorrow you&rsquo;ll be appointed adjutant somewhere and can
      snap your fingers when it is said &lsquo;There are thieves among the Pávlograd
      officers!&rsquo; But it&rsquo;s not all the same to us! Am I not right, Denísov? It&rsquo;s
      not the same!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Denísov remained silent and did not move, but occasionally looked with his
      glittering black eyes at Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You value your own pride and don&rsquo;t wish to apologize,&rdquo; continued the
      staff captain, &ldquo;but we old fellows, who have grown up in and, God willing,
      are going to die in the regiment, we prize the honor of the regiment, and
      Bogdánich knows it. Oh, we do prize it, old fellow! And all this is not
      right, it&rsquo;s not right! You may take offense or not but I always stick to
      mother truth. It&rsquo;s not right!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And the staff captain rose and turned away from Rostóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s twue, devil take it!&rdquo; shouted Denísov, jumping up. &ldquo;Now then,
      Wostóv, now then!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv, growing red and pale alternately, looked first at one
      officer and then at the other.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, gentlemen, no... you mustn&rsquo;t think... I quite understand. You&rsquo;re
      wrong to think that of me... I... for me... for the honor of the regiment
      I&rsquo;d... Ah well, I&rsquo;ll show that in action, and for me the honor of the
      flag... Well, never mind, it&rsquo;s true I&rsquo;m to blame, to blame all round.
      Well, what else do you want?...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Come, that&rsquo;s right, Count!&rdquo; cried the staff captain, turning round and
      clapping Rostóv on the shoulder with his big hand.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I tell you,&rdquo; shouted Denísov, &ldquo;he&rsquo;s a fine fellow.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s better, Count,&rdquo; said the staff captain, beginning to address
      Rostóv by his title, as if in recognition of his confession. &ldquo;Go and
      apologize, your excellency. Yes, go!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Gentlemen, I&rsquo;ll do anything. No one shall hear a word from me,&rdquo; said
      Rostóv in an imploring voice, &ldquo;but I can&rsquo;t apologize, by God I can&rsquo;t, do
      what you will! How can I go and apologize like a little boy asking
      forgiveness?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Denísov began to laugh.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;ll be worse for you. Bogdánich is vindictive and you&rsquo;ll pay for your
      obstinacy,&rdquo; said Kírsten.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;No, on my word it&rsquo;s not obstinacy! I can&rsquo;t describe the feeling. I
      can&rsquo;t...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, it&rsquo;s as you like,&rdquo; said the staff captain. &ldquo;And what has become of
      that scoundrel?&rdquo; he asked Denísov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He has weported himself sick, he&rsquo;s to be stwuck off the list tomowwow,&rdquo;
       muttered Denísov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It is an illness, there&rsquo;s no other way of explaining it,&rdquo; said the staff
      captain.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Illness or not, he&rsquo;d better not cwoss my path. I&rsquo;d kill him!&rdquo; shouted
      Denísov in a bloodthirsty tone.
    </p>
    <p>
      Just then Zherkóv entered the room.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What brings you here?&rdquo; cried the officers turning to the newcomer.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We&rsquo;re to go into action, gentlemen! Mack has surrendered with his whole
      army.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s not true!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve seen him myself!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What? Saw the real Mack? With hands and feet?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Into action! Into action! Bring him a bottle for such news! But how did
      you come here?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ve been sent back to the regiment all on account of that devil, Mack.
      An Austrian general complained of me. I congratulated him on Mack&rsquo;s
      arrival... What&rsquo;s the matter, Rostóv? You look as if you&rsquo;d just come out
      of a hot bath.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, my dear fellow, we&rsquo;re in such a stew here these last two days.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The regimental adjutant came in and confirmed the news brought by Zherkóv.
      They were under orders to advance next day.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;We&rsquo;re going into action, gentlemen!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, thank God! We&rsquo;ve been sitting here too long!&rdquo;
     </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0034" id="link2HCH0034"></a>
      CHAPTER VI
    </h2>
    <p>
      Kutúzov fell back toward Vienna, destroying behind him the bridges over
      the rivers Inn (at Braunau) and Traun (near Linz). On October 23 the
      Russian troops were crossing the river Enns. At midday the Russian baggage
      train, the artillery, and columns of troops were defiling through the town
      of Enns on both sides of the bridge.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was a warm, rainy, autumnal day. The wide expanse that opened out
      before the heights on which the Russian batteries stood guarding the
      bridge was at times veiled by a diaphanous curtain of slanting rain, and
      then, suddenly spread out in the sunlight, far-distant objects could be
      clearly seen glittering as though freshly varnished. Down below, the
      little town could be seen with its white, red-roofed houses, its
      cathedral, and its bridge, on both sides of which streamed jostling masses
      of Russian troops. At the bend of the Danube, vessels, an island, and a
      castle with a park surrounded by the waters of the confluence of the Enns
      and the Danube became visible, and the rocky left bank of the Danube
      covered with pine forests, with a mystic background of green treetops and
      bluish gorges. The turrets of a convent stood out beyond a wild virgin
      pine forest, and far away on the other side of the Enns the enemy&rsquo;s horse
      patrols could be discerned.
    </p>
    <p>
      Among the field guns on the brow of the hill the general in command of the
      rearguard stood with a staff officer, scanning the country through his
      fieldglass. A little behind them Nesvítski, who had been sent to the
      rearguard by the commander in chief, was sitting on the trail of a gun
      carriage. A Cossack who accompanied him had handed him a knapsack and a
      flask, and Nesvítski was treating some officers to pies and real
      <i>doppelkümmel</i>. The officers gladly gathered round him, some on their knees,
      some squatting Turkish fashion on the wet grass.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, the Austrian prince who built that castle was no fool. It&rsquo;s a fine
      place! Why are you not eating anything, gentlemen?&rdquo; Nesvítski was saying.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Thank you very much, Prince,&rdquo; answered one of the officers, pleased to be
      talking to a staff officer of such importance. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a lovely place! We
      passed close to the park and saw two deer... and what a splendid house!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Look, Prince,&rdquo; said another, who would have dearly liked to take another
      pie but felt shy, and therefore pretended to be examining the countryside&mdash;&ldquo;See,
      our infantrymen have already got there. Look there in the meadow behind
      the village, three of them are dragging something. They&rsquo;ll ransack that
      castle,&rdquo; he remarked with evident approval.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;So they will,&rdquo; said Nesvítski. &ldquo;No, but what I should like,&rdquo; added he,
      munching a pie in his moist-lipped handsome mouth, &ldquo;would be to slip in
      over there.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He pointed with a smile to a turreted nunnery, and his eyes narrowed and
      gleamed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That would be fine, gentlemen!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The officers laughed.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Just to flutter the nuns a bit. They say there are Italian girls among
      them. On my word I&rsquo;d give five years of my life for it!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They must be feeling dull, too,&rdquo; said one of the bolder officers,
      laughing.
    </p>
    <p>
      Meanwhile the staff officer standing in front pointed out something to the
      general, who looked through his field glass.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, so it is, so it is,&rdquo; said the general angrily, lowering the field
      glass and shrugging his shoulders, &ldquo;so it is! They&rsquo;ll be fired on at the
      crossing. And why are they dawdling there?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      On the opposite side the enemy could be seen by the naked eye, and from
      their battery a milk-white cloud arose. Then came the distant report of a
      shot, and our troops could be seen hurrying to the crossing.
    </p>
    <p>
      Nesvítski rose, puffing, and went up to the general, smiling.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Would not your excellency like a little refreshment?&rdquo; he said.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a bad business,&rdquo; said the general without answering him, &ldquo;our men
      have been wasting time.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Hadn&rsquo;t I better ride over, your excellency?&rdquo; asked Nesvítski.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, please do,&rdquo; answered the general, and he repeated the order that had
      already once been given in detail: &ldquo;and tell the hussars that they are to
      cross last and to fire the bridge as I ordered; and the inflammable
      material on the bridge must be reinspected.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Very good,&rdquo; answered Nesvítski.
    </p>
    <p>
      He called the Cossack with his horse, told him to put away the knapsack
      and flask, and swung his heavy person easily into the saddle.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;ll really call in on the nuns,&rdquo; he said to the officers who watched him
      smilingly, and he rode off by the winding path down the hill.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Now then, let&rsquo;s see how far it will carry, Captain. Just try!&rdquo; said the
      general, turning to an artillery officer. &ldquo;Have a little fun to pass the
      time.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Crew, to your guns!&rdquo; commanded the officer.
    </p>
    <p>
      In a moment the men came running gaily from their campfires and began
      loading.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;One!&rdquo; came the command.
    </p>
    <p>
      Number one jumped briskly aside. The gun rang out with a deafening
      metallic roar, and a whistling grenade flew above the heads of our troops
      below the hill and fell far short of the enemy, a little smoke showing the
      spot where it burst.
    </p>
    <p>
      The faces of officers and men brightened up at the sound. Everyone got up
      and began watching the movements of our troops below, as plainly visible
      as if but a stone&rsquo;s throw away, and the movements of the approaching enemy
      farther off. At the same instant the sun came fully out from behind the
      clouds, and the clear sound of the solitary shot and the brilliance of the
      bright sunshine merged in a single joyous and spirited impression.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0035" id="link2HCH0035"></a>
      CHAPTER VII
    </h2>
    <p>
      Two of the enemy&rsquo;s shots had already flown across the bridge, where there
      was a crush. Halfway across stood Prince Nesvítski, who had alighted from
      his horse and whose big body was jammed against the railings. He looked
      back laughing to the Cossack who stood a few steps behind him holding two
      horses by their bridles. Each time Prince Nesvítski tried to move on,
      soldiers and carts pushed him back again and pressed him against the
      railings, and all he could do was to smile.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a fine fellow you are, friend!&rdquo; said the Cossack to a convoy soldier
      with a wagon, who was pressing onto the infantrymen who were crowded
      together close to his wheels and his horses. &ldquo;What a fellow! You can&rsquo;t
      wait a moment! Don&rsquo;t you see the general wants to pass?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      But the convoyman took no notice of the word &ldquo;general&rdquo; and shouted at the
      soldiers who were blocking his way. &ldquo;Hi there, boys! Keep to the left!
      Wait a bit.&rdquo; But the soldiers, crowded together shoulder to shoulder,
      their bayonets interlocking, moved over the bridge in a dense mass.
      Looking down over the rails Prince Nesvítski saw the rapid, noisy little
      waves of the Enns, which rippling and eddying round the piles of the
      bridge chased each other along. Looking on the bridge he saw equally
      uniform living waves of soldiers, shoulder straps, covered shakos,
      knapsacks, bayonets, long muskets, and, under the shakos, faces with broad
      cheekbones, sunken cheeks, and listless tired expressions, and feet that
      moved through the sticky mud that covered the planks of the bridge.
      Sometimes through the monotonous waves of men, like a fleck of white foam
      on the waves of the Enns, an officer, in a cloak and with a type of face
      different from that of the men, squeezed his way along; sometimes like a
      chip of wood whirling in the river, an hussar on foot, an orderly, or a
      townsman was carried through the waves of infantry; and sometimes like a
      log floating down the river, an officers&rsquo; or company&rsquo;s baggage wagon,
      piled high, leather covered, and hemmed in on all sides, moved across the
      bridge.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s as if a dam had burst,&rdquo; said the Cossack hopelessly. &ldquo;Are there many
      more of you to come?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;A million all but one!&rdquo; replied a waggish soldier in a torn coat, with a
      wink, and passed on followed by another, an old man.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If <i>he</i>&rdquo; (<i>he</i> meant the enemy) &ldquo;begins popping at the bridge now,&rdquo; said the
      old soldier dismally to a comrade, &ldquo;you&rsquo;ll forget to scratch yourself.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      That soldier passed on, and after him came another sitting on a cart.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Where the devil have the leg bands been shoved to?&rdquo; said an orderly,
      running behind the cart and fumbling in the back of it.
    </p>
    <p>
      And he also passed on with the wagon. Then came some merry soldiers who
      had evidently been drinking.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And then, old fellow, he gives him one in the teeth with the butt end of
      his gun...&rdquo; a soldier whose greatcoat was well tucked up said gaily, with
      a wide swing of his arm.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes, the ham was just delicious...&rdquo; answered another with a loud laugh.
      And they, too, passed on, so that Nesvítski did not learn who had been
      struck on the teeth, or what the ham had to do with it.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Bah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they&rsquo;ll all be
      killed,&rdquo; a sergeant was saying angrily and reproachfully.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;As it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean,&rdquo; said a young soldier with
      an enormous mouth, hardly refraining from laughing, &ldquo;I felt like dying of
      fright. I did, &lsquo;pon my word, I got that frightened!&rdquo; said he, as if
      bragging of having been frightened.
    </p>
    <p>
      That one also passed. Then followed a cart unlike any that had gone
      before. It was a German cart with a pair of horses led by a German, and
      seemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects. A fine brindled cow with a
      large udder was attached to the cart behind. A woman with an unweaned
      baby, an old woman, and a healthy German girl with bright red cheeks were
      sitting on some feather beds. Evidently these fugitives were allowed to
      pass by special permission. The eyes of all the soldiers turned toward the
      women, and while the vehicle was passing at foot pace all the soldiers&rsquo;
      remarks related to the two young ones. Every face bore almost the same
      smile, expressing unseemly thoughts about the women.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Just see, the German sausage is making tracks, too!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Sell me the missis,&rdquo; said another soldier, addressing the German, who,
      angry and frightened, strode energetically along with downcast eyes.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;See how smart she&rsquo;s made herself! Oh, the devils!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There, Fedótov, you should be quartered on them!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I have seen as much before now, mate!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Where are you going?&rdquo; asked an infantry officer who was eating an apple,
      also half smiling as he looked at the handsome girl.
    </p>
    <p>
      The German closed his eyes, signifying that he did not understand.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Take it if you like,&rdquo; said the officer, giving the girl an apple.
    </p>
    <p>
      The girl smiled and took it. Nesvítski like the rest of the men on the
      bridge did not take his eyes off the women till they had passed. When they
      had gone by, the same stream of soldiers followed, with the same kind of
      talk, and at last all stopped. As often happens, the horses of a convoy
      wagon became restive at the end of the bridge, and the whole crowd had to
      wait.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And why are they stopping? There&rsquo;s no proper order!&rdquo; said the soldiers.
      &ldquo;Where are you shoving to? Devil take you! Can&rsquo;t you wait? It&rsquo;ll be worse
      if he fires the bridge. See, here&rsquo;s an officer jammed in too&rdquo;&mdash;different
      voices were saying in the crowd, as the men looked at one another, and all
      pressed toward the exit from the bridge.
    </p>
    <p>
      Looking down at the waters of the Enns under the bridge, Nesvítski
      suddenly heard a sound new to him, of something swiftly approaching...
      something big, that splashed into the water.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Just see where it carries to!&rdquo; a soldier near by said sternly, looking
      round at the sound.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Encouraging us to get along quicker,&rdquo; said another uneasily.
    </p>
    <p>
      The crowd moved on again. Nesvítski realized that it was a cannon ball.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Hey, Cossack, my horse!&rdquo; he said. &ldquo;Now, then, you there! get out of the
      way! Make way!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      With great difficulty he managed to get to his horse, and shouting
      continually he moved on. The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way for
      him, but again pressed on him so that they jammed his leg, and those
      nearest him were not to blame for they were themselves pressed still
      harder from behind.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Nesvítski, Nesvítski! you numskull!&rdquo; came a hoarse voice from behind him.
    </p>
    <p>
      Nesvítski looked round and saw, some fifteen paces away but separated by
      the living mass of moving infantry, Váska Denísov, red and shaggy, with
      his cap on the back of his black head and a cloak hanging jauntily over
      his shoulder.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Tell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!&rdquo; shouted Denísov
      evidently in a fit of rage, his coal-black eyes with their bloodshot
      whites glittering and rolling as he waved his sheathed saber in a small
      bare hand as red as his face.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, Váska!&rdquo; joyfully replied Nesvítski. &ldquo;What&rsquo;s up with you?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The squadwon can&rsquo;t pass,&rdquo; shouted Váska Denísov, showing his white teeth
      fiercely and spurring his black thoroughbred Arab, which twitched its ears
      as the bayonets touched it, and snorted, spurting white foam from his bit,
      tramping the planks of the bridge with his hoofs, and apparently ready to
      jump over the railings had his rider let him. &ldquo;What is this? They&rsquo;re like
      sheep! Just like sheep! Out of the way!... Let us pass!... Stop there, you
      devil with the cart! I&rsquo;ll hack you with my saber!&rdquo; he shouted, actually
      drawing his saber from its scabbard and flourishing it.
    </p>
    <p>
      The soldiers crowded against one another with terrified faces, and Denísov
      joined Nesvítski.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How&rsquo;s it you&rsquo;re not drunk today?&rdquo; said Nesvítski when the other had
      ridden up to him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They don&rsquo;t even give one time to dwink!&rdquo; answered Váska Denísov. &ldquo;They
      keep dwagging the wegiment to and fwo all day. If they mean to fight,
      let&rsquo;s fight. But the devil knows what this is.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What a dandy you are today!&rdquo; said Nesvítski, looking at Denísov&rsquo;s new
      cloak and saddlecloth.
    </p>
    <p>
      Denísov smiled, took out of his sabretache a handkerchief that diffused a
      smell of perfume, and put it to Nesvítski&rsquo;s nose.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Of course. I&rsquo;m going into action! I&rsquo;ve shaved, bwushed my teeth, and
      scented myself.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The imposing figure of Nesvítski followed by his Cossack, and the
      determination of Denísov who flourished his sword and shouted frantically,
      had such an effect that they managed to squeeze through to the farther
      side of the bridge and stopped the infantry. Beside the bridge Nesvítski
      found the colonel to whom he had to deliver the order, and having done
      this he rode back.
    </p>
    <p>
      Having cleared the way Denísov stopped at the end of the bridge.
      Carelessly holding in his stallion that was neighing and pawing the
      ground, eager to rejoin its fellows, he watched his squadron draw nearer.
      Then the clang of hoofs, as of several horses galloping, resounded on the
      planks of the bridge, and the squadron, officers in front and men four
      abreast, spread across the bridge and began to emerge on his side of it.
    </p>
    <p>
      The infantry who had been stopped crowded near the bridge in the trampled
      mud and gazed with that particular feeling of ill-will, estrangement, and
      ridicule with which troops of different arms usually encounter one another
      at the clean, smart hussars who moved past them in regular order.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Smart lads! Only fit for a fair!&rdquo; said one.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What good are they? They&rsquo;re led about just for show!&rdquo; remarked another.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t kick up the dust, you infantry!&rdquo; jested an hussar whose prancing
      horse had splashed mud over some foot soldiers.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I&rsquo;d like to put you on a two days&rsquo; march with a knapsack! Your fine cords
      would soon get a bit rubbed,&rdquo; said an infantryman, wiping the mud off his
      face with his sleeve. &ldquo;Perched up there, you&rsquo;re more like a bird than a
      man.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There now, Zíkin, they ought to put you on a horse. You&rsquo;d look fine,&rdquo;
       said a corporal, chaffing a thin little soldier who bent under the weight
      of his knapsack.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Take a stick between your legs, that&rsquo;ll suit you for a horse!&rdquo; the hussar
      shouted back.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0036" id="link2HCH0036"></a>
      CHAPTER VIII
    </h2>
    <p>
      The last of the infantry hurriedly crossed the bridge, squeezing together
      as they approached it as if passing through a funnel. At last the baggage
      wagons had all crossed, the crush was less, and the last battalion came
      onto the bridge. Only Denísov&rsquo;s squadron of hussars remained on the
      farther side of the bridge facing the enemy, who could be seen from the
      hill on the opposite bank but was not yet visible from the bridge, for the
      horizon as seen from the valley through which the river flowed was formed
      by the rising ground only half a mile away. At the foot of the hill lay
      wasteland over which a few groups of our Cossack scouts were moving.
      Suddenly on the road at the top of the high ground, artillery and troops
      in blue uniform were seen. These were the French. A group of Cossack
      scouts retired down the hill at a trot. All the officers and men of
      Denísov&rsquo;s squadron, though they tried to talk of other things and to look
      in other directions, thought only of what was there on the hilltop, and
      kept constantly looking at the patches appearing on the skyline, which
      they knew to be the enemy&rsquo;s troops. The weather had cleared again since
      noon and the sun was descending brightly upon the Danube and the dark
      hills around it. It was calm, and at intervals the bugle calls and the
      shouts of the enemy could be heard from the hill. There was no one now
      between the squadron and the enemy except a few scattered skirmishers. An
      empty space of some seven hundred yards was all that separated them. The
      enemy ceased firing, and that stern, threatening, inaccessible, and
      intangible line which separates two hostile armies was all the more
      clearly felt.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;One step beyond that boundary line which resembles the line dividing the
      living from the dead lies uncertainty, suffering, and death. And what is
      there? Who is there?&mdash;there beyond that field, that tree, that roof
      lit up by the sun? No one knows, but one wants to know. You fear and yet
      long to cross that line, and know that sooner or later it must be crossed
      and you will have to find out what is there, just as you will inevitably
      have to learn what lies the other side of death. But you are strong,
      healthy, cheerful, and excited, and are surrounded by other such excitedly
      animated and healthy men.&rdquo; So thinks, or at any rate feels, anyone who
      comes in sight of the enemy, and that feeling gives a particular glamour
      and glad keenness of impression to everything that takes place at such
      moments.
    </p>
    <p>
      On the high ground where the enemy was, the smoke of a cannon rose, and a
      ball flew whistling over the heads of the hussar squadron. The officers
      who had been standing together rode off to their places. The hussars began
      carefully aligning their horses. Silence fell on the whole squadron. All
      were looking at the enemy in front and at the squadron commander, awaiting
      the word of command. A second and a third cannon ball flew past. Evidently
      they were firing at the hussars, but the balls with rapid rhythmic whistle
      flew over the heads of the horsemen and fell somewhere beyond them. The
      hussars did not look round, but at the sound of each shot, as at the word
      of command, the whole squadron with its rows of faces so alike yet so
      different, holding its breath while the ball flew past, rose in the
      stirrups and sank back again. The soldiers without turning their heads
      glanced at one another, curious to see their comrades&rsquo; impression. Every
      face, from Denísov&rsquo;s to that of the bugler, showed one common expression
      of conflict, irritation, and excitement, around chin and mouth. The
      quartermaster frowned, looking at the soldiers as if threatening to punish
      them. Cadet Mirónov ducked every time a ball flew past. Rostóv on the left
      flank, mounted on his Rook&mdash;a handsome horse despite its game leg&mdash;had
      the happy air of a schoolboy called up before a large audience for an
      examination in which he feels sure he will distinguish himself. He was
      glancing at everyone with a clear, bright expression, as if asking them to
      notice how calmly he sat under fire. But despite himself, on his face too
      that same indication of something new and stern showed round the mouth.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Who&rsquo;s that curtseying there? Cadet Miwónov! That&rsquo;s not wight! Look at
      me,&rdquo; cried Denísov who, unable to keep still on one spot, kept turning his
      horse in front of the squadron.
    </p>
    <p>
      The black, hairy, snub-nosed face of Váska Denísov, and his whole short
      sturdy figure with the sinewy hairy hand and stumpy fingers in which he
      held the hilt of his naked saber, looked just as it usually did,
      especially toward evening when he had emptied his second bottle; he was
      only redder than usual. With his shaggy head thrown back like birds when
      they drink, pressing his spurs mercilessly into the sides of his good
      horse, Bedouin, and sitting as though falling backwards in the saddle, he
      galloped to the other flank of the squadron and shouted in a hoarse voice
      to the men to look to their pistols. He rode up to Kírsten. The staff
      captain on his broad-backed, steady mare came at a walk to meet him. His
      face with its long mustache was serious as always, only his eyes were
      brighter than usual.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, what about it?&rdquo; said he to Denísov. &ldquo;It won&rsquo;t come to a fight.
      You&rsquo;ll see&mdash;we shall retire.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;The devil only knows what they&rsquo;re about!&rdquo; muttered Denísov. &ldquo;Ah, Wostóv,&rdquo;
       he cried noticing the cadet&rsquo;s bright face, &ldquo;you&rsquo;ve got it at last.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And he smiled approvingly, evidently pleased with the cadet. Rostóv felt
      perfectly happy. Just then the commander appeared on the bridge. Denísov
      galloped up to him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Your excellency! Let us attack them! I&rsquo;ll dwive them off.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Attack indeed!&rdquo; said the colonel in a bored voice, puckering up his face
      as if driving off a troublesome fly. &ldquo;And why are you stopping here? Don&rsquo;t
      you see the skirmishers are retreating? Lead the squadron back.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The squadron crossed the bridge and drew out of range of fire without
      having lost a single man. The second squadron that had been in the front
      line followed them across and the last Cossacks quitted the farther side
      of the river.
    </p>
    <p>
      The two Pávlograd squadrons, having crossed the bridge, retired up the
      hill one after the other. Their colonel, Karl Bogdánich Schubert, came up
      to Denísov&rsquo;s squadron and rode at a footpace not far from Rostóv, without
      taking any notice of him although they were now meeting for the first time
      since their encounter concerning Telyánin. Rostóv, feeling that he was at
      the front and in the power of a man toward whom he now admitted that he
      had been to blame, did not lift his eyes from the colonel&rsquo;s athletic back,
      his nape covered with light hair, and his red neck. It seemed to Rostóv
      that Bogdánich was only pretending not to notice him, and that his whole
      aim now was to test the cadet&rsquo;s courage, so he drew himself up and looked
      around him merrily; then it seemed to him that Bogdánich rode so near in
      order to show him his courage. Next he thought that his enemy would send
      the squadron on a desperate attack just to punish him&mdash;Rostóv. Then
      he imagined how, after the attack, Bogdánich would come up to him as he
      lay wounded and would magnanimously extend the hand of reconciliation.
    </p>
    <p>
      The high-shouldered figure of Zherkóv, familiar to the Pávlograds as he
      had but recently left their regiment, rode up to the colonel. After his
      dismissal from headquarters Zherkóv had not remained in the regiment,
      saying he was not such a fool as to slave at the front when he could get
      more rewards by doing nothing on the staff, and had succeeded in attaching
      himself as an orderly officer to Prince Bagratión. He now came to his
      former chief with an order from the commander of the rear guard.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Colonel,&rdquo; he said, addressing Rostóv&rsquo;s enemy with an air of gloomy
      gravity and glancing round at his comrades, &ldquo;there is an order to stop and
      fire the bridge.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;An order to who?&rdquo; asked the colonel morosely.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t myself know &lsquo;to who,&rsquo;&rdquo; replied the cornet in a serious tone, &ldquo;but
      the prince told me to &lsquo;go and tell the colonel that the hussars must
      return quickly and fire the bridge.&rsquo;&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Zherkóv was followed by an officer of the suite who rode up to the colonel
      of hussars with the same order. After him the stout Nesvítski came
      galloping up on a Cossack horse that could scarcely carry his weight.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;How&rsquo;s this, Colonel?&rdquo; he shouted as he approached. &ldquo;I told you to fire
      the bridge, and now someone has gone and blundered; they are all beside
      themselves over there and one can&rsquo;t make anything out.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The colonel deliberately stopped the regiment and turned to Nesvítski.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You spoke to me of inflammable material,&rdquo; said he, &ldquo;but you said nothing
      about firing it.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;But, my dear sir,&rdquo; said Nesvítski as he drew up, taking off his cap and
      smoothing his hair wet with perspiration with his plump hand, &ldquo;wasn&rsquo;t I
      telling you to fire the bridge, when inflammable material had been put in
      position?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I am not your &lsquo;dear sir,&rsquo; Mr. Staff Officer, and you did not tell me to
      burn the bridge! I know the service, and it is my habit orders strictly to
      obey. You said the bridge would be burned, but who would burn it, I could
      not know by the holy spirit!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, that&rsquo;s always the way!&rdquo; said Nesvítski with a wave of the hand. &ldquo;How
      did you get here?&rdquo; said he, turning to Zherkóv.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;On the same business. But you <i>are</i> damp! Let me wring you out!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;You were saying, Mr. Staff Officer...&rdquo; continued the colonel in an
      offended tone.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Colonel,&rdquo; interrupted the officer of the suite, &ldquo;You must be quick or the
      enemy will bring up his guns to use grapeshot.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The colonel looked silently at the officer of the suite, at the stout
      staff officer, and at Zherkóv, and he frowned.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;I will the bridge fire,&rdquo; he said in a solemn tone as if to announce that
      in spite of all the unpleasantness he had to endure he would still do the
      right thing.
    </p>
    <p>
      Striking his horse with his long muscular legs as if it were to blame for
      everything, the colonel moved forward and ordered the second squadron,
      that in which Rostóv was serving under Denísov, to return to the bridge.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There, it&rsquo;s just as I thought,&rdquo; said Rostóv to himself. &ldquo;He wishes to
      test me!&rdquo; His heart contracted and the blood rushed to his face. &ldquo;Let him
      see whether I am a coward!&rdquo; he thought.
    </p>
    <p>
      Again on all the bright faces of the squadron the serious expression
      appeared that they had worn when under fire. Rostóv watched his enemy, the
      colonel, closely&mdash;to find in his face confirmation of his own
      conjecture, but the colonel did not once glance at Rostóv, and looked as
      he always did when at the front, solemn and stern. Then came the word of
      command.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Look sharp! Look sharp!&rdquo; several voices repeated around him.
    </p>
    <p>
      Their sabers catching in the bridles and their spurs jingling, the hussars
      hastily dismounted, not knowing what they were to do. The men were
      crossing themselves. Rostóv no longer looked at the colonel, he had no
      time. He was afraid of falling behind the hussars, so much afraid that his
      heart stood still. His hand trembled as he gave his horse into an
      orderly&rsquo;s charge, and he felt the blood rush to his heart with a thud.
      Denísov rode past him, leaning back and shouting something. Rostóv saw
      nothing but the hussars running all around him, their spurs catching and
      their sabers clattering.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Stretchers!&rdquo; shouted someone behind him.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv did not think what this call for stretchers meant; he ran on,
      trying only to be ahead of the others; but just at the bridge, not looking
      at the ground, he came on some sticky, trodden mud, stumbled, and fell on
      his hands. The others outstripped him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;At boss zides, Captain,&rdquo; he heard the voice of the colonel, who, having
      ridden ahead, had pulled up his horse near the bridge, with a triumphant,
      cheerful face.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv wiping his muddy hands on his breeches looked at his enemy and was
      about to run on, thinking that the farther he went to the front the
      better. But Bogdánich, without looking at or recognizing Rostóv, shouted
      to him:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Who&rsquo;s that running on the middle of the bridge? To the right! Come back,
      Cadet!&rdquo; he cried angrily; and turning to Denísov, who, showing off his
      courage, had ridden on to the planks of the bridge:
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Why run risks, Captain? You should dismount,&rdquo; he said.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, every bullet has its billet,&rdquo; answered Váska Denísov, turning in his
      saddle.
    </p>
    <p>
      <br />
    </p>
    <p>
      Meanwhile Nesvítski, Zherkóv, and the officer of the suite were standing
      together out of range of the shots, watching, now the small group of men
      with yellow shakos, dark-green jackets braided with cord, and blue riding
      breeches, who were swarming near the bridge, and then at what was
      approaching in the distance from the opposite side&mdash;the blue uniforms
      and groups with horses, easily recognizable as artillery.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Will they burn the bridge or not? Who&rsquo;ll get there first? Will they get
      there and fire the bridge or will the French get within grapeshot range
      and wipe them out?&rdquo; These were the questions each man of the troops on the
      high ground above the bridge involuntarily asked himself with a sinking
      heart&mdash;watching the bridge and the hussars in the bright evening
      light and the blue tunics advancing from the other side with their
      bayonets and guns.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ugh. The hussars will get it hot!&rdquo; said Nesvítski; &ldquo;they are within
      grapeshot range now.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;He shouldn&rsquo;t have taken so many men,&rdquo; said the officer of the suite.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;True enough,&rdquo; answered Nesvítski; &ldquo;two smart fellows could have done the
      job just as well.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, your excellency,&rdquo; put in Zherkóv, his eyes fixed on the hussars, but
      still with that naïve air that made it impossible to know whether he was
      speaking in jest or in earnest. &ldquo;Ah, your excellency! How you look at
      things! Send two men? And who then would give us the Vladímir medal and
      ribbon? But now, even if they do get peppered, the squadron may be
      recommended for honors and he may get a ribbon. Our Bogdánich knows how
      things are done.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;There now!&rdquo; said the officer of the suite, &ldquo;that&rsquo;s grapeshot.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He pointed to the French guns, the limbers of which were being detached
      and hurriedly removed.
    </p>
    <p>
      On the French side, amid the groups with cannon, a cloud of smoke
      appeared, then a second and a third almost simultaneously, and at the
      moment when the first report was heard a fourth was seen. Then two reports
      one after another, and a third.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh! Oh!&rdquo; groaned Nesvítski as if in fierce pain, seizing the officer of
      the suite by the arm. &ldquo;Look! A man has fallen! Fallen, fallen!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Two, I think.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;If I were Tsar I would never go to war,&rdquo; said Nesvítski, turning away.
    </p>
    <p>
      The French guns were hastily reloaded. The infantry in their blue uniforms
      advanced toward the bridge at a run. Smoke appeared again but at irregular
      intervals, and grapeshot cracked and rattled onto the bridge. But this
      time Nesvítski could not see what was happening there, as a dense cloud of
      smoke arose from it. The hussars had succeeded in setting it on fire and
      the French batteries were now firing at them, no longer to hinder them but
      because the guns were trained and there was someone to fire at.
    </p>
    <p>
      The French had time to fire three rounds of grapeshot before the hussars
      got back to their horses. Two were misdirected and the shot went too high,
      but the last round fell in the midst of a group of hussars and knocked
      three of them over.
    </p>
    <p>
      Rostóv, absorbed by his relations with Bogdánich, had paused on the bridge
      not knowing what to do. There was no one to hew down (as he had always
      imagined battles to himself), nor could he help to fire the bridge because
      he had not brought any burning straw with him like the other soldiers. He
      stood looking about him, when suddenly he heard a rattle on the bridge as
      if nuts were being spilt, and the hussar nearest to him fell against the
      rails with a groan. Rostóv ran up to him with the others. Again someone
      shouted, &ldquo;Stretchers!&rdquo; Four men seized the hussar and began lifting him.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oooh! For Christ&rsquo;s sake let me alone!&rdquo; cried the wounded man, but still
      he was lifted and laid on the stretcher.
    </p>
    <p>
      Nicholas Rostóv turned away and, as if searching for something, gazed into
      the distance, at the waters of the Danube, at the sky, and at the sun. How
      beautiful the sky looked; how blue, how calm, and how deep! How bright and
      glorious was the setting sun! With what soft glitter the waters of the
      distant Danube shone. And fairer still were the faraway blue mountains
      beyond the river, the nunnery, the mysterious gorges, and the pine forests
      veiled in the mist of their summits... There was peace and happiness... &ldquo;I
      should wish for nothing else, nothing, if only I were there,&rdquo; thought
      Rostóv. &ldquo;In myself alone and in that sunshine there is so much happiness;
      but here... groans, suffering, fear, and this uncertainty and hurry...
      There&mdash;they are shouting again, and again are all running back
      somewhere, and I shall run with them, and it, death, is here above me and
      around... Another instant and I shall never again see the sun, this water,
      that gorge!...&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      At that instant the sun began to hide behind the clouds, and other
      stretchers came into view before Rostóv. And the fear of death and of the
      stretchers, and love of the sun and of life, all merged into one feeling
      of sickening agitation.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;O Lord God! Thou who art in that heaven, save, forgive, and protect me!&rdquo;
       Rostóv whispered.
    </p>
    <p>
      The hussars ran back to the men who held their horses; their voices
      sounded louder and calmer, the stretchers disappeared from sight.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, fwiend? So you&rsquo;ve smelt powdah!&rdquo; shouted Váska Denísov just above
      his ear.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;It&rsquo;s all over; but I am a coward&mdash;yes, a coward!&rdquo; thought Rostóv,
      and sighing deeply he took Rook, his horse, which stood resting one foot,
      from the orderly and began to mount.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Was that grapeshot?&rdquo; he asked Denísov.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Yes and no mistake!&rdquo; cried Denísov. &ldquo;You worked like wegular bwicks and
      it&rsquo;s nasty work! An attack&rsquo;s pleasant work! Hacking away at the dogs! But
      this sort of thing is the very devil, with them shooting at you like a
      target.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      And Denísov rode up to a group that had stopped near Rostóv, composed of
      the colonel, Nesvítski, Zherkóv, and the officer from the suite.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, it seems that no one has noticed,&rdquo; thought Rostóv. And this was
      true. No one had taken any notice, for everyone knew the sensation which
      the cadet under fire for the first time had experienced.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Here&rsquo;s something for you to report,&rdquo; said Zherkóv. &ldquo;See if I don&rsquo;t get
      promoted to a sublieutenancy.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Inform the prince that I the bridge fired!&rdquo; said the colonel triumphantly
      and gaily.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;And if he asks about the losses?&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;A trifle,&rdquo; said the colonel in his bass voice: &ldquo;two hussars wounded, and
      one knocked out,&rdquo; he added, unable to restrain a happy smile, and
      pronouncing the phrase &ldquo;knocked out&rdquo; with ringing distinctness.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0037" id="link2HCH0037"></a>
      CHAPTER IX
    </h2>
    <p>
      Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command of
      Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly to it, losing
      confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness of supplies, and
      compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anything that had been
      foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded by
      Kutúzov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube, stopping where
      overtaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actions only as far as
      necessary to enable it to retreat without losing its heavy equipment.
      There had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the
      courage and endurance&mdash;acknowledged even by the enemy&mdash;with
      which the Russians fought, the only consequence of these actions was a yet
      more rapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and
      had joined Kutúzov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army, and
      Kutúzov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces. The defense
      of Vienna was no longer to be thought of. Instead of an offensive, the
      plan of which, carefully prepared in accord with the modern science of
      strategics, had been handed to Kutúzov when he was in Vienna by the
      Austrian Hofkriegsrath, the sole and almost unattainable aim remaining for
      him was to effect a junction with the forces that were advancing from
      Russia, without losing his army as Mack had done at Ulm.
    </p>
    <p>
      On the twenty-eighth of October Kutúzov with his army crossed to the left
      bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time with the
      river between himself and the main body of the French. On the thirtieth he
      attacked Mortier&rsquo;s division, which was on the left bank, and broke it up.
      In this action for the first time trophies were taken: banners, cannon,
      and two enemy generals. For the first time, after a fortnight&rsquo;s retreat,
      the Russian troops had halted and after a fight had not only held the
      field but had repulsed the French. Though the troops were ill-clad,
      exhausted, and had lost a third of their number in killed, wounded, sick,
      and stragglers; though a number of sick and wounded had been abandoned on
      the other side of the Danube with a letter in which Kutúzov entrusted them
      to the humanity of the enemy; and though the big hospitals and the houses
      in Krems converted into military hospitals could no longer accommodate all
      the sick and wounded, yet the stand made at Krems and the victory over
      Mortier raised the spirits of the army considerably. Throughout the whole
      army and at headquarters most joyful though erroneous rumors were rife of
      the imaginary approach of columns from Russia, of some victory gained by
      the Austrians, and of the retreat of the frightened Bonaparte.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew during the battle had been in attendance on the Austrian
      General Schmidt, who was killed in the action. His horse had been wounded
      under him and his own arm slightly grazed by a bullet. As a mark of the
      commander in chief&rsquo;s special favor he was sent with the news of this
      victory to the Austrian court, now no longer at Vienna (which was
      threatened by the French) but at Brünn. Despite his apparently delicate
      build Prince Andrew could endure physical fatigue far better than many
      very muscular men, and on the night of the battle, having arrived at Krems
      excited but not weary, with dispatches from Dokhtúrov to Kutúzov, he was
      sent immediately with a special dispatch to Brünn. To be so sent meant not
      only a reward but an important step toward promotion.
    </p>
    <p>
      The night was dark but starry, the road showed black in the snow that had
      fallen the previous day&mdash;the day of the battle. Reviewing his
      impressions of the recent battle, picturing pleasantly to himself the
      impression his news of a victory would create, or recalling the send-off
      given him by the commander in chief and his fellow officers, Prince Andrew
      was galloping along in a post chaise enjoying the feelings of a man who
      has at length begun to attain a long-desired happiness. As soon as he
      closed his eyes his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the wheels and
      the sensation of victory. Then he began to imagine that the Russians were
      running away and that he himself was killed, but he quickly roused himself
      with a feeling of joy, as if learning afresh that this was not so but that
      on the contrary the French had run away. He again recalled all the details
      of the victory and his own calm courage during the battle, and feeling
      reassured he dozed off.... The dark starry night was followed by a bright
      cheerful morning. The snow was thawing in the sunshine, the horses
      galloped quickly, and on both sides of the road were forests of different
      kinds, fields, and villages.
    </p>
    <p>
      At one of the post stations he overtook a convoy of Russian wounded. The
      Russian officer in charge of the transport lolled back in the front cart,
      shouting and scolding a soldier with coarse abuse. In each of the long
      German carts six or more pale, dirty, bandaged men were being jolted over
      the stony road. Some of them were talking (he heard Russian words), others
      were eating bread; the more severely wounded looked silently, with the
      languid interest of sick children, at the envoy hurrying past them.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew told his driver to stop, and asked a soldier in what action
      they had been wounded. &ldquo;Day before yesterday, on the Danube,&rdquo; answered the
      soldier. Prince Andrew took out his purse and gave the soldier three gold
      pieces.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;That&rsquo;s for them all,&rdquo; he said to the officer who came up.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Get well soon, lads!&rdquo; he continued, turning to the soldiers. &ldquo;There&rsquo;s
      plenty to do still.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;What news, sir?&rdquo; asked the officer, evidently anxious to start a
      conversation.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Good news!... Go on!&rdquo; he shouted to the driver, and they galloped on.
    </p>
    <p>
      It was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved
      streets of Brünn and found himself surrounded by high buildings, the
      lights of shops, houses, and street lamps, fine carriages, and all that
      atmosphere of a large and active town which is always so attractive to a
      soldier after camp life. Despite his rapid journey and sleepless night,
      Prince Andrew when he drove up to the palace felt even more vigorous and
      alert than he had done the day before. Only his eyes gleamed feverishly
      and his thoughts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and
      rapidity. He again vividly recalled the details of the battle, no longer
      dim, but definite and in the concise form in which he imagined himself
      stating them to the Emperor Francis. He vividly imagined the casual
      questions that might be put to him and the answers he would give. He
      expected to be at once presented to the Emperor. At the chief entrance to
      the palace, however, an official came running out to meet him, and
      learning that he was a special messenger led him to another entrance.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;To the right from the corridor, <i>Euer Hochgeboren!</i> There you will find the
      adjutant on duty,&rdquo; said the official. &ldquo;He will conduct you to the Minister
      of War.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The adjutant on duty, meeting Prince Andrew, asked him to wait, and went
      in to the Minister of War. Five minutes later he returned and bowing with
      particular courtesy ushered Prince Andrew before him along a corridor to
      the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work. The adjutant by his
      elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any attempt at familiarity
      on the part of the Russian messenger.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew&rsquo;s joyous feeling was considerably weakened as he approached
      the door of the minister&rsquo;s room. He felt offended, and without his
      noticing it the feeling of offense immediately turned into one of disdain
      which was quite uncalled for. His fertile mind instantly suggested to him
      a point of view which gave him a right to despise the adjutant and the
      minister. &ldquo;Away from the smell of powder, they probably think it easy to
      gain victories!&rdquo; he thought. His eyes narrowed disdainfully, he entered
      the room of the Minister of War with peculiarly deliberate steps. This
      feeling of disdain was heightened when he saw the minister seated at a
      large table reading some papers and making pencil notes on them, and for
      the first two or three minutes taking no notice of his arrival. A wax
      candle stood at each side of the minister&rsquo;s bent bald head with its gray
      temples. He went on reading to the end, without raising his eyes at the
      opening of the door and the sound of footsteps.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Take this and deliver it,&rdquo; said he to his adjutant, handing him the
      papers and still taking no notice of the special messenger.
    </p>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew felt that either the actions of Kutúzov&rsquo;s army interested
      the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was concerned
      with, or he wanted to give the Russian special messenger that impression.
      &ldquo;But that is a matter of perfect indifference to me,&rdquo; he thought. The
      minister drew the remaining papers together, arranged them evenly, and
      then raised his head. He had an intellectual and distinctive head, but the
      instant he turned to Prince Andrew the firm, intelligent expression on his
      face changed in a way evidently deliberate and habitual to him. His face
      took on the stupid artificial smile (which does not even attempt to hide
      its artificiality) of a man who is continually receiving many petitioners
      one after another.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;From General Field Marshal Kutúzov?&rdquo; he asked. &ldquo;I hope it is good news?
      There has been an encounter with Mortier? A victory? It was high time!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      He took the dispatch which was addressed to him and began to read it with
      a mournful expression.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Oh, my God! My God! Schmidt!&rdquo; he exclaimed in German. &ldquo;What a calamity!
      What a calamity!&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      Having glanced through the dispatch he laid it on the table and looked at
      Prince Andrew, evidently considering something.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is not
      captured.&rdquo; Again he pondered. &ldquo;I am very glad you have brought good news,
      though Schmidt&rsquo;s death is a heavy price to pay for the victory. His
      Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today. I thank you! You
      must have a rest. Be at the levee tomorrow after the parade. However, I
      will let you know.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      The stupid smile, which had left his face while he was speaking,
      reappeared.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;<i>Au revoir!</i> Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to see
      you,&rdquo; he added, bowing his head.
    </p>
    <p>
      When Prince Andrew left the palace he felt that all the interest and
      happiness the victory had afforded him had been now left in the
      indifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant. The
      whole tenor of his thoughts instantaneously changed; the battle seemed the
      memory of a remote event long past.
    </p>

</div><!--end chapter-->

<div class="chapter">

    <h2><a name="link2HCH0038" id="link2HCH0038"></a>
      CHAPTER X
    </h2>
    <p>
      Prince Andrew stayed at Brünn with Bilíbin, a Russian acquaintance of his
      in the diplomatic service.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Ah, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor,&rdquo; said
      Bilíbin as he came out to meet Prince Andrew. &ldquo;Franz, put the prince&rsquo;s
      things in my bedroom,&rdquo; said he to the servant who was ushering Bolkónski
      in. &ldquo;So you&rsquo;re a messenger of victory, eh? Splendid! And I am sitting here
      ill, as you see.&rdquo;
     </p>
    <p>
      After washing and dressing, Prince Andrew came into the diplomat&rsquo;s
      luxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him. Bilíbin
      settled down comfortably beside the fire.
    </p>
    <p>
      After his journey and the campaign during which he had been deprived of
      all the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince
      Andrew felt a pleasant sense of repose among luxurious surroundings such
      as he had been accustomed to from childhood. Besides it was pleasant,
      after his reception by the Austrians, to speak if not in Russian (for they
      were speaking French) at least with a Russian who would, he supposed,
      share the general Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was then
      particularly strong.
    </p>
    <p>
      Bilíbin was a man of thirty-five, a bachelor, and of the same circle as
      Prince Andrew. They had known each other previously in Petersburg, but had
      become more intimate when Prince Andrew was in Vienna with Kutúzov. Just
      as Prince Andrew was a young man who gave promise of rising high in the
      military profession, so to an even greater extent Bilíbin gave promise of
      rising in his diplomatic career. He was still a young man but no longer a
      young diplomat, as he had entered the service at the age of sixteen, had
      been in Paris and Copenhagen, and now held a rather important post in
      Vienna. Both the foreign minister and our ambassador in Vienna knew him
      and valued him. He was not one of those many diplomats who are esteemed
      because they have certain negative qualities, avoid doing certain things,
      and speak French. He was one of those, who, liking work, knew how to do
      it, and despite his indolence would sometimes spend a whole night at his
      writing table. He worked well whatever the import of his work. It was not
      the question &ldquo;What for?&rdquo; but the question &ldquo;How?&rdquo; that interested him. What
      the diplomatic matter might be he did not care, but it gave him great
      pleasure to prepare a circular, memorandum, or report, skillfully,
      pointedly, and elegantly. Bilíbin&rsquo;s services were valued not only for what
      he wrote, but also for his skill in dealing and conversing with those in
      the highest spheres.
    </p>
    <p>
      Bilíbin liked conversation as he liked work, only when it could be made
      elegantly witty. In society he always awaited an opportunity to say
      something striking and took part in a conversation only when that was
      possible. His conversation was always sprinkled with wittily original,
      finished phrases of general interest. These sayings were prepared in the
      inner laboratory of his mind in a portable form as if intentionally, so
      that insignificant society people might carry them from drawing room to
      drawing room. And, in fact, Bilíbin&rsquo;s witticisms were hawked about in the
      Viennese drawing rooms and often had an influence on matters considered
      important.
    </p>
    <p>
      His thin, worn, sallow face was covered with deep wrinkles, which always
      looked as clean and well washed as the tips of one&rsquo;s fingers after a
      Russian bath. The movement of these wrinkles formed the principal play of
      expression on his face. Now his forehead would pucker into deep folds and
      his eyebrows were lifted, then his eyebrows would descend and deep
      wrinkles would crease his cheeks. His small, deep-set eyes always twinkled
      and looked out straight.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;Well, now tell me about your exploits,&rdquo; said he.
    </p>
    <p>
      Bolkónski, very modestly without once mentioning himself, described the
      engagement and his reception by the Minister of War.
    </p>
    <p>
      &ldquo;They received me and my news as one receives a dog in a game of
      skittles,&rdquo; said he in conclusion.
    </p>
    <p>
      Bilíbin smiled and the wrinkles on his face disappeared.
    </p>
    <p>
      <i>&ldquo;Cependant, mon cher,&rdquo;</i> he remarked, examining his nails from a
      distance and puckering the skin above his left eye, <i>&ldquo;malgré la haute
      estime que je professe pour</i> the Orthodox Russian army, <i>j&rsquo;avoue que
      votre victoire n&rsquo;est pas des plus victorieuses.&rdquo;</i> *
    </p>
<p class="footnote">
     * &ldquo;But my dear fellow, with all my respect for the Orthodox
